entry.description: One of football's greatest defensive ends. Atkins won All-American honors at Tennessee in 1951 and 1952 and went on to an unparalleled 17-year career in the NFL. Played with the Cleveland Browns, Chicago Bears and New Orleans Saints, was an oft-time All-NFL pick and winner of the Vince Lombardi Award in 1969. Inducted into the Pro Football Hall of Fame.

A National League catcher for 13 seasons with Cincinnati, San Francisco, Milwaukee and Chicago. Bailey posted a lifetime batting average of .265. Played in five All-Star games. Helped lead the Giants to the 1962 pennant and played in the World Series, won by the Yankees, four games to three. Hit three home runs in one game at Brooklyn in 1956.

Served as coach of all sports at Fisk University and Lane College and as athletic director and basketball coach of Knoxville College. He was a star athlete at Tennessee State University and a top pitcher in the Negro National League in the era that produced Satchel Paige, Josh Gibson and Cool Papa Bell.

The first man to leap over 27 feet in the long jump, Boston was a medal winner in three consecutive Olympic games. He won the gold at Rome in 1960, silver at Tokyo in 1964 and a bronze at Mexico City in 1968. A standout athlete at Tennessee State, he later served as a guidance counselor and as a Dean of Student Affairs.

Tailback for the great Tennessee teams of 1938 and 1939, All-American in 1939 and the NFL's first draft choice in 1940. Cafego returned to U.T. as an assistant coach in 1955 and remained a committed member of the Vol staff. His punters and place kickers have ranked among the nations best over the last 20 years. Member of the College Football Hall of Fame.

One of U.T.'s top athletes of the 1920s, a regular on the Vol football, basketball and baseball teams from 1921 through 1924. Selected as the school's best all-around athlete in 1922 and 1923. Also one of Knoxville's most avid tennis enthusiasts throughout the years, having won a number of championships in senior play.

All-Southern football lineman at U.T. 1906-1909. Long time chairman of the U.T. athletics council from the late 1920s to the early '60s. Dean of the U.T. College of Engineering. Served as vice-president of the NCAA and acting commissioner of the Southeastern Conference, 1948. Member of the College Football Hall of Fame. Deceased.

Voted Knoxville's greatest all-around athlete in the Knoxville Journal's half-century poll in 1950. Foxx played at Knoxville High School, was All-SEC wingback on the great Tennessee teams of 1938-40, also a starter on the basketball team and later signed a pro baseball contract with the Giants organization.

The dean of the inductees at age 86, Hollingsworth was one of baseball's hardest-throwing pitchers in the 1920s. Played with the Pittsburgh Pirates in 1921, the Washington Senators in 1923, and the Brooklyn Dodgers in 1924. Set a number of strikeout records in the high minor leagues, and fanned Lou Gehrig in that famous Yankee star's first at-bat in the major leagues.

A versatile athlete who starred on the U.T. basketball teams of the early 1020s, the last Vol to play the "standing guard" role before that position was phased out of the game. Captain of three sports in Knoxville High School. As a sophomore football player in 1921, he scored the first touchdown ever made at the Vol's new gridiron, Shields-Watkins Field.

The dominant female swim star in Knoxville and the South in the 1940s, she won the National Swimming Championship in 1941 and at one time held the national record for the 100-meters. She qualified for the Olympic team in 1948 but did not get to compete because of a conflicting schedule.

This longtime Knoxville sports figure was honored for his contributions in many areas. He coached the YMCA swim teams for almost two decades, 1938-55, set up a competitive swim program at Whittle Springs pool when he was a manager there, and coached the Knoxville Raiders boys football teams to national honors in the 1940s and 1950s.

Head coach of all sports at Austin High School from 1934 through 1966. His football teams posted an all-time record of 221 wins, 63 losses and seven ties, including three national championships, five Southern championships and five state championships. His basketball teams won three state titles.

Manager of the Pittsburgh Pirates 1948-52, National League manager of the year in 1948. Long time manager of championship teams in the New York Yankees farm system in the 1930s and 1940s. Played briefly in the American League as a catcher for the Chicago White Sox in 1913 and the Philadelphia Athletics in 1916-17.

University of Tennessee head football coach from 1926-1962. General Neyland's teams posted records of 173 wins, 31 losses and 12 ties in 21 seasons. Eight of his teams had undefeated regular season records, and the 1951 team won the National Championship. Member of the College Football Hall of Fame. Deceased.

A Young High School football star (1949), Parker went to Jones Junior College in Ellisville, Mississippi, and then transferred to Mississippi State, where he won an All-American quarterback in 1953. Set the Southeastern Conference record for points scored in one season, 120 in 1952. He led the Edmonton Eskimoes to two Grey Cup titles in the Canadian Football League, was named the league's Most Valuable Player three times, and was selected as the CFL's top player of the last 25 years.

An All-State and All-Southern football guard at Knoxville High School in the late 1930s, Ramsey was written off as too small by U.T. scouts. He went to William and Mary, where he made All-American in 1942. After World War II, he signed with the Chicago Cardinals and helped lead that team to the NFL championship in 1947 and was an All-NFL selection several times. Later served as head coach of the Buffalo Bills in the AFL for three seasons in the 1960s. College Football Hall of Fame 1978.

The first Tennessee basketball super star, Reeder scored 36 points in his first game as a Vol in 1913. Later transferred to the University of Delaware, where he won All-East honors, then tantamount to All-American. One of the first basketball players to use the one-hand jump shot. Deceased.

Perhaps Knoxville's finest female athlete, Doris was a star in many sports. She was a national marbles championship contender at age 9, was the star pitcher for a state championship fast pitch softball team at age 14, and a two-time Most Valuable Player in the Women's Professional Baseball League in the 1940s. She led that league in pitching, home runs and stolen bases.

One of college football's all-time great guards. Suffridge starred at Central High School, made All-American three straight years, 1938-40, as mainstay at U.T.'s unbeaten teams of that era. Later played pro football with the Philadelphia Eagles. Member of the College Football Hall of Fame.

All-American end and captain of the unbeaten and untied 1938 Tennessee team. Selected SEC and national coach of the year, 1956. Returned to U.T. as head coach in 1955, eight-year record of 49-29-4, including 10-0 regular season in 1956 when Vols were ranked No. 2 in the nation. Member of College Football Hall of Fame.

A coach, teacher and administrator for over fifty years, Buford began his career at Coal Creek (now Lake City) in 1927 and also coached at Jefferson City, Knoxville High and Knoxville East. His Knoxville High teams of 1941 and 1951 won State Championships.
Captained the Tennessee baseball team in 1919, and two years later he was shortstop for Connie Mack's Philadelphia Athletics. An avid golfer and founder of the Athletic House.
Football halfback for Knoxville College in the 1920s. Coached football at Knoxville Colored High School, 1926-27.

Played basketball for four years at Maryville College and for 22 years in recreation leagues. She also played and managed softball and is a member of the Tennessee Hall of Fame; retired Superintendent of Knox County Schools.
Graduate of Young High and Hiawassee College. Director of City of Knoxville Recreation Bureau for 41 years.

His father was principal of the Black School for the Deaf. He competed in the 1928 Olympics and trained at U.T. for the Olympics. In the 1932 Olympics in Los Angeles, he won the long-jump gold medal (25-3/4) and he was given a parade on his return to Knoxville.
Football player at U.T., 1922-25. Captain of the Vols, 1924-25. Member, National Football Hall of Fame.

Played football and basketball for Petie Siler at Morristown High and he was All-Southeastern Conference at Tennessee. Captain of the 1937 Vols and was recognized on several All-American teams. He was City Tennis Champion in 1937 and senior singles Champion of the Stat in 1958.

He was a football legend at Knoxville High and he won a varsity letter as an eighth grader at Park Junior High. He scored ten touchdowns in a four-game flurry as a Trojan. He had the winning touchdown for Tennessee against Auburn in 1935, but his college career was cut short by injury.
He was known as "The Red Grange of Central High;" as quarterback and safety man he gained 1500, 2282 and 2150 yards in three varsity seasons. Pinky played at Tennessee Wesleyan and at Mercer.

Tommy grew up near Whittle Springs Golf Course and was one of the top golfers ever developed in Knoxville. He was the first Knoxvillian to win the State Amateur Championship and also the first Knoxvillian to play on the professional tour.
Played football for Knoxville High in mid 1930's. Played tailback for U.T., 1939-41.
Baseball player for Boston Braves. Won the National League pennant in 1914. Coached Knoxville High football team, 1928-1942. Won 1983 National Prep Team Championship.
Top-ranked amateur boxer; pro two years. Head of Knoxville Golden Gloves. Member Tennessee Athletic Commission, 1955-1980.
Won 1950 Knoxville Journal Southern Appalachian Golf Championship. Turned pro in 1957. Established Space Coast Mini-tour.
Austin High basketball player in late 1950s. Twice All-America at the University of Cincinnati. Won NCAA Championships 1961 and 1962 (tourney MVP). New York Knicks #1 draft choice in 1963.
U.T. Football player and track star, 1923-27. Assistant U.T. football coach in 1930s and 1940s. Knoxville High football coach in late 1940s and early 1950s.
Baseball player during youth. Tennis instructor at Tyson Park. One of top senior tennis players in Tennessee.
Racecar driver during late 1920s and early 1930s. Placed third in 1931 Indianapolis 500.

Lettered in football, basketball, and tennis at Central High, 1932-36. Knox County Tennis Champ, 1944; Tennessee Pro-Am Golf Championship, 1952; won Southern Appalachian, 1959-1963; State Seniors, 1968.
Outstanding swimmer won 1953 NCAA 100 yard freestyle. Held six SEC records: 50, 100, 200 yard freestyle, 100 and 200 back stroke, 150 yard medley relay.
Knoxville News-Sentinel sports writer and editor, 1929-1980. Covered all sports from marbles to the Olympics. Campaigned for all-around sports program at U.T. including women's athletics and SEC.

Hobe was a Minor League baseball player in the 1920s and was a manager in the Appalachian League for a number of years. From 1937-41 his teams won five baseball pennants, and his teams won seven pennants in ten years as a Minor League manager. At 88 years of age, he was the oldest of the 1985 inductees.

Ken played Major League baseball with Cincinnati and St. Louis, compiling a pitching record over a five-year span of 28-2. He was a Major League umpire for seventeen years before retiring in 1973, and he never missed a game assigned to him and officiated 3,433 games. During his umpiring tenure, he worked three World Series and four All-Star games.

Alex began his swimming career at age fifteen and was a member of the Knoxville High School swim team, 1935-38, and the University of Tennessee swim team, 1938-42. He helped organize the Knoxville Aquatic Club and taught swimming and life saving for the YMCA and the Boys Club. He has twice won the National Long Distance Swimming Championship in the two-mile lake swim in the All-American Master Swimmer Championships. He has competed in the International Master Swim Meet program from 1978 to present and has competed in four countries and Hawaii.

Ray played high school football at Rhea County and Rockwood. He was captain of five football squads, Rockwood, Knoxville Central, Tennessee Wesleyan, Tennessee and the Philadelphia Eagles. In 1960, he became a head football coach and athletic director at Florida. Ray was the coach of the 1969 Florida team that beat U.T. in the Gator Bowl. While at Florida, he coached two outstanding players who went on to play pro football, John Reaves and Steve Spurrier.

Stanley began his boxing career as a participant in 1944 attending the University of South Carolina on an athletic scholarship for boxing. He officiated in the First National Golden Gloves Tournament and has since officiated tournaments in sixteen different countries. In 1976, Stan was selected as the only U.S. Official of the Year and has been inducted into the Tennessee, Alabama and Georgia Boxing Halls of Fame.

Gene was a baseball star at Knoxville High (1931-33) and at U.T. (1935-37). While at U.T., he was an All-SEC guard in 1937 and played on a Vol team that won 27 straight games. He worked with the City Bureau of Recreation for twenty years and helped develop Little League baseball in 1947 and Biddy baseball in 1951. During that time he worked with under privileged boys at the Lamar Street Recreation Center.

Jack first gained notoriety in 1937 as a swimmer in the 50 and 100-yard butterfly. He served as commissioner of football for the KFOA for 26 years and was elected as commissioner in basketball, an office he held for 31 years. In 1976, Jack was the recipient of the Distinguished Service Award for the East Tennessee Chapter of the National Football Foundation Hall of Fame.

Lindsey is a member of the National Sportswriters and Sportscasters Hall of Fame and was the play-by-play announcer for the New York Mets for seventeen years. He began his career as an assistant publicity director and special tutor for U.T. athletes as a U.T. undergraduate in the late 1930s and early 1940s. He began his radio career in Knoxville and joined NBC-TV in the 1950s, becoming one of the nation's top sportscasters.

In the 1930s, Bernice was one of the top female athletes in the Knoxville area excelling in basketball and softball. From 1930-34, she was the City Women's Tennis Champion and was runner-up in the State Championship in 1930. She was also a city council member from 1968-72 and 1976-83.

Harvey played tailback for the Vols in the early 30s under General R. R. Neyland and succeeded him as head coach (1953-54). He was also on the first Tennessee team to win a Southeastern Conference cage title in 1936. He devoted 43 years to football as a player, was Central High School's head coach, coached at U.T. and was a scout for the Dallas Cowboys.

Jack played collegiate tennis at Rice University and won the National Intercollegiate Championship. In the 1940s, he was the top men's tennis player in the city and was the tennis pro at Cherokee Country Club. He won the State Men's Singles championship three times and was nationally recognized for more than thirty years as a player, coach, professional and administrator.

Ed was an end on the Tennessee Football teams of 1938, 1939 and 1940 that were undefeated and went to the Orange, Rose and Sugar Bowls. He was an All-NFL Player with the Washington Redskins in 1942 and, after serving in the U.S. Navy during World War II, he played for the Chicago Bears in 1946-47. In 1965, he was presented a Silver Anniversary Award by Sports Illustrated.

Earl made his contribution through helping youth by organizing and coaching youth baseball. This former Knoxville Police Department captain and Sid Hatfield managed "The Prospectors" team that won the National Stan Musical Championship at Battle Creek, Michigan in 1964. He coached and managed Babe Ruth League All-Stars and helped organize baseball for the 13-14 age groups. His Cardinals had an 18-0 record, and his FOP teams won State Championships in 1958, 1959 and 1964.

Bill won the 1951 SEC Tennis Singles Championship and teamed with John Cullum to win the SEC Doubles Title. While at U.T. he served as the captain of the Tennis Team and received an invitation to play at Wimbleton in 1953. He won the Rodgers Memorial Title in 1953 and served as Pro at Cherokee Country Club in 1955. While the Tennis Pro in Palm Springs, California, he taught such celebrities as Dinah Shore, Kirk Douglas, Gregory Peck, Robert Stack, David Hartman, and Dino Martin.

Paul was an All-State center at Young High School in 1941 and played his collegiate career at Ole Miss. He coached at Jones Junior College 1950-54, was head coach at Mississippi State 1961-66 and was voted SEC Coach of the Year in 1963. Paul was Defensive Coordinator for the Auburn Tigers under Coach Shug Jordan. In 1973, the Birmingham Touchdown Club voted him SEC Assistant Coach of the Year. While at Mississippi State he coached two Knoxvillians, Jackie Parker and D. D. Lewis. He coached one year in the Canadian Football League in Edmonton, Alberta.

Tommy was one of Knoxville's greatest fast pitch softball pitchers. He began playing in 1928 when softball originated. He pitched for the Booker Davidson team that won the State Tournament and reached the semifinals of the National Tournament at Chicago's Soldier Field. He struck out 15 batters in one game and pitched two no-hit, no-run games. In the late 20s he won the 118-Pound Title News Sentinel Golden Gloves Tournament and was on the YMCA Wrestling team that won the Southern YMCA Wrestling Championship in 1928.

Jake is a Knoxville College graduate and coached the Florida A&M Rattlers for 25 years with a record of 203 wins, 36 losses and 4 ties. At his retirement in 1970, his winning percentage was .845, the best among active coaches. His teams won six National Negro College Championships. In 1975, Jake was presented the Triple Crown of Awards: the Amos Alonzo Stagg Award from the American Football Coaches Association, the Walter Camp Foundation Award, and was inducted into the College Football Hall of Fame. Jake was inducted into the Tennessee Sports Hall of Fame in 1970. He retired as A&M Athletic Director in 1975.
Football and basketball coach at Knoxville College, 1928-1947. YMCA professional, 1943-1972. Southern Intercollegiate Athletic Conference Hall of Fame.

Billy became the first University of Tennessee diver to win an event at the Southeastern Conference Swim Championship winning the 1-meter in 1941 and 1942. He transferred to Compton Junior College in California and won the California 1 and 3 Meter Diving titles and the Mexican 3-Meter Diving title. He won five city meet diving titles in Knoxville at Whittle Springs Pool and captured the Tennessee AAU Championship and the National Junior Title. He also played blocking back under Coach Bob Neyland at U.T. He was inducted into the Tennessee Swim Hall of Fame in 1985.

Rose won 10 Women's City Golf Tournament titles and 8 Knox Area Women's Golf Association titles. Her last Women's City Title was won in a sudden death playoff in 1981. She won five city titles in 1971, '72,'73,'75 and 1976 and three Knoxville Area Women's Golf Association titles in four years. While away from Knoxville for 6 years (1962-68), Rose taught tennis for the Parks and Recreation Department in Huntsville, Alabama and won 27 One-Day Invitational Golf Tournaments. During the 50s and early 60s she taught Physical Education for both City and County School Systems.

In 1986, Bob had served as the Golden Gloves Physician in Knoxville for 28 years. In 1974 he served as the Ringside Physician at the National AAU Tournament held at the Knoxville Civic Coliseum and the National Golden Gloves Tournament in Lowell, Mass. In 1974, he accompanied the U.S. Boxing Team to Poland and the U. S. Team to Cuba in 1978. He has also served as personal physician to Heavyweight Champion Big John Tate and Featherweight Challenger Bernard Taylor. Bob was voted into the Southern Boxing Hall of Fame in 1983.

Bob began his association with the University of Tennessee in 1936 playing as a lineman of the football team from 1936 to 1938. He served as a coach at Baylor for three years, Florida for 10 years and was an Assistant Football Coach under Bowden Wyatt before becoming Athletic Director in 1963. During his twenty-three years as Athletic Director at U.T., Tennessee won National Championships in Cross-country (1972), Track and Field (1974), and Swimming (1978). During Woodruff's years as the Athletic Director, the Vols won the Southeastern Conference All-Sports Trophy four times, five times before it became the official Bernie Moore Award.

Tommy grew up under the influence of a former hall of fame inductee George Lebow. He graduated from Knoxville High in 1946 where he earned letters in basketball, football, track and tennis. He graduated from U.T. in 1952 Cum Laude and earned letters in basketball and tennis. While at U.T. he was named All-Southeastern Conference in basketball in 1952 and was undefeated in college tennis singles play. Tommy has coached basketball at Dandridge High School, Lenoir City High School, Carson Newman, University of Florida, and the University of Tennessee Chattanooga. He coached tennis at the University of Chattanooga, University of Tennessee and University of Tennessee Chattanooga. He was selected the U.S.P.T.A. National Player of the Year in 1986 for the 5th time and he has won numerous city, state, regional and national tennis titles.

Ben joined the Journal's Sports Department in 1947 and became Sports Editor for the Journal in 1969. Over his 40 year career with the Journal, Ben has written about virtually every inductee. He graduated from Young High School in 1942 and worked at the Journal while attending U.T. He has been named Sports Writer of the Year in Tennessee five times. He has written three books. The latest he co-authored, "You Can Go Home Again." He has written his noted column "Byrd's Eye View" for years and played a significant part in promoting the new basketball arena.

Quinn was the sometimes forgotten member of U.T.'s most famous backfield in the early years of the Bob Neyland era. He was the fullback in the unit that boasted Bobby Dodd at quarterback and Gene McEver and Buddy Hackman at halfbacks (known as Hack, Mack and Dodd). He played on the 1928, 1929 and 1930 teams that only lost one game. This was considered Neyland's first great team. After graduation he spent one year as the freshman coach at U.T. and then went to Central High School as head coach in 1932, 1933, and 1934. He left Central and became assistant coach at Centre College in Danville, KY and later became head coach. In 1946, he became head coach at The Citadel in Charleston, SC and coached there until 1952. In 1950 The Citadel beat South Carolina, which only makes the second time in the schools history that South Carolina had lost The Citadel.

Gladys began playing tennis in St. Petersburg, Florida in the 1930s and she came to U.T. in 1942 majoring in Micro Biology. In the 1950s and 1960s she played in city and local tournaments. She won many singles and doubles tournaments with Mary Jane Garcia, Larry Grable and mixed doubles with John Cullum. During the late 40s and early 50s she won five city singles championships. She began teaching tennis at the Ramey Tennis School and attended the National Tennis Teachers workshop in New York City on eight occasions. She taught the non credit-tennis course at UT for years and has coached Candy Reynolds, a world ranked player. In January 1987, she won the 65 singles in the Southern Senior Women Closed Indoor and will represent Tennessee in the 65' in the 1st Southern Senior Cup.

D. D. is a native of Knoxville and a graduate of Fulton High School and Mississippi State. In 1967 D. D. was name All-American and Southeastern Conference Player of the Year. He played thirteen years as linebacker for the Dallas Cowboys and holds the record for playing in more play-off games than any other player (27) and five Super Bowls. D. D. began the D. D. Lewis/Boys Club Celebrity Golf Tournament in 1979, which helped establish the D. D. Lewis Fund as well as the Boys Club of Christenberry Heights in 1982.

Pat began his professional baseball career by signing a contract with the Knoxville Smokies of the old Southern Association. The tall right-hander was promoted to the Dodgers in 1949 where he posted a 1-1 record as a reliever. After an arm operation in 1949 Pat was optioned to the Texas League and played AAA ball with Montreal and St. Paul for four years. He played a total of 15 seasons, including two in Havana, and pitched three no hit games and only posted one losing year in professional ball. In an All Star game, which went nineteen innings, Pat pitched the entire game and hit in the winning run in the nineteenth inning to win the game. He also pitched a seventeen inning game.

Ray was head basketball coach at U.T. from 1962-77 and over the 15 year period, his teams won three Southeastern Conference titles in 1967, 1972, and 1977 with a win-loss record of 278-112 (.713 winning percentage). In the mid 1970s, he attracted Vol fans with his Ernie and Bernie Show (Ernie Grunfield and Bernard King). He is a graduate of Miami of Ohio and coached Whittenberg College to the N.C. A.A. Division II Championship in 1961. He became Athletic Director at U.T. Martin in February 1980.

Clifford began his teaching and coaching in Atmore, Alabama and moved to Hale High School in Maryville. After coaching four sports at Vine Junior, he then moved to Austin East where he combined a coaching record of 600 wins and 183 losses. He coached Austin East to its first State Basketball Championship in 1977. After he retired from the Knoxville City School system, he coached at Knoxville college for six years. Clifford has won KIL Coach of the Year four times, District Coach seven times, and State Coach once. He was in the final eight for National Coach of the Year and selected Kellogg Coach of the Year. He was also selected to coach the East against the West TSSAA Championship game. He played basketball and tennis at Austin High School and Knoxville College. In 1981, he was a member of the section committee on the McDonald All-American High School selection team.

B.E. began his coaching career at Tellico Plains High School and taught for over 42 years in the Knoxville City School system. He was a prominent figure in track and field and coached many regional and state championship teams. While coaching football at Knoxville High, his teams won three successive State Championships in 1942, 1943, and 1944. After Knoxville High closed he went to Fulton High and after his retirement in 1958 he went to Webb. His Fulton High teams never lost to another city school team and while at Webb he won the Mid-South Championship in track 1967 and 1968 and was runner-up in 1969. After retiring from Webb he began coaching at Knoxville Catholic until his death in October 1969.

Eddie, "The Knoxville Bear," never played in a billiard tournament until he was 41. His first tournament was in Macon, Georgia in a tournament sponsored by Roy Gamby. He finished second in snooker and nine ball. In 1961, he lost in the finals to Luther Lassiter for the World Championship. In 1963 in Johnston City, Illinois, Eddie won the one pocket World Championship that was televised over Sports Spectacular. In 1964 he won the U.S. Open Nine Ball Tournament and the World's All-Round Championship (this includes one pocket, nine ball and straight pool) beating Lassiter in the finals. In 1967 Eddie won the Stardust Open in Las Vegas at the Stardust Hotel. During his career, Eddie was considered the best bank pool player in the world.

Coach Bussard coached swimming at U.T. for 21 seasons, winning a national championship in 1978 and eight Southeastern Conference titles, seven in a row from 1972-78. His Vols finished in NCAA's top five from 1972 through 1979. He was twice selected NCAA swim coach of the year, in 1972 and 1978. He was considered to have been the world's best sprint-freestyle coach. He was an assistant coach at the 1984 Olympics and the 1979 Pan-Am Games. He coordinated the U.S. Soviet Union dual meet at U.T. Student Aquatic Center in 1982. Two of his swimmers won Olympic gold medals?freestyler David Edgar (1972) and butterflyer Matt Vogel (1976).

Buddy Cruze had an outstanding high school career in football and basketball at Knoxville High and East High School before earning All-American honors in football at Tennessee as an end. He was All-State in football and basketball at East High during the 1951-52 school year and was named to All-Southern and All-American high school teams. Cruze set the state High School Tournament single-game record of 47 points against Oliver Springs. It was Cruze's reception of a pass from Johhny Majors that set up the only touchdown in U.T.'s 7-0 victory over Georgia Tech in 1956 that lifted the Vols to the No.1 ranking the following week.

A.W. was a U.T. basketball player and captain and an All-American in 1964-65. He started three seasons for U.T. and twice was All-SEC. In a 1976 poll, Davis was voted best high school player in Tennessee since 1951. He averaged 30.5 points as a junior at Rutledge High in 1959-60 and 34.9 in 1960-61. He was drafted by the Los Angeles Lakers in the fifth round in 1965. He served as assistant coach to U.T.'s Ray Mears 1970-74, coached at Walter State Community College for two years and was TJCAA coach of the year each season. For many years he also worked with John Ward as color commentator with the Vol Network as an announcer.

entry.category: Female High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description: Tracie is a 1988 graduate of Farragut High School. She was a dual sports competitor playing basketball and soccer. Her basketball career began as a freshman; as a sophomore she was selected to the 1st team in the KIL, and she also played AAU. During her Junior year she was 2nd team All-East Tennessee and her Senior year she was selected to the 1st team in the KIL and was Honorable Mention All-East Tennessee and All-State. During her Junior year as a soccer player she was All-Region, All-Tournament (MVP) and All-State. During her Senior year she was All-American, selected Top Player in Region 2, All-Region, All KIL (MVP) and All-State. She was featured on E.S.P.N., TV on the Honor Roll Segment of the show. She signed a college soccer scholarship to the University of North Carolina at Greensboro.

Ann was a golf and basketball star as a youngster in Maryville, winning the Knox Area Women's Golf Association Championship when she was 13. She won the KAWGA Championship 12 times, the State women's amateur golf title five times and the Southern women's amateur championship in 1978. She was the No. 1 ranked junior golfer in the country and No. 5 among women amateurs in 1962. At Maryville High School she led the girl's high school basketball scoring in the state with a 35-point average. She was granted a Neyland Scholarship to attend U.T. in 1963 and became the first female athlete to compete on a U.T. men's athletic team. She graduated cum laude in 1967 and became the first woman and also the youngest person, in 177 years, to be appointed to the board of trustees. She was also the first woman to serve on the U.T. Athletics Board.
Major league baseball player during 1940s; Brooklyn Dodgers, 1943; the Boston Braves, 1945-48; and the Washington Senators, 1948.

entry.category: Male High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description: 1988 grad of Austin-East, was member of the State Champs, 1986, and was All-State Quarterback. Recognized as a scholar/athlete, and received a number of awards including the "Johnny Mauer Award."

Coach Mauer coached basketball and was an assistant football coach at Tennessee and Florida. After eight years at Miami of Ohio, Mauer came to Tennessee where his basketball teams won 128 and lost only 42 (a.755 percentage) while winning two SEC championships. Mauer also served as an assistant football coach to Bowden Wyatt. Was a teammate of legendary Harold "Red" Grange at Illinois and captained the Illinois basketball team. He coached Kentucky basketball from 1927 to 1930 and was succeeded by Adolph Rupp. He coached Florida basketball 1953-60 and returned to U.T. in 1961 as an end coach under Bowden Wyatt.

Raleigh is a graduate of Austin-East High School, Class of 1980, and a 1984 graduate of the University of Tennessee. While a student at Austin-East he played football, baseball, basketball and track. While at U.T. he played offensive center and guard. Johnny Majors praised Raleigh as one of the best offensive linemen I've been around. He had a fine career at U.T. culminating in the Japan Bowl all-star game. In his senior year, he was named Offensive Player of the Game against Auburn. He was drafted by the Washington Redskins and began his professional career as an offensive guard in 1985. This past season he was a member of the 1988 Super Bowl Team with the Washington Redskins. He joins two other Knoxvillians Bill Anderson and D. D. Lewis, in winning a Super Bowl.

Played in the last Knoxville High Basketball Team, and the team won the State Championship in 1951. He was All-KIL as a center and linebacker at East High in 1952. He began his coaching career at Park Junior High where he coached football, basketball, baseball, and track. He later was an assistant football coach at South High, East High and Holston High. "Doc" was a former West High School principal who had previously officiated high school basketball and football in the Southeastern and Ohio Valley Conferences. He was President of the Knoxville Basketball Officials Association from 1976-85. He was a leader in the drive to make competitive sports available to youngsters. He served on the TSSAA Board of Control before his retirement in 1986. In 1988 he was inducted into the TSSAA Hall of Fame, as an Administrator.
Football end for U.T. from 1959-61. Drafted by Buffalo Bills, 1961. Selected to AFL All-Star team, 1964. Played for San Diego, 1972-73.

Vaughn was a tailback on the Tennessee football team 1932-34. The Vols won 24 games, lost five and tied one during those years. Vaughan earned All-American and All-Southeastern Conference honors. He was considered to have been one of Tennessee's greatest passers during the single-wing days. He played at Knoxville High before attending U.T. and played for the Detroit Lions and Chicago Cardinals after completing his eligibility at Tennessee.

Wright was a baseball and basketball star at Knoxville High in the late 1930s, and then was a standout in those sports at Tennessee and Duke. He was on two KHS state championship basketball teams. Made All-SEC at U.T. and All-Southern at Duke, playing for the Blue Devils during World War II as a U. S. Marine trainee. After returning to U.T. as a basketball guard and completing his final season (1946-47), Wright signed a baseball contract with St. Louis Browns of the American League. He was sent to Aberdeen, S.D. to play minor-league ball and suffered a long bout with tuberculosis, which ended his baseball-playing career. He coached basketball and baseball at West High before taking a student counseling position with U.T. He coached U.T. baseball teams 19 years before retiring in 1981 (395-291-2 record). He organized the Bill Wright Diamond Dinner, Knoxville's winter baseball banquet.

Football player at Austin High. Played football at Clark College. At Tennessee State ran track, played football, basketball and baseball. All-Conference team 1946. Black College All-American team 1948-1949.

Lloyd Foree was born and raised in Niota, Tennessee and first came to Knoxville to compete in a hole-in-one contest in the late 30s. After winning the contest he turned pro and became an assistant pro at Cherokee Country Club in the spring of 1936 under Richard Clarkson. Foree was a radio operator on a B-17 during WWII and upon his return to Knoxville, he worked briefly at Whittle Springs Golf Course and then at Holston Hill Country Club. In 1948, Foree became the first pro at Dean Hill Country Club and remained at Dean Hill until his death. During his pro career he won the Tennessee State Open in the Pro Division. Lloyd had a very successful television show for more than ten years on WTVK, Channel 26, interviewing golfers and giving golf instructions. He was extremely popular with his fellow pros as well as with the amateurs.

Dana Royal Forsyth has won many honors as both a player and a teacher. She has been ranked #1 in the state and #1 in the south in both the 35 and 40 age group and has won 6 city championships. Her contributions and accomplishments as a teaching professional are equally impressive. She was named USTA Tennis Pro of the Year in 1981 in large part due to the work she did in the area of junior tennis. Dana is responsible for the development of "Junior Team Tennis," the "Junior Grand Prix Tournament Circuit" and the "Knoxville Junior Tennis Development Program." She is, indeed, one of Knoxville's greatest tennis ambassadors.
Knoxville College athlete. 28-year veteran of Knoxville Recreation Bureau.

entry.category: Male High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description: Brad, a senior at Central High School was a cross country and track star. Higdon represents Central High School with outstanding attitude and effort. He won 1st place in the State Cross Country Meet in Nashville, regional 1st place and outstanding runner in the Dan Crow Relays, KIL 1st place and outstanding runner in the News-Sentinel Relays, and district 1st place and outstanding runner in the Karns Invitational.

Joe Higdon was the manager/coach of the 1937 Booke-Davidson Fast Pitch Softball Team. This team was the only Knoxville team to win a state championship. The team went to the National Tournament in Chicago and was defeated in the quarterfinals by Miami, Florida 1-0. Joe was a big supporter of fast softball, which was a great sport in the Knoxville area in the late 30s and 40s. Some of the team members included Tommy Ford, Harry Nacey, Bob Foxx, Ott Shetterly, Al Thomas, Frank Higdon, Ray Cannon and Red Hankins.

Hutchens was a longtime football coach at Rule High and also coached at Fulton. The football field at Rule is named for him. Hutchens is best remembered for his work as head football coach at Rule High School in the 1940s and '50s. Taking over a program that was well below the top level, he soon had the Golden Bears competing on even terms with Knoxville's Big Three of the period ? Knoxville High, Central and Young. He was one of the most popular men on the local sports scene for three decades, as highly regarded as a sportsman as he was a coach.

Tim Irwin started his football career at Central High School where he played tight end and noseguard and was an All-State selection in football and an All-East Tennessee nominee as a center on the school basketball team. Tim was a three-year letterman, two-year starter, captain, and team offensive MVP his senior year at the University of Tennessee. He played in the Japan Bowl and the East-West Shrine Game and was an Academic All-American Selection. Tim became a fixture as right tackle with the Minnesota Vikings and assumed the starting job when Ron Yary retired following the 1981 season. In 1986 he started every game and he entered the 1987 season with the longest consecutive start streak amongst active Viking players (73 games). In 1984, he tied a Viking team record with two blocked field goal attempts in a single game against Atlanta. Tim attended law school during the off- season.

Johnson is an outstanding runner and has completed 10 consecutive Boston Marathons and finished third in the Masters Division in 1984. That was the same year she was the first woman ever to complete the course in the Old Dominion 100-mile endurance race. She also has completed five 100-mile runs and has set national age records for 50 miles, 100K, and 50K. In 1988 Johnson ran the length of the Appalachian Trail through the Smoky Mountain National Park in 18 hours and 50 minutes and has run from downtown Gatlinburg to the top of Mt. LeConte and back in less than 4.5 hours. She was the executive director of the Knox County Association for Retarded Citizens.

Kozar was the hard-charging fullback on the Vols national championship team of 1951. He played for U.T. in 1950-52 and he played in the 1953 College All-Star game. His inside rushing provided the perfect balance for All-America tailback Hank Lauricella's outside running, and that backfield unit of Kozar, Lauricella, wingback Bert Rechichar and blocking back Jimmy Hahn is regarded as one of the greatest in Tennessee football history. Kozar later earned a doctorate in physical education and has been a high-ranking member of the U.T. administration and faculty staff for the last two decades. In recognition of his accomplishments and contributions, the NCAA honored Kozar with their prestigious Silver Anniversary Award.

entry.category: Female High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description: Amy, a Bearden High School graduate, was an outstanding student academically as well as a volleyball, basketball, and softball star. Her senior year, McManus was captain of the volleyball and co-captain of the basketball and softball team, news paper editor, Southern Association of Student Councils co-president, and National Honor Society Secretary. Among her athletic achievements are most athletic in senior class, volleyball letter winner, starter, and All-District for four years, volleyball all-region and all-state, basketball MVP and All-District her senior year, and softball All-District her senior year.

Ace Miller is the director of amateur boxing in Knoxville and was elected to a second two-year term as president of the National Golden Gloves. He directed the National Golden Gloves tournament in Knoxville two times, (the second being May 1989). Miller developed the Knoxville Golden Gloves program into one of the nation's finest. One of his pupils, Big John Tate, won a bronze medal for the U.S. in Montreal Olympic Games if 1976, then turned professional under Miller's management and fought his way to the heavyweight championship of the world in 1980. Miller has also served as manager of Bernard Taylor, one of the nation's top lightweights.

Needham starred at old Knoxville High School and was captain of the 1931 football team, which won the high school state championship for the third straight year. He was named All-State, All Southern and All-American as he led his team to a perfect 13-0 season . . .they outscored their opponents 592-12. "Shorty" played guard for General Bob Neyland's 1933-35 University of Tennessee Volunteers. Despite being one of the smallest linemen ever to play for the Vols, he was a three-year letterman, 1933-34-35. Shy and retiring off the field, Needham was a veritable demon when engaged in football activity.

Rohe was responsible for building a dynasty in track and field, having coached the Vols to 20 SEC championships and 16 All-Americans during the eight years he coached at U.T. and resided in Knoxville. U.T.'s overall record during the Rohe era 120-16, including a 41-0 record indoors. Rohe was the Director of the NCAA Track and Field Championships held on the new Tom Black Track in 1969, attracting some of the world's best athletes and also 15,000 spectators. Under Rohe's dynamic leadership, Knoxville became the "track center of the South," with many National AAU and high school invitation meets being held every year. He organized the very first Dogwood Relays and Tom Black Classic (now called the Gatorade Classic), which became two of the top track meets in the nation. Rohe was one of the founders of the United States Track and Field Federation and also was instrumental in the organization of the old World Football League.

Walker, this year's special contributor inductee, worked for the city recreation bureau from 1944-83. He developed and administrated comprehensive year-round recreation program for the citizens of Knoxville. From 1965-83, Walker spent much of his time as the director of the Cal Johnson center, where his well-organized program was regarded as a model. Walker received three leadership awards from the Tennessee Recreation and Park Association and received a twenty-year service award from the Southern Association. Locally, the City Council renamed the Wilson-Castle Field as the Claude A. Walker Field in recognition of his dedication and professionalism.
Central High football player during 1930s. Central High head football coach 1951 to 1958. Won four Knoxville football titles during 1950s.
Basketball and football official for over 40 years. SEC official 17 years, and Ohio Valley Conference Official for 18 years.

Cartha played women's fast pitch softball from age 13 until 1967. Her career included several state and regional titles and two trips to the World Women's Softball Tournament. She also played women's professional baseball in 1947. As a coach, she had two state championship teams. Cartha was a softball umpire for ten years until her retirement in 1982. During these years she umpired three Women's National Tournaments and numerous state and regional tournaments.

entry.category: Male High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description: Led his Central High baseball team to 1990 State Championship. Player of the Year in 1989/90. 11-0 with a 0.52 ERA and .505 batting average.
Tennis players for over 30 years. Selected U.S.T.A.'s Tennis Family of the Year in 1976.

Ed began his career with the Knoxville Journal in the late 1920s and served as Journal sports editor from 1940 to 1974. He has been recognized often for his work as a sports journalist and as a leader in the sports community.

Long-time assistant sports editor for News Sentinel, he was on that newspaper's staff from mid 1930s until his retirement in 1980. Recognized as a fine newspaperman and leader in the sports community.

Bill was prep All-American at Fulton High School in 1965. He played on the University of Tennessee's 1967 SEC basketball championship team as a sophomore starting guard. Bill played under Coach Ray Mears and was Vol Captain in his senior season. In 1968 Bill was a unanimous All-SEC selection and was drafted by the Dallas Cowboys of the NFL, the Philadelphia 76ers of the NBA and the ABA's Denver team.

entry.category: Female High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description: Amy was an all-star athlete from Halls High School and a KIL Player of the Year. She led the Lady Red Devils softball team to the Tennessee State High School Tournament Final Four, two consecutive years. Amy had a .62 ERA and when not busy hitting home runs and triples she traded in her cleats for basketball sneakers and soccer shoes, sports she also excelled in at Halls.

Ed began his love for basketball as an 11-year-old YMCA Pirate. He had an outstanding basketball record at Knoxville High School in the 1940s, making the All District Team each of the three years he was there. Ed went on to be the University of Tennessee's guard from 1946 to 1949. While at U.T., Ed led the Volunteers to the heartbreak UT/KY SEC game, where KY lost its first SEC after 36 straight wins. Ed made All-South Eastern Conference Team his senior year. Ed's 32- point record for most points scored in a single game at U.T. held up for five years.

1990 marks the end of Pay Ryan's 13-year career with the New York Jets. After playing for the University of Tennessee from 1973 to 1977, Pat was drafted by the Jets and stayed with the team throughout his professional career. Used mainly as a back-up quarterback, Pat was considered one of the most effective back-up quarterbacks in the league throwing 39 touchdowns for 5,280 yards and a completion percentage of 57%. In 1986, with the team suffering a 5 game losing streak, Pat was given the starting job in the first game of the playoff. He threw 3 touchdowns and led the team to a 35-15 victory over Kansas City. Pat's best performance came in 1988 when he passed for 341 yards and threw 4 touchdowns in a 35 to 28 victory over Miami.
Played football for Central High in mid-1940s. U.T. All-SEC defensive end, 1949 and 1950. Played professional football for New York Giants.

An all around athlete, Ron was a Fulton High School Falcon along with teammate Billy Justus. Ron lettered in football, basketball, golf, and baseball at U.T. As a forward, Ron led his team to the 1967 SEC basketball championship. The same year Ron was Sporting News All-American punter. In 1967 Ron was named to the third team UPI All-American basketball team. The following year Ron led the nation as a football punter with a 43.8-yard average. Ron's professional athletic career continued this football-basketball trend. As a seven-year veteran of the NFL, Ron punted for the Dallas Cowboys and went to the Super Bowl twice before going on to the Green Bay Packers. Ron also played professional basketball in the ABA for New Orleans.
Six-time All-America track runner for U.T. in 1970s. Was alternate on 1972 Olympic 400-meter relay team. Won 1947 NCAA Championship 440 relay. Captain 1977 U.T. track team.

Chris pitched his way from the Central High School Bobcats to the major leagues. Drafted by the majors during Spring training of his senior year, Chris played 12 seasons of professional ball as a pitcher for the Houston Astros, Kansas City Royales, St. Louis Cardinals, Detroit Tigers and the Pittsburgh Pirates. In 1964, Chris was the Texas League Pitcher of the Year. The first pitch of his rookie year with Houston (then the Colts 45) was to the legendary Willy Mays, followed by Willie McCovey and Orlanda Cepeda! In 1972, while pitching for the Detroit Tigers, Chris's team won the American League Eastern Division and went on to play the Oakland A's in the playoffs. That year, Chris had the lowest ERA on the pitching staff.

A native of Bradenton, Florida, Bill was an outstanding wingback on the 1955-57 U.T. football teams. He was a member of the 1956 SEC championship team, and was co-captain of the 1957 Vols team that defeated Texas A&M in the Gator Bowl. He played professional football for the Washington Redskins and the Green Bay Packers, and has the distinction of playing in Super Bowl I. Bill was the "color man" for radio broadcasts of U.T. football games for over twenty years.

Bill played for nationally ranked basketball teams at Knoxville High School from 1939-41. He was captain of the team in 1941, when the team captured the state championship and he was an All-State selection. He was a member of two teams that won their conference basketball championships; U.T. winning the SEC; and Duke, capturing the Southern Conference. Bill was a TSSAA football and basketball official twenty-five years, and has operated the clock at Neyland Stadium since 1967.

entry.category: Male High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description: A football star at Central High, he rushed for 1,803 yards and a single-season total of 2,456 all-purpose yards. Led the state in scoring with 39 touchdowns and averaged 9.1 yards per carry.

A multi-talented athlete, Milo first gained attention as a member of the legendary 1930 football team at Knoxville High School. He earned All-Southern honors as the fullback on a team that went through the season undefeated and untied. Their thirteen opponents scored a total of only twelve points during the entire season. He was also a TSSAA official for many years, and won over sixty bowling trophies, including the 1963 State Team Championship.

entry.category: Female High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description: Karns High School track star won four events in KIL track championships. Named female KIL Athlete of the Year in both her junior and senior years.

Oak Ridge Junior Men's tennis champion in 1945 and 1946, B.B. was a star athlete at Oak Ridge High from 1946-49, establishing a record by being the leading scorer on both the football and basketball teams, and the leading hitter on the baseball team. During an illustrious career at U.T., he was the first Vols baseball player to receive All-America honors. He was also the first Oak Ridge High School graduate inducted into the Oak Ridge Sports Hall of Fame.

A letterman in both football and basketball at Rule High School, Joel graduated in 1945. He worked as a TSSAA official for thirty-eight years, 1947 through 1985, helping found the Knoxville Football Officials Association and serving as president for five years. He worked playoff games every year, beginning with the first year playoffs were held, and also officiated for the South Atlantic Conference. He was named a supervisor of officials in 1986.

Stan led the Vols track team to thirty-one championships in fifteen years as the head coach. He coached 100 All-Americans. His U.T. teams won every SEC track championship held between 1981 and 1985, and were twice national champions. Stan has been named National Coach of the Year six times. During his thirty-four years as a head coach, his teams have won thirty-five league titles. He served as head coach for the 1988 U.S. Olympic Team for the games in Seoul.

Clarence could run with the football. In 1969, during his senior year at Austin East High School, he averaged 16.7 yards per carry. In one game, against a team from Evarts, Kentucky, he carried the ball three times for 155 yards and three touchdowns. A starter at tailback four years for Western Kentucky University, his teams won the Ohio Valley Conference championship in 1970, 1971 and 1972. He played pro football for the NY Jets ('73-'76) and the Browns ('77).

Tennessee Wesleyan grad lettered 3 years in football. East Tennessee Golden Gloves featherweight champ 1958-60. Officiated high school and college football, basketball games for 35 years. Pro boxing referee. Deputy Director Knoxville Parks and Recreation Department.

A multi-sports star, Ralph graduated from Knoxville High School in 1932 with letters in football, basketball, and track. He played on a fast pitch softball team that went to the national tournament, and was also a member of the YMCA volleyball team that twice played for the national championships in the 1930s. In addition, Ralph won two state cycling championships and participated in the national championships in the 1930s. He was a football and basketball official for many years.

Known for his tennis prowess and as a former Knoxville mayor, Kyle was a star on the 1951 state basketball championship team while attending Knoxville High School. At McCallie in Chattanooga, he was a starter on the football team, All Mid-South Most Valuable Player on the basketball team, and a star on the tennis team. He was an outstanding tennis competitor at U.T., and captained the team his senior year. He has won many tennis tournaments in both singles and doubles.

Vaughn won her first golf tournament at the age of eight, and continued throughout her life to play competitively and to promote golf throughout the Knoxville area and the state of Tennessee. She won women's club championships at Cherokee and Holston Hills during the 1930s, 1940s, and 1950s. In 1946, she was president of the Tennessee Women's Golf Association, and was runner-up for the state championship the next year.

Reggie was an outstanding defensive lineman during his career at the University of Tennessee, capturing All-America honors and other national recognition. He has continued his stellar play for the Philadelphia Eagles, where a perennial selection for the Pro Bowl.

entry.category: Female High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description: This Farragut High School scholar/athlete holds six school records in basketball and five school records in track and field. She was captain of both the track team and the basketball team in 1991-1992. Marvena was named All-KIL and All-District in basketball; and All-KIL, All-Regional, All-State and AAU All-American in track, while leading her school to the State Championship. Among her awards are several Most Valuable Fielder and Most Valuable Sprinter awards, as well as the United States Army National Scholar/Athlete Award. Marvena was also a Congressional Winner in the National Art Honor Society competition. She was named KIL Female Athlete of the Year.

This Farragut High graduate starred in football, basketball, and as a sprinter on the track team. He was an All-State selection in both football and basketball. A four-year starting safety for U.T.'s football Vols, Bates developed a reputation as the team's hardest hitter and surest tackler. Signed as a free agent rookie by the Dallas Cowboys in 1983, he immediately became known for his ferocious special teams play. His notoriety helped propel the NFL into adding a spot on the Pro Bowl teams for special teams coverage players. In 1984 he became the first player so honored. Bates received the Bob Lily Award for displaying leadership and character on and off the field in 1991 and 1992.

Sportswriters called him the South High Basketball Scoring Machine. He averaged 31.9 points a game in 1962, and 36.2 points per game in 1963. Both led the state. His 3, 134 career points was a state high school record at that time. Cole scored 50 or more points five times, including 66 against Karns. He also set the state high school high jump record in 1963 by clearing 6 feet 2 inches. He attended Martin and was named MVP in state junior colleges. He was Martin's first All-American. He graduated from Middle Tennessee State. As a coach, Cole's record was 50-9 at Battle Ground Academy, 45-10 at Martin, and 30-4 at Woodbury High, for an overall .820 winning percentage.

A middle distance runner, she was a standout representing U.T. from 1966 through graduate school in 1972. This three-time collegiate champion was a member of the World University Games Team, a member of the Pan American Team and was a finalist in the 1968 and 1972 Olympic Trials. Terry has an outstanding record as women's track coach, first at the University of Tennessee and then the University of Texas. She has been named national Coach of the Year 9 times, Southwest Conference Coach of the Year 12 times, and was head U.S. women's track coach for international meets, including the 1988 Olympics. Her teams have won 6 NCAA national and 20 conference championships.

A 1941 Knoxville High graduate, he was paired with a new doubles partner, Reese Patterson, in 1971. The team began adding their names to tennis record books immediately?first in the city, then the state and the South, and, finally in national competitions. Patterson and Ford have won numerous doubles titles, including the 1986 National Clay-Court championship (60 division). Following life-threating illnesses, they took to the courts again, winning the 1991 Southern Seniors Indoor Open (65 division), the National Clay-Court and Grass-Court championships. They lost only five doubles matches in the 21 years between 1971 and 1992.

entry.category: Male High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description: An All-American in two sports with a 3.94 GPA?that's Central High's Todd Helton. His football awards include All-District (4 years), District Offensive Player of the Year (2 years), All-KIL (3 years), KIL Player of the Year, All-East Tennessee (2 years), All-State (2 years), and All-American. He was Gatorade Player of the Year and judged one of the top 12 quarterbacks in the Southeast. His baseball honors are equally impressive: All-KIL (3 years), All-District (4 years), District Player of the Year (3 years), All-State, and All-American. Todd was selected one of USA Today's Top 25 High School Prospects, and Baseball America's Top 25. He received Central High's Academic Award 4 years.

A native of Maryville, he received his Bachelor's degree from Maryville College (1953) and a Master's degree from the University of Michigan (1954). His coaching career moved from high school to the college ranks, culminating with his service as athletic director for Vanderbilt University from 1978 to 1990. Kramer was named the sixth commissioner of the Southeastern Conference in January 1990. He has been a leader in intercollegiate athletics for many years, was instrumental in the SEC expansion movement, and has distinguished himself while serving on several important NCAA committees, including the selection committee for all 64 NCAA Basketball Tournament berths.

A native of Roane County, Tennessee, he graduated from Central High in Wartburg. He joined the Marines in 1950, and learned the Isshinryu style of Karate while stationed in Okinawa. Long began teaching martial arts when he returned to Knoxville after his discharge from the Marines in 1959, and has taught thousands of students over the years. One of the only two people in the world to hold the highest rank in Isshinryu?the 10th Degree Black Belt?his teams won the national Isshinryu championships 6 straight years (1986-1991). Long has authored six martial arts books and produced eight videos. His written and video Isshinryu training course is the first of its kind worldwide.

A graduate of Knox High, he lettered in football and basketball, and was captain of the football team in 1936, his senior year. He signed with U.T., lettering in football and basketball in 1938 and 1940. These were legendary football teams. The 1938 team went undefeated, won U.T.'s first SEC championship, and made Tennessee's first bowl appearance (a win over Oklahoma in the Orange Bowl). The 1939 team was undefeated, untied, unscored on, and SEC champ; and the 1940 team was also undefeated and SEC champions. Luttrell was also on the Vols' 1940-41 SEC basketball championship team. He had a distinguished career as an SEC football official from 1949 through 1966.

A 1941 Knoxville High graduate, he was paired with a new doubles partner, Reese Patterson, in 1971. The team began adding their names to tennis record books immediately?first in the city, then the state and the South, and, finally in national competitions. Patterson and Ford have won numerous doubles titles, including the 1986 National Clay-Court championship (60 division). Following life-threating illnesses, they took to the courts again, winning the 1991 Southern Seniors Indoor Open (65 division), the National Clay-Court and Grass-Court championships. They lost only five doubles matches in the 21 years between 1971 and 1992.

A great Central High scholar athlete, he was president of his senior class in 1961, and captain of the football and basketball teams. Football honors include All-State, All Southern and All-American. Died at age 24.

He first came to the attention of local sports figures when he led efforts to establish a football team at Powell High. With the aid of hand-me-down uniforms and equipment provided by Robert Neyland, the team was formed and Roberts was named it captain in 1929 and 1930. He was a popular and highly respected amateur baseball and softball player in the Knoxville area for many years, playing on a number of championship teams. In 1943, at the age of 32, he signed with the Knoxville "Smokies" and created headlines with his power at the plate and his skill as an infielder and outfielder. At age 45, he took up golf and shot an 89 in his first round. He has since won several area tournaments. He scored his sixth hole-in-one at the age of 78.

A native of Henrietta, Tennessee, her accomplishments have reached legendary proportions. She has more NCAA titles than any other women's coach (1987, 1989, and 1991). She has taken her Lady Vols to the Final Four 11 times. She has over 15 consecutive seasons with 20 or more wins, and is one of only a handful of coaches with over 400 victories. A co-captain on the 1976 Olympic team which captured the silver medal, Summitt coached the U.S. silver medal effort in the 1983 World Games, and guided the U.S. team to the gold in the 1984 Olympics. Twice a recipient of the Naismith Coach of the Year award, she was enshrined in the Women's Sports Foundation Hall of Fame.

One of the Knoxville area's premier golfers for four decades, this 1956 Fulton High graduate has won nearly 100 tournaments throughout the Southeast. As an amateur, he won the Knoxville Open in 1962, and has won the City Championship 4 times. In 1963, he won 9 straight amateur tournaments in a row. He won the Tri-States Amateur twice, the Cleveland Invitational twice, and the Southern Appalachian 3 times. Turning professional in 1964, he won the Metropolitan Open in Miami. Regaining his amateur status in 1974, Varner was twice runner-up in the State Senior Tournament and won the 1989 State Senior PGA tournament over a strong field of pros and amateurs.

A 1962 graduate of Austin High, he was a standout in three sports: football, baseball and track. But it was his football exploits as a quarterback that made the headlines. His senior year, Walters scored 22-touchdown running, and threw 11 touchdown passes. He received a scholarship to Indiana University, and was a starting running back as a freshman. Following graduation in 1966, he played pro ball in the Canadian Football League for two years, leading the league in punt returns. He began his college-coaching career in 1968 while attending graduate school at Indiana, and has built a solid reputation as an outstanding coach of defensive backs at several major universities.

A true newspaperman, his career with the News-Sentinel actually began as a carrier in Knoxville's Lincoln Park neighborhood. He began working as a copy boy in 1941 following his graduation from Knoxville High School. After a stint in the military, returned to the paper in 1946, joining the sports staff in 1948. For 20 years, he was assistant sports editor under the late Tom Siler, also a Knoxville Sports Hall of Fame member. He retired in 1985 after a 50-year association with the News-Sentinel. During a distinguished newspaper career, he received many honors from such organizations as the Knoxville Golf Association and the Greater Knoxville Tennis Association. Was one of the founders of the Fellowship of Christian Athletes in Knoxville, and later served as president of the organization.

Sports seem always to have been part of his life. First, he was a player. Then he was a teacher, a coach, and an athletic director. In each phase of his life, he achieved recognition for excellence. Born in Knoxville, he was an All State basketball and football player. After receiving a BA from Morris Brown College and an MA from Tennessee State, he was a teacher, coach, and athletic director at Holloway High School in Murfreesboro, and held similar positions at West Fulton and Therrel High Schools in Atlanta. As a player, his honors included All SIAC in football and basketball. He coached three championship teams as Holloway High and was in three championship playoffs at Therrel. He is in the Morris Brown College Hall of Fame for both.
Completed 38 marathons. Named Outstanding Track Official of the Year in 1987 by the Athletics Congress/USA. First President of Knoxville Track Club.

An All-America football star and an All-State basketball player, Michael Lynn Cofer graduated from Rule High School in Knoxville. At the University of Tennessee, Mike concentrated on football, earning All-SEC and honorable mention All-American honors his senior year. He entered the professional ranks in 1983 with the Detroit Lions. Mike made his debut as a defensive end, but was moved to linebacker in 1985. He found a home, and set a Lions record by leading the club in sacks four consecutive years. In 1988, his exceptional ability earned him a place on the NFC Pro Bowl Team. In 1990, he was named the Lions Defensive MVP and was named to the NFL All-Pro team. A knee injury kept him out most of the 1991 season, but he played hurt in 1992 and, despite his injuries, Mike Cofer had another strong showing.

This native of Norfolk, Virginia, Steve Delong was a two-time All SEC and All America selection at the University of Tennessee in 1963 and 1964. Considered one of the finest linemen in U.T. football history, he won the Outland Trophy as the nation's best lineman in 1964, and was named Most Valuable Player in the 1965 Senior Bowl. Steve was the number one draft choice of the San Diego Chargers, and one of three number one draft selections of the Chicago Bears (the other two were Dick Butkus and Gayle Sayers). He played seven seasons to the 35-year All-time SEC team selected by the Atlanta Journal, and was inducted into the College Football Hall of Fame in 1993. Steve and his son, Keith, are the only father and son All-America selections in U.T. sports history.

He was the first of four brothers to play at Holston High School, and set quite a pace for his siblings to chase. He let the KIL in scoring in 1966 with 772 points and was second in 1967. He was voted Most Valuable Player of the 1967 Tennessee State Tournament, and was named the state's Mr. Basketball. His high school career average was 24.9 points per game, with a single-game high of 44 points. His free throw percentage of 87.6 was a school record. At U.T., he was a three-year starter who averaged 19.4 points per game as a junior and 20.6 points per game as a senior, running the team from point guard. He holds the U.T. free throw percentage record hitting 88.1% of his charity tosses. In 1971, Jimmy was the nation's third best free throw shooter, hitting 143 of 165 for an 86.7% average.

A football and baseball star at Knoxville's Bearden High School from 1964 through 1967, Phil concentrated solely on baseball at the University of Tennessee, and established himself as an outstanding player. He lettered in baseball in 1968 through 1970, and was an All-Southeastern Conference selection in 1969 and 1970. A first-round draft choice of the Oakland A's in the 1971 draft, Phil played major league baseball for 16 seasons, mostly with the Houston Astros. He played on the Pittsburgh Pirates 1979 World Series Championship team. Turning his attention to managing, he took over the Milwaukee Brewers, leading them to a second-place finish in the American League's Eastern Division in 1992.

An outstanding basketball player at Gibbs High School, she was selected captain of the basketball team and was twice named to the All-Tournament team. She also played on summer league teams, winning the state championship, and going on to the Southern Tournament where she was selected to the All Southern Tournament team. At UT, Retha majored in Physical Education and, in graduate school, took a class in golf. Her love of golf has become a life-long pursuit of excellence, leading her to several Beaver Brook Country Club women's championships and medalist honors in other area tournaments. Retha was a PE instructor in area high schools for 27 years, and has coached several teams to regional and state tournaments. She received the Babe Zaharias Award from the Knox Area Golf Association.

One of the great athletes ever to attend Knoxville High School, Bill Hunt received seven letters in sports during his three years in high school. He was named to the All-Time, All Knoxville High School Team, having played end on the 1937 KHS National Championship football team. He was the center and captain of the basketball team, breaking the state scoring record in 1938 and being named to the All State team. He held three state track records while at Knoxville High School, and was named Outstanding City League Softball Player. Bill received a basketball scholarship to the University of Florida, where he stated at center and was team captain. He later transferred to U.T. on a track scholarship. He was a PE instructor at Tyson Junior High and was an assistant football coach for the Knoxville High School football team.

The first Tennessee School for the Deaf athlete to compete as a member of the World Games for the Deaf, Lavoy Killian is regarded one of the great athletes ever at TSD. He lettered in football, basketball, and track and field. He was named to the Knoxville News-Sentinel's second team All-City football squad in 1955. In 1956, he was named Deaf Prep All-America for his play at halfback. He was also named a Deaf Prep All-American track and field athlete for his speed in the 100-yard dash. At the World Games for the Deaf in Milan, Italy, he was on the USA's winning 4 by 100 meter relay team, finished fifth in the 100-meter dash, and was forced to withdraw from the diving competition due to injury. In 1992, he was the recipient of the Tennessee School for the Deaf Alumni Association hall of Fame Amateur Athlete Award.

A native of the Ritta community near Knoxville, he dug out a tennis court on Murphy farm, thus beginning a life-long of the game. At Central High School and the University of Tennessee, he continued to work on his game, and began teaching tennis some years later. He also earned Southern Singles ranking in 1978 and 1979, and national ranking in 1983. Jack was instrumental in the start of the Smoky Mountain Junior and Senior Tournaments in Blount County, and has been recognized for his work with seniors tennis programs. He has coached some nationally ranked players, and coached the Knoxville Women Seniors, who won State and South titles before playing in the Tucson Nationals in 1992.

Born in Shaw, Mississippi, she graduated from Shaw High School in 1944 with academic and athletic honors. Twice she won the doubles championship for her tennis team, and once was the singles champion. Martha was also an All-County and All-District player on championship basketball teams. Following her graduation from Mississippi University for Women in 1948, she began winning tournaments in earnest, compiling an outstanding record of victories in singles, doubles and mixed doubles through the '50s and '60s. She has had National Senior ranking for 15 years. Martha taught PE for 30 years, the last 10 years in the Knox County School System. Retired, she continued her tennis, and played on the Tennessee team in the STA Senior Cup Championship.

entry.category: Female High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description: A graduate of Central High School, she has garnered a host of honors and awards in recognition of her outstanding talents on the basketball court. She was named Ms. Basketball AAA in Tennessee, and was an All-State and AAU All-America selection. She was named an honorable mention All-America on the Kodak, Parade, and Street's and Smith teams. She is also Tennessee's 1993 Gatorade Player of the Year. In leading her team to a 22-9 record, Tanika scored 678 points her senior year, an average of 24.2 points per game. Her career statistics include: 2,456 point scored (21.9 per game), 1,152 rebounds (10.2 per game), 393 steals and 459 assists. She had an excellent 54% field goal percentage, and made 44% of her three-point attempts. Tanika was the first player from Knoxville to sign with the Lady Vols since 1984.

entry.category: Male High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description: Student/athlete graduated with honors from Halls High. A quarterback and punter, he was named All KFL, All District, All East TN and District 3AAA. Baseball record: batting average (.508), player of the year, most RBIs and most homeruns.

One of Tennessee's most widely known sports figures, he attended Knoxville High School and graduated from the University of Tennessee in 1935. A teacher in the Knoxville School System for 7 years prior to service in World War II, Sam became a PE teacher at UT after the war. In addition to teaching thousands of students, he was a long-time track official, official scorer at UT basketball games, and annual tournament director of TSSAA basketball. For many years he was a fixture on the "chain gang" at UT football games. Among his honors were: South Knoxville Citizen of the Year by the South Knoxville Civitan Club; and YMCA Man of the Year. He was a recipient of the Community Service Award by United Community Services, and was honored by the Tennessee Association of Physical Education and Recreation.

A part of Tennessee School for the Deaf for nearly 60 years, he enrolled as a student in 1920. He served as captain of the football team, and set a pole-vaulting record that stood for 50 years. At Gallaudet College, he was a halfback and punter, and captained the 1938 track team. After earning a Master's at UT, he returned to TSD, where he served for 40 years as Assistant Dean, football and basketball coach, athletic director, track and baseball coach, and teacher. He was named National Deaf Prep Football Coach of the Year in 1947 and 1948, and was inducted into the National Fraternal Society of the Deaf Hall of Fame in 1974. Retired in 1978, he was presented the Distinguished Service Award by the East Tennessee Chapter of the National Football Foundation and Hall of Fame in 1981.
Johnny Butler's Run. Vols vs. 'Bama 1939. With the ball on the 44, the UT tailback took the snap and began a serpentine route to the end zone, which covered more than 100 yards. Tenn. 21-0.

A native of Bluefield, West Virginia, he came to UT on a football scholarship in 1948. He was the starting center from 1949-1951 under Gen. Robert R. Neyland. Davis was known for his accurate snaps in the single-wing formation days when centering the ball meant shoveling it back five yards to the tailback or fullback. It was said he never made an errant snap, and that he carried out his blocking assignments with the same skill. During his 3 varsity seasons, UT's record was 28-4-1, capturing a national title in 1951. He returned to UT in 1966 as head freshman coach, and then moved to defensive end coach. Davis was the Vols' wrestling coach for five years. Served as Associate Athletics director for facilities.

entry.category: Female High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description: A multi-talented athlete, she was a four-year starter in volleyball, softball, and basketball at Karns High School. Voted the Most Athletic Female at Karns, Tracy was named to All-District teams in three sports and is the recipient of several Most Valuable Player awards. Her remarkable athletic prowess is matched by her academic abilities. Her high school grade point average of 3.75 ranked her near the top of her class. Tracy was also a certified Special Olympics Volleyball coach.

A star nose tackle at Knoxville's Austin High School, he became a defensive force for the University of Michigan. He earned letters from 1966-1968, and was a starter his last two seasons. He earned All Big Ten recognition after his final season. Goss' personal highlight was a career-high performance with 21 tackles in Michigan's 28-14 victory over Michigan State in 1968. He credits his days at the University of Michigan with laying the foundation and paving the way for a successful business career following graduation. In addition to his business interests, he has been active in a number of civic organizations, and served on a special Advisory Commission to the Big Ten Conference for 15 years.

A native of Powell, he graduated from Powell High School in 1948, and received his B.S. degree from UT in 1952. Following service during the Korean War, he served as physical director for the Knoxville YMCA, and coached swimming, basketball, volleyball, and other teams. It was there that he became interested in underwater diving, and, in 1965, was one of the first YMCA certified SCUBA diving instructors in the country.Soon recognized as an authority on underwater diving, Maples developed successful SCUBA leadership programs for instructors.
