He represents the SCUBA certifying agencies of the National Association of Underwater Instructors and the Professional Association of Diving Instructors.

For 32 years, he was a member of the UT Health, PhysEd and Recreation faculty, where he earned a reputation as a tough, fair taskmaster in physical fitness courses. Plotnicki exercised regularly, ending his workday with a game of handball, the sport that brought him national recognition. He brought several national tournaments to Knoxville. He was a founding member of the Knoxville Track Club, and served as a track official and starter for 28 years. Plotnicki, a native of South Bend, Indiana, graduated from George Washington, received his Masters from UT, and the doctor of education degree from Boston University. The UT handball courts were named in his honor following his death in 1980.

A native of Knoxville, he is considered one of the finest athletes ever to graduate from Catholic High School. In football, he led the city in scoring in 1967 and was named All-City, All-East Tennessee, and All-State. In basketball, he earned All-City, All-East Tennessee, and All-State honors. In baseball, he made the All-City team. He showed his track and field abilities by winning the state high school decathlon competition in 1967. Proctor attended Memphis State, were he lettered 4 years in basketball and was named to the All-Conference second team in 1970. He was also a long-jumper and a member of the 440-yard relay team. He was head coach at Shelby State Community College (90-42 record), then as assistant at Drake, Baylor, Ole Miss and the University of Missouri at Kansas City.

A native of Bogota, Columbia, Reveiz lettered in football, soccer, and wrestling at Sunset High School in Miami, Florida. He enjoyed a record-setting college career as a soccer-style kicker at the University of Tennessee, where he was a three-time All-SEC selection. Records he established in four hears at UT (1981-84) included: greatest percentage of field goals attempted; most field goals made; field goal percentage and extra point percentage. Reveiz began his pro football career with Miami in 1985, garnering the team's Rookie of the Year award and, later All-Pro honors. Following a brief stint with San Diego, he signed on with the Vikings, where he has continued his record-setting ways: fifth on the Vikings all-time scoring list (344 points); first in 50-yard field goals (6); and second in field goals made (73).

As junior golfer playing out of Central High in Knoxville, he won the City Tournament in 1945, and followed that with appearances at the National Juniors Tournament in 1946 (third place) in Columbus Ohio, and 1947 in Peoria, Illinois. He is the only three-time winner of the Southern Appalachian Tournament, with victories in 1946, 1949, and 1955. Seay became the golf professional at Whittles Springs Golf Course in 1955. He was head professional at the Cleveland Country Club before becoming the pro at Beaver Brook County Club in Knoxville. He continued in that post for 33 years, then was named Pro-Emeritus at Beaver Brook. Seay set course records at two golf courses. He had scored four holes-in-one and two double-eagles. His lowest round was a 61 (9 under par) at Beaver Brook.

entry.category: Male High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description: The South-Doyle Pioneer's record-setting quarterback has amassed a significant number of honors during his distinguished high school athletic career. He was selected All-Region Quarterback of the Year and All-District Player of the Year. He was chosen for the All-East Tennessee first team, and the All-State second team. Shawn set school career records by completing 265 passes in 445 attempts for 3,358 yards. He passed for 27 touchdowns and ran for 16 more. He also excelled in both basketball and baseball, making the All-District team in both sports in his junior and senior years. Shawn is an honor student who participates in Young Life and the Fellowship of Christian Athletes.

An all-around athlete, he first gained wide recognition for his abilities at East High School, where he starred in football, basketball, and baseball. At UT, he lettered in baseball three years. He is the only player to participate in every Smoky Mountain Classic Softball Tournament, and has played softball at the national level for 27 years. Stalcup played on 15 Tennessee State Championship teams, 8 Southern Region Championship teams, and competed in 14 ASA or USSSA national tournaments. Four times he was named an All-American in national tournaments. At the 1990 ASA Men's Masters National Tournament, he won the batting title with an average of .857 with 8 home runs. He coached Jr. Pro Basketball for 4 years, winning city and state championships, and taking two teams to the National Tournament.

He was Austin-East's first All-State football player in 1968, and followed that up with All-State baseball honors in 1969. Following graduation he attended Carson-Newman College, where the athletic honors kept rolling in: twice and All-American in football (1972 and 1973), and three times a baseball All-American (1972, 1973, and 1974, batting .454 that year). Torbush played professional baseball in the Kansas City Royals organization before becoming a college head coach in both football and baseball. He has been a defensive coordinator for Division I football teams for 10 years, joining the University of North Carolina staff in 1988. Under his direction, the Tar Heels' defense was nationally ranked (1991-1994). Torbush became the youngest person ever inducted into the Carson Newman College Hall of Fame in 1989.

Star of 1977 Austin-East State Basketball Champs. A 4-year starter at Ole Miss, set many records, twice named to All-SEC team. Drafted in 2nd round by Dallas, also played for the Denver Nuggets and Chicago Bulls.

A two-sport star at Knoxville's Bearden High School, she was a three-year starter on the basketball team and a standout on the track squad. She was selected to the All-KIL, All-District, and All-Region teams in both sports, and was twice chosen the Outstanding Athlete in the News-Sentinel Relays (1974 and 1976). Outstanding in both track and field events. Warlick established a record time in winning the 440 dash at the 1976 state meet. Originally attending UT on a track scholarship, she was a four-year player for the Lady Vols, and helped lead her team to Final Four appearances in three of her four years. She was twice named to All-America teams, and played on the U.S. National Team, which finished, 2nd in world competition in Bulgaria. Warlick is now an assistant coach for the Lady Vols.

A basketball standout at Oak Ridge High School, Jennifer entered Stanford University on a scholarship. While at Stanford, she received several collegiate honors including All-Pac Conference (1987-1990), Pac 10 MVP and Kodak All-American in 1989 and 1990. She led her team to an NCAA championship title at Thompson-Bowling Arena in 1990 and was the Most Valuable Player of the Final Four Tournament. Other awards she has received include the prestigious Naismith Trophy and the Wade Trophy; both awarded to her in 1990. She has played professional ball in Europe for five years. An alternate in the 1992 Olympics, she will represent the United States in Atlanta as a member of the 1996 women's basketball team.

entry.category: Female High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description: A multi-talented athlete, she was an outstanding performer in softball and basketball at Halls High School. She was voted The Most Athletic Female in her senior class. She has been named to numerous All-Tournament teams, and has also received several All-KIL, All-District and All-State Honors. On the softball diamond, Shannon posed a double offensive threat to the opposition. A big hitter, she had a batting average of 454. In 1993, she had 74 stolen bases, the next year 64, and her senior year 57. She was chosen as the KIL Player of the Year in softball in 1993 and 1995. Shannon will play softball for Cumberland College in Williamsburg, Kentucky.

As an outstanding basketball player at Gibbs High School in 1965, he played on one of the best teams in KIL history. He earned a scholarship to Carson Newman, where he started on the varsity team for four years and set a career scoring mark of 2,365 points. He presently holds the rebounding record for Carson Newman College and has been named to the Carson Newman College, "Team of the Century." Everette was drafted by Washington in the American Basketball Association. Also an excellent softball player, he has been on 12 Tennessee State Championship teams and was named as one of the top players in the country by the United States Softball Association.

He was captain of the last football team that ever played at Knoxville High School in 1950. Several years later as the athletic director and basketball coach at Fulton High, he began to amass his amazing record of wins, championship teams and list of who's who in All-American prep and college players. He coached Fulton to a 300-129 basketball record, was league champion or runner-up ten times, took four teams to district tournaments, five to regionals and made seven trips to the state tournament. He produced high school All-American's Billy Justus and Terry Russell and three college All-Americans, Justus and Ron Widby at UT and Roy Hill at Carson Newman. Thirteen of his players earned college scholarships in basketball.

Few college basketball programs have ever had a one-two punch like Grunfield and King. The Ernie and Bernie Show averaged over 50 points per game during a three-year period (1975-1977). As a team, Tennessee posted records of 18-8, 21-6 and 22-6 in those years. King was not only a scoring threat averaging 25.8 points per game, but also a great rebounder. He is UT's number two all-time leading rebounder, with 13.2 rebounds per game and a career total of 1004. He became an NBA all-star and led the NBA in scoring. Ernie Grunfeld was UT's all-time scoring leader with 2259 career points, until Allan Houston broke the record a few years ago. Grunfeld now is the General Manager of the New York Knicks.

One of the most exciting quarterbacks ever to play in the SEC, he dazzled Big Orange fans, and opposing fans alike, with his ability to escape tackles and make the big play. Known as the Artful Dodger, Holloway did it all in his career at UT. Just when you thought he was about to be downed by a tackle, he slipped away, more often than not getting away for a big gain. He made opposing defensive coaches work overtime devising ways to stop him. He finished with 966 yards rushing and 3102 passing for his career. He completed 238 passes in 407 attempts with 18 TD passes. Drafted by Canadian Football League, he played 13 seasons for three different teams. He was league MVP in 1982. He was inducted into the Tennessee Sports Hall of Fame in 1993.

Few college basketball programs have ever had a one-two punch like Grunfield and King. The "Ernie and Bernie Show" averaged over 50 points per game during a three-year period (1975-1977). As a team, Tennessee posted records of 18-8, 21-6 and 22-6 in those years. King was not only a scoring threat averaging 25.8 points per game, but also a great rebounder. He is UT's number two all-time leading rebounder, with 13.2 rebounds per game and a career total of 1004. He became an NBA all-star and led the NBA in scoring. Ernie Grunfeld was UT's all-time scoring leader with 2259 career points, until Allan Houston broke the record a few years ago. Grunfeld now is the General Manager of the New York Knicks.

entry.category: Male High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description: Quarterback at Powell High School. 1992 KIL Sophomore of the Year, 1994 KFL Offensive Player of Year. Four sport letterman.

A graduate of Knoxville High School, he lettered in both football and baseball. He began his officiating career in 1958, calling baseball, football and basketball games. For twelve years, he was a TSSAA basketball official. The 1995 football season marks his 38th year as a TSSAA football official. During this time he officiated two championship games and worked every play-off game but one. For 10 seasons he has acted as a football supervisor for the TSSAA in the Knoxville area. He serves on the boards of the Knoxville Quarterback Club and the East Tennessee Chapter of the National Football Foundation Hall of Fame. In 1980, he was the first recipient of the Ed Harris Memorial Award.
Leader in bowling in the U.S. and internationally. Served on the Board of directors of the Women's International Bowling Association and life member of the Tennessee Women's Bowling Association.
First African-American athlete to compete at Tennessee School for the Deaf. Twice competed in the World Deaf Olympics. In 1969, Deaf Prep All-America competing in track, basketball and football.

An all around athlete at Maryville College, he participated in football, baseball and track; then, wrestling caught his attention. He says, "The very first match I ever saw, I wrestled in it." He went on to wrestle three years at Maryville College. Stafford later started and coached two very successful wrestling programs, one at Sevier County High in 1963, the other at South-Young High School in 1988. He also coached football for twenty years, track eight years, basketball for one year and wrestling eleven years. Somehow, he also fit officiating into his busy schedule. He has officiated college wrestling since 1963 and serves on the TSSAA State Wrestling Committee. Stafford is the Athletic Director and Assistant Principal at South-Doyle High.

Born in Knoxville, his family moved to Morristown six years later where he completed his early education. While in high school, he was captain of the football and basketball teams, and was voted "most valuable" football player in 1932. He quarterbacked the football team for four years; he also played golf, tennis and ran hurdles on his high school track team.In 1934, Stephens received a football scholarship to Duke University where he was a blocking back and fullback for coach Wallace Wade. He was a four-year letterman in football, and he also played one year of basketball at Duke. Stephens majored in religious education with a minor in sociology. Upon graduation, he was recommended by his coach for his Boy's Club job as Executive Director of the Elizabeth City Boy's Club, North Carolina. In 1943, he moved to Knoxville to help start the Boy's Club of Knoxville.

A Knoxville native, he was one of the top tennis products to ever come out of this city. As a junior tennis player, he was ranked number one in the world, winning 21 national titles. He was a finalist at the French and Italian Junior Opens and a semifinalist at Wimbledon. At age 17, his first match at Wimbledon was on Centre Court with Billie Jean King in mixed doubles. They made it to the quarterfinals, losing to John Newcombe and Evonne Goolagong. In seven years on the tour, he played in each Grand Slam event and was ranked as high as 22 in the world, beating Boris Becker, Ivan Lendl, Gene Mayer and Pat Cash. In 1984, he qualified for the U.S. National Pro Indoor Tournament and was defeated in the semifinals against Jimmy Connors.

A prep All-American at Austin-East, he was rated the number one prospect in the nation. Recruited by Penn State, he immediately impacted the team receiving MVP honors as a freshman in the Citrus Bowl in 1987. Drafted by the Pittsburgh Steelers, he led the team in rushing in 1993. The New England Patriots, needing a running back, added him to their team roster in 1994. There he continued his record-setting ways. He was second on the team in rushing (343 yards); first in catches made by running backs (67); third on the team in touchdowns (8) and first on the team in kickoff returns averaging 20.5 yards per return.

A native of Loudonville, New York, he was the nation's number one prospect in swimming two decades ago. Swimming for UT, he was a member of nine NCAA championships while setting American records in the 50 freestyle, 200 freestyle and 400 freestyle relays. The Vols were 49-0 in dual meets during his career and won three SEC titles. He was the first in NCAA history to win five gold medals at one championship. In 1988, he returned to UT as coach of the swim program taking over the position left open by the retirement of his former coach Ray Bussard. Under Trembley's coaching the Vols have been consistently ranked in the nation's top 10 by the College Swim Coaches of America. He has won 90 percent of his meets and had five top 10 national finishes. He was named SEC's Men's Coach of the Year for the second consecutive season in 1995.

entry.category: Male High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description: Records were made to be broken and that is what Todd Atkins has done at Gibbs High School. Atkins holds virtually every football passing record at Gibbs High School. He is the all-time leader in passing and has set the record for single game passing yards, single game completions, single season record for passing yards and single season record for completions. He was also All-Region 1-AAA, Best Defensive Back and the Captain of the football team. In Track and Field, Atkins is the record holder in the Decathlon with 7,580 points. He holds the record for most points in a single meet with 58, and in 1994 was the 1A/AA Decathlon Runner-up.

Benita attended the University of Tennessee on a full athletic scholarship in track and field, receiving a Bachelor of Science degree in Industrial Engineering. In the 1984 Olympics in Los Angeles, she became only the second American, after Babe Didrickson, ever to win the gold medal in the 100-meter hurdles. Benita's competitive career spanned 15 years as a member of the 1980 and 1984 U.S. Olympic Teams and an alternate on the 1988 U.S. Olympic Team. Benita was a gold medalist in the 1983 Pan Am Games, and 8- time national champion, and a 15-time All-American. As a result of her accomplishments, she was named "Hurdler of the Decade" for the 80's by Track and Field News Benita has established a successful career off the track as well. In 1991, she began her career in Sports Marketing and Administration as a Regional Director for Special Olympics International. Beginning in 1993, she became the Program Director for a division of the Atlanta Committee for the Olympic Games, where she managed marketing programs with the 33 U.S. Olympic Sport National Governing Bodies and the Olympic sponsors in preparation for the 1966 Atlanta Olympic Games.In October of 1995, Benita was appointed as the Director of the U.S. Olympic Committee's new training center in San Diego, managing the state-of-the-art warm weather facility.Benita is a member of the Athletics Advisory of the United States Olympic Committee and President Elect of the Women's Sports Foundation.
Nicknamed "Tennessee" Gross, he lettered at Knox College. Played pro baseball and football and played on several pro and semi-pro basketball teams. Coached basketball for over 30 years.

Teammate of Hall of Fame speaker, Hank Lauricella, Haslam was the starting tackle on the Tennessee Football team in 1950, 1951 and 1952, and captain of the 1952 squad. Those years were marked with success with the 1950 and 1952 teams going to the Cotton Bowl and the 1951 team bringing the National Championship to the University of Tennessee. After college, Haslam was a commissioned offer in the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers and served active duty in Korea. Founder and Chairman of Pilot Corporation, Haslam now serves the community of Knoxville as a member of numerous civic organizations.
NFL official for more than 20 years. Officiated the 1985 Super Bowl. Graduated Central High School. Played tackle on the 1952 and 1953 U.T. football teams.

Kane represented the U.S. running the 1500 meters in the 1984 Olympics in Los Angeles. In 1983 she was ranked third in the nation in the 1500 meters, that same year winning several medals in various international competition. Kane was a member of the University of Tennessee Track Team from 1973 to 1977 and later came back to UT as an assistant coach in the women's track program. She was selected as SEC Cross Country Coach of the Year in 1992. Since the mid-80s, Kane has worked in the broadcasting field, providing color analysis for track and field and basketball. Currently, Kane is an anchor on WBIR's Live at Five and is the host of a fitness show on TNi.

entry.category: Female High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description: A star in track and basketball at Karns High School, in 1994 was the state champion in 200 and 400 meters. In basketball, scored more than 1,000 points.

Playing offensive guard for the University of Tennessee, Michels led the way up front for the hard-charging Tennessee teams of 1950, 1951 and 1952. Michels was an All-American in 1952, and two time All-SEC. He won the Jacobs Trophy as the SEC's best blocker in 1952. After college, Michels headed for the NFL. He played professionally for the Philadelphia Eagles and the Winnipeg Blue Bombers of the Canadian Football League. He spent the next twenty-seven years as an assistant coach with the Minnesota Vikings, coaching in four Super Bowls (1970, 1974, 1975, 1977) and eight divisional playoffs.

In 20 years of coaching high school football, 79 of his players received college scholarships. Record 156 wins, 44 losses, 4 ties. Won 4 championships in baseball with a record of 173 wins and 42 losses in 9 years.

Reynolds was an all-around athlete in high school but it wasn't until college that she focused solely on tennis. Playing for SMU her freshman year, she transferred to the University of Tennessee Chattanooga as a sophomore. In January 1977, Reynolds turned professional on the Women's Tennis Tour and began what would become a career in professional tennis spanning ten years. She has won 28 professional tennis titles, and won titles in 8 different countries. In 1983, Reynolds won the French Open Grand Slam Doubles Titles and that same year with her doubles partner Rosalyn Fairbanks, placed second to Martin Navratilova and Pam Shriver in the U.S. Open. Her highest ranking was #22 in the world in singles and #2 in doubles. In 1988, Reynolds won the Player Service Award at the WITA Annual Awards Banquet.

Royal picked up a racquet at the age of 9 and almost immediately began playing competitive tennis. During the next four decades, he would win several tournaments and championships titles. As a youngster, he was ranked 2nd in the 15 and under category in the South. He won the City Championship three years in a row (1958-1960). He was a three-time winner of the State Championship and won the Southern Championship in 1979. Playing for the University of Tennessee, Royal occupied the number one position on the tennis team for three years. Even a stint in the army didn't stop him from playing. As a soldier stationed in Europe, Royal won the U.S. Army Europe Championship in 1956. He later went on to coach at UT, winning two SEC titles and coaching two All-Americans. Royal was the first tennis pro at Knoxville Racquet Club and later became the pro at Cherokee Country Club.

Bernard Taylor is distinguished as one of the most celebrated boxers in the history of amateur boxing. He holds the second highest record of National Golden Gloves and National AAU titles. In 1976 he won his first Golden Glove Championship boxing in the bantamweight division and later won three Championships as a featherweight. Taylor turned pro in 1980 and held the North American Boxing Federation Champion title from 1985 to 1988. He was the USBA Featherweight Champion from 1990 until 1994. He officially retired in February 1994 with a professional record of 44 wins (19 knockout), 3 losses, and 1 draw.

Wade always knew what he wanted to do when he grew up. He was only 2 years old, barely big enough to hold a fishing pole, when he first began fishing. By the time he was 18, Wade won his first bass boat in the fishing tournament. In 1976 at the age of 19, he was the youngest person ever to win a professional tournament. For the next four years he competed in over 100 national tournaments from Texas to Virginia, winning seven national tournaments. He holds 10 national titles and has regularly placed within the top 50 in Bass Anglers Sportsman Society finishes. In 1989 he set an all-time record for a three-day tournament in Tennessee, catching 24 bass weighing in at 75 pounds total weight.

Reggie was an outstanding defensive lineman during his career at the University of Tennessee, capturing All-American honors and other national recognition. He continued his stellar play with Philadelphia Eagles, where he was a perennial selection for the Pro-Bowl. Now, a defensive end with the Green Bay Packers, White is still at the very top of his game after 11 years, documented by his selection in 1995 to the Pro Bowl for the 10th consecutive year. In 1994 he was elected to the NFL's 75th Anniversary All-Time Team. White leads the league in quarterback sacks recording an even dozen in 1995 to swell his career total to 157.

A multi-sport athlete at Austin High School, Wynn excelled in basketball leading the Panthers to championships in the district and regional basketball tournaments. Wynn played in the first integrated game in the city of Knoxville between South High and Austin High, leading the Panthers that year to an 8-6 record. His team played in the regional tournament where he was named MVP. After high school, Wynn accepted a scholarship to the University of Cincinnati where he played three years of varsity, lettering every year. While at the University of Cincinnati, Wynn became know for his tremendous desire to win, and his hustle and determination on the court.
Began bowling at 12 and joined the adult leagues at 17. Played in 28 national American Bowling Congress Tournaments.

With 143 games, Conklin played in more games in her career than any other Lady Vol. She helped win two straight NCAA titles and played in the national championships three times. Conklin ranks in the top 10 of the Lady Vols career lists in five different categories and holds the record for three-point goals (six) and attempts (11). She earned academic All-Southeastern Conference honors her final three years at Tennessee and was selected to the All-SEC second team her senior season. Conklin graduated with a degree in therapeutic recreation in May and was drafted in the third round by the Atlanta Glory.

As a 14 year-old Halls High School student, Davis was offered a professional baseball contract, a football scholarship and a contract with the Harlem Globetrotters. His multi-sport prowess continued at Alcoa High School, where he was a star running back. His string of honors include All Blount County, All Chilhowee Conference, All East Tennessee, All Southern, All American, Prep All American, Tennessee All State, Parade All American and Alcoa High School Player of the Century. At Tennessee State University he starred in baseball and was an All-American football player. After graduating from TSU, he was drafted by the Philadelphia Eagles and was Eagles rookie of the year in 1971. He went on to play for the New England Patriots and the New York Giants.

Named the nation's "Best Defender" by College Sports magazine after her senior year, Davis also earned the title of most outstanding player of the East Regional Tournament and All-SEC second-team honors. She improved her points and rebounds average each year and ranks in the top 20 in four statistical categories. She earned the team's Unsung Hero award in 1995 after helping UT advance to the national championship game. Davis graduated with a degree in community health education in December and was drafted in the fourth round by the ABL defending champion, Columbus Quest.

Over a span of 33 years, Dickey has been a principal force on the UT sports scene, first as a coach by winning two Southeastern Conference football championships and later as director of the highly successful Vol athletic department. As head coach, he brought Tennessee back into national prominence with a 46-15-4 record over his six years. His teams appeared in five bowl games and he had 15 All-American selections and 23 All-SEC selections during his tenure. Ten of his players were named Academic All-SEC and two were Academic All-America. As UT's fourth athletic director he has overseen a program of facilities construction and renovation. A landmark development was the expansion of Neyland Stadium to a capacity of 102,544.

A founder of the Knoxville Track Club in 1962, Durham coached the first men and women's team to win five Southeastern AAU championships. He coached Terry Hull Crawford who became a world-class printer, the first women's track coach at UT and ten a coach for the US Olympic team. Durham organized the first summer track and field program for children at the Tom Black Track and served as a track and field official for more than 40 years, officiating at high school, college and AAU level, including two NCAA championships, SEC championships and the Junior Olympics. He also founded the annual Volunteer Track Class and directed it for 28 years. The VTC is regarded as on of the top interscholastic meets in the U.S.
Played for Booker and Davidson in the Softball World Series in Chicago in the 1930's. A member of the Knoxville Officials Association from 1933-1950.

Hawkins is being honored for his achievements in basketball, although he earned a reputation as an all-around athlete at Austin High School and later at Florida A&M University. In 1941 he was ranked 9th nationally as a junior tennis player by the American Tennis Association and was later named to the All-State basketball team. At FAMU he was a member of the tennis conference championship doubles team and runner-up in the singles championship. His basketball team won the S.I.A.C. Conference championship in 1945 and 1947 and he was selected to the All-Conference 1st team in 1947.

entry.category: Male High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description: Huskey starred in football, baseball and basketball at Webb School before signing to play baseball at UT. As a high school baseball player he was awarded a string of All-District honors from his freshman to his senior year. For his efforts on the football field he as earned Class 2A, All-State honors, All-East Tennessee Class 2A Player of the Year and was selected to the Tennessee Kentucky All-Star Football Team. In basketball, Huskey has played in state and regional tournaments and earned an All-District Class 2A honorable mention.

entry.category: Female High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description: Named one of Soccer America's Super 11 recruits in Southeast USA, Lauter turned down numerous colleges to accept a scholarship from UT. While at Farragut High School she set a state record for scoring the most goals in a season and was named Soccer World's East Tennessee Player of the Year and Near Post Player of the Year. She has played on the Olympic Development Tennessee team and Region 3 Regional Team. Lauter has collected a string of titles including All District, All Region, All KIL, All State and All South.

Finishing her UT career in grand style, Marciniak was named the most outstanding player of the 1996 Final Four. The Boost/Naismith Award finalist entertained crowds with her flashy, all-out style of play during her three seasons at UT after transferring from Notre Dame. She was a two time academic All-SEC honoree and was named to the 1996 East Regional and 1995 Mideast Regional teams. Ranked in the top 20 in seven Lady Vol career statistical categories, Marciniak graduated with a degree in psychology in December of her final season and began working on a master's degree. She was recently assigned by the ABL to the Long Beach expansion team.
All-around sportsman who lettered in football and baseball. Officiated football for 40 years and played state level softball and badminton.

After establishing a reputation as the best defensive end in the Southeastern conference, he earned All-American and All-SEC honors in 1966 as a linebacker with UT. Teammates honored his leadership ability by naming him a co-captain of the 1966 Tennessee team. The following year the Detroit Lions, where he stayed for 12 seasons and played 168 games, drafted him. He missed only two games during his entire pro career and at one time played in 142 consecutive games. He played in the Pro Bowl and in 1970 competed in the NFL playoffs. Naumoff retired from football in 1979 and now works at UT.

A former State Seniors Champion, Pike has been a leader in women's golf in Tennessee, serving as secretary of the Women's Tennessee Golf Association and working with area women and junior organizations. She didn't pick up a golf club until her mid-thirties but went on to play in 22 state, 17 state senior and three southern senior tournaments. She was awarded the Ed Harris Sportsmanship Award by the Knox Area Women's Golf Association, the Knox Area Interclub and the Ladies 18 Hole Golf Association at Beaver Brook Country Club.

A graduate of Fulton High School, ETSU and UT, Ray became Tennessee's first Women's Athletic Director in 1977. She is credited with developing the Lady Vol program into one of the strongest in the nation. During her eight years of leadership, the program grew in funding from $126,000 to $1,200,000. All the teams were ranked in the top 20 and the women's program won its first national championship. As President/CEO of the Knoxville Sports Corporation, Ray has hosted events that have generated more than $83,000,000 for the local economy and attracted extensive national coverage in the broadcast and print media. Events staged in Knoxville have included the USA Track and Field Championships, an NFL game, the AAU Junior Olympic Games, PGA Golf Show and the USA National Gymnastics Championships.

Thompson ended her Lady Vol career perfectly, shooting 4-4 from the field to help the Lady Vols win their second straight NCAA championship. She earned Midwest Regional All-Tournament team honors along the way and ranks in the top 20 in six Lady Vol career lists. Thompson began her career by playing in all 33 games, starting three and earning a spot on the SEC All-Freshman team. She received the team's Unsung Hero award as a senior and the sixth-player award as a freshman and junior. Scheduled to graduate with a degree in human services this month, Thompson was recently drafted in the sixth round by the Seattle Reign.

This Knoxville native starred in baseball at Central High and later at UT, where he was named All-SEC in 1993 and 1994 and All-American in 1994. Recently named Detroit Tigers' Minor League Player of the Year, Trammell split the season between AA Jacksonville and AAA Toledo, hitting 33 home runs and driving in 99 runs. As impressive as his power numbers was his .312 batting average. His outstanding 1996 season helped him land a spot on the Detroit Tigers' opening day roster this spring. He has been named the Tigers' eighth-best prospect and chosen to the overall Double A All-Star Team by Baseball America.

"Give him six". Known as the legendary "Voice of the Vols," Ward has done radio play-by-play for Vol basketball since the 1965 season and football since 1968. With analyst Bill Anderson, he hosts the ever-popular Kick-off Call-in Show on the Vol network and he has also hosted Vol coaches on television shows broadcast throughout the country. Named Best Collegiate Announcer in 1976 by Nationwide Publications of Los Angeles, he has been a consistent winner of the Best Sportscaster in Tennessee award and was the first president of the Tennessee Broadcasters' Association. Incidentally, he has also earned a place in Knoxville's list of 10 Best Dressed Men three times.
Captain of the U.T.'s 1969 SEC champion football team that had a 9-1 regular season record. He made 18 career interceptions including bowl games.

He is the only coach in Tennessee history who has won state championships in the same school year in three sports. That year was 1987 when he coached Austin-East to titles in Class AA Football, Girls Track and Boys Track. Believe it or not, the state boys high school track championship came down to a coin flip. Austin-East and Brentwood Academy had finished the track meet tied with 64 points each. The officials tossed a coin and the Austin-East Roadrunners became the state champions. During his ten year coaching career, Anderson coached 56 athletes that received athletic scholarships and six athletes that went on to play in the NFL.

He began his baseball career playing little league ball in 1949 in Chilhowee Park. Many years later Bales went on to play professionally for the Chicago Cubs. After his pro career, he turned to coaching and in 1974 began his now 25 year coaching stint at Central High School. At Central, his teams have won 11 district championships, seven regional titles and one state crown. In 1990, he coached Central High School to a 31-0 season. He has received the TSSAA District Coach of the Year 12 times and was inducted into the East Tennessee Baseball Coaches Hall of Fame in 1997.

While serving as Women's Athletics Director at the College of Charleston, the women's athlete program was selected as the number one program in the country. Now fourteen years with the University of Tennessee, she continues to be a leader and voice for women's collegiate athletics. She has overseen the growth and strength of the University's programs realizing unparalleled success. In 1987, she was awarded the Women's Basketball Coaches Association Leadership Award and in 1995, the National Association of Collegiate Women's Athletic Administrators Regional Award. She has been appointed to the prestigious 14-member NCAA executive committee and has served on several other NCAA and SEC committees and councils. As avid tennis player, she is a former State and Southern doubles champion.

A Bearden High School graduate, DiFelice set the single season record for home runs and RBIs as a senior. Continuing his batting proficiency at the University of Tennessee, he lead the Vols in home runs, doubles, hitting and slugging percentages while standing second in RBIs. In 1990 he won SEC player of the week honors and Second Team All-SEC honors as a catcher. Turning pro in 1991, DiFelice was drafted in the eleventh round by the St. Louis Cardinals and played six years in their minor league. In 1996, he debuted in the majors with the Cardinals. Following the 1997 season, he was the tenth pick of Tampa Bay Devil Rays in the first round of the expansion draft.
Considered the coaching genius behind the U.T. VOLS defense that beat Miami in the 1986 Sugar Bowl. Also coached Alabama leading the nation 3 times in scoring defense.

He is perhaps the most legendary assistant coach in the history of college football. Thirty-eight years in the profession molded him into a coaching giant. Donahue played tackle for General Bob Neyland and was a member of the 1950 team that went 11-1 and defeated Texas in the Cotton Bowl. After college, he coached at Memphis State, Mississippi State, Alabama and Tennessee. Donahue is considered the coaching genius behind the Vols defense that beat Miami in the 1986 Sugar Bowl. When he wasn't working with Tennessee he was coaching against them beating the Vols 11 times in a row. He coached teams that won five national championships, (four while at Alabama), 14 conference championships and 26 bowl games.

As the longest serving member of the University of Tennessee Athletic Department, Manning has served the Athletic Department for 48 years. Manning began in 1950 as the Sports Information Director serving for 10 years in that capacity. In 1960, he was named Administrative Assistant to General Bob Neyland. Manning now serves as the Executive Assistant to the Athletic Director after previously filling the role of Administrative Assistant, Assistant Athletic Director, Associate Athletic Director and Senior Associate Director. In 1989, he was named Business Manager of the Year by the College Business Managers Association. Manning also serves as a director of the Tennessee Sports hall of Fame and on several Southeastern Conference Committees.
Knoxville News-Sentinel sports writer since 1957. He has covered many sports, but is most noted for reporting on U.T. swimming for which he was inducted into the Swimming Hall of Fame in 1985.

A Knoxville native, she was one of the top women athletes in the state. She captained the Knoxville High School girl's basketball team in 1926 and again in 1927, and was the team's leading scorer for the second year. She later played on the top independent women's basketball team in the area and gained All-Star honors playing softball. For over 35 years she taught school at Christenberry Junior High and Whittle Springs Junior High. While at Christenberry, she coached both the boys and girls basketball teams. Teaming with her husband, G.R. Lebow, they managed the Whittle Springs swimming pool for many years.

entry.category: Male High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description: Multi-sport athlete at Austin-East High School excelling in football, track, baseball and basketball. Received National Football Foundation and Hall of Fame Scholar-Athlete Award.

A Senior tennis standout, she is currently ranked 27th in the nation and sixth in the Southern States in the 60 singles division. In Women's 55 singles she is ranked number one in the state of Tennessee. Martin holds several state singles, doubles and mixed doubles titles. She has participated in U.S. National Tournaments and National Senior Women's Grass, Indoor and Clay Championships. Twice she has been named the Outstanding Athlete of the Year (1995 and 1996) and was the Gold Medalist at the 1993 Senior Olympics.

He began his coaching career at South High School in 1956 where he coached football, basketball, track and cross-country for 13 years. In 1962, he organized cross-country at the high school level and started the first Summer Track Program in Knoxville. That year he also was one of the original founders of the Knoxville Track Club. Neff officiated numerous tract and field events including 624 track meets at local, regional, state and national levels. He was voted Number One Track Official in Tennessee in 1996 by the USTAF of Tennessee. The Robert I. Neff Service Award is named in his honor and gives annually to the outstanding track official by the Knoxville Track Club.

From Pensacola High School where he excelled in three sports, he came to the University of Tennessee to play baseball and football. Payne scored fifteen touchdowns and contributed heavily to the National Championship in 1951. He was a member of the first SEC baseball team to reach the College World Series and was Second Team All-American at second base. After college, he was drafted by the Pittsburgh Steelers and the Washington Senators baseball team. Later he settled back in the Knoxville area coaching at Farragut High School, where he was instrumental in developing one of the most outstanding baseball programs in the country. His last year at Farragut he was named KIL Coach of the Year.

All-time leading scorer (3,550 points) at Porter High School in Maryville. She was a 7 time All American in AAU basketball and played on the 1963 U.S. All Star team that won the Pan Am Games gold medal.

entry.category: Female High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description: An outstanding soccer player and student at Bearden High School, she received District Team and Regional Team honors all four year of high school. Stroud graduated with a 3.6 GPA. For her soccer prowess, she was twice name Best Eleven and All East Tennessee and three times All KIL. In 1997, she was on the All-State Tournament Team, was voted East Tennessee Player of the Year and All KIL Player of the Year. She is the all time scoring leader at Bearden. Sarah will play soccer for Auburn University.

John Tate moved to Knoxville in May 1975 to work with Ace Miller, director of the Golden Gloves boxing program. Four years later, Tate reached the finals of the Golden Gloves. In the 1976 Olympics in Montreal, he brought home the bronze medal. Turning pro in 1977, he battled through 20 opponents to win the WBA Championship. On March 31, 1980 in Stockley Athletic Center, "Big" John Tate fought to defend his WBA Crown, losing in the final round to Mike Weaver. The memory of his rise to WBA Champion lives on in the hearts and minds of Knoxvillians and the boxing world.

They began their broadcast career together with the Vol Network in 1968 and for 31 years they contributed to the memories made on the football field, including the 13-0 national championship season. Ward had called basketball for the Vols as well and he was the Tennessee Sportscaster of the Year 28 times. Other honors included the Lindsey Nelson Award given by the Knoxville Quarterback Club and the "Distinguished American" award bestowed by the East Tennessee Chapter of the National Football Foundation and Hall of Fame. Anderson was co-captain of the 1957 Vol football team and played professionally with the Washington Redskins and with the Greenbay Packers in Superbowl I. He was also an assistant coach at UT. Together, John Ward and Bill Anderson were the longest running broadcast team in Division I.

entry.category: Female High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description: As a cross-country and track and field runner at West High School, Christy was a KIL Champion in both events. She was a cross country Region II Champion for four years and a state champion for three years. She holds the State cross-country record of 17:26 for three miles and was named KIL Track Athlete of the Year in 1997. She set a record on the state level in the 3200M at the "Vol Track Classic" and was named Gatorade Circle of Champions State Track Athlete of the Year in 1997 and 1998. In 1997, she was runner up in the 1500M at the AAU Track Nationals. Christy has signed with the University of Tennessee.

He is known simply as "Coach" to the students at Fulton High School where he has been Athletic Director since 1976. He has also served as an assistant coach in both football and baseball. Black is an SEC and ACC baseball umpire and has umpired fourteen SEC tournaments in his career. He is also the District Coordinator and Umpire Training Coordinator for the TSSAA and has umpired numerous TSSAA state championship baseball tournaments. Black has served as the National Director of the Jr. Pro Basketball Association since 1982 and worked with the late Bobby Lippert to run the Jr. Pro National Tour held in Knoxville. He has been a member of the UT "Chain Crew" on the east side of Neyland Stadium for over 31 years.

Don played basketball at Rule High School and was awarded a basketball scholarship to Mississippi State College. A broken ankle hindered his college career, but his career as an all sports referee included time as a professional baseball umpire. He was also a well known basketball and football official for area college and high school games. Don was involved in the summer baseball program for the City of Knoxville Recreation Bureau. And, while he was an elementary school principal in the Knoxville City School System, he worked part time as Director of Concessions for the UT Athletic Department in an effort to remain closely involved in sports.

Howard began playing tennis in 1975 at the age of 46. In the twenty-two years since, hardly a day has passed when he has not spent time on the court. In tennis, he has won over 100 senior-age division tournament titles and has been ranked at the state and southern levels since age 55 at the national level in the 60 senior age divisions. He was also a former minor league baseball player and one of the first members of the Professional Bowlers Association. Howard founded the UT Tennis Boosters Club, has served two terms as president of the Greater Knoxville Tennis Association, and is a community philanthropist. In January, he was inducted into the TN Tennis Association Hall of Fame. Howard is now the owner and director of the Cedar Bluff Racquet Club.

Eddie was a member of the UT Vols football team from 1971-1973 and played in three bowl games. He led the team in punt returns 1972 and 1973, and his 42 returns for 429 yards in 1972 is the third best mark in Vol history. Eddied was an eighth round draft choice of the Cleveland Browns in 1974 and played through 1975. He continued to play in the NFL with Washington and the Los Angeles Rams, and he played in the USFL as well. Eddie was an early John Madden Team selection.

Charlie was a Tennessee football captain before he began coaching in 1957. As a student at UT, he was an education major and received the Roy N. Lotspeich award as the top scholar-athlete on the team in 1955. He graduated from UT in 1956 and was a member of Doug Dickey's staff in the early 1960s. He went to Arkansas as defensive coordinator in 1965 and became head coach at Virginia Tech in 1971. After 17 years of coaching, he capped his career by serving as president and CEO of a trucking company he founded 1980.
Began swimming for the Knoxville Swimming Association at age 8 and was ranked in the top 25 nationally in the 1970's. She set record times in competitions including the Junior Olympics.

A former Austin High School graduate, Walter played football, basketball, and tennis in college at Johnson C. Smith University in Charlotte, North Carolina. He was a member of the tennis team for four years, during which time his team won the CIAA Championship. While in Charlotte, he won both the City Championship and the North Carolina State Championship, and he later won the Knoxville City Championship and the Georgia State Open Championship. After serving in the Army during WWII, Walter earned his medical degree and practiced medicine in Knoxville.

Haywood was named Sports Information Director at UT in 1961 by General Robert R. Neyland, and he has continued to work in the Vol Publicity Office in a variety of positions. He was named to the College Sports Information Directors of America Hall of Fame in 1984 and received the organization's top honor, the Arch Ward Award in 1992. Inside Sports Magazine name Haywood one of the nation's Top 5 SIDs. He and former inductee Gus Manning co-host the nation's longest running radio sport program The Locker Room on Vol game days.

A 1992 Central High School graduate, Helton earned All America honors in both baseball and football. He continued to play both sports at the University of Tennessee and distinguished himself as a baseball player by earning All America honors each of the three years he played. Todd set nineteen school records in baseball while at UT and let the Vols to the 1995 College World Series. Helton was a first round draft choice by the Colorado Rockies in the 1995 Baseball Amateur Draft, and after playing for two years in the minor leagues, he has had one of the finest rookie sessions in recent memory. Only three players have hit more homers as a National League Rookie and only one had more RBIs.

Attended Knoxville College where he was a four-year starter as a basketball guard and football quarterback and co-captain of his team. He continued to play football while in the army and later became a director of the YMCA.

Bobby attended West High School and lettered in baseball and received a scholarship to Carson Newman College. Served as Athletic Superintendent for the City of Knoxville for over ten years and supervised one of the largest youth football leagues in the region. His commitment to youth is sports included officiating youth football and working with Junior Pro Basketball as Assistant National Director. He was a TSSAA assigning officer for high school baseball, basketball, and football in East Tennessee. He was also a high school football official and umpire. Bobby was recognized by TSSAA with the Distinguished Official award in 1997 and was presented with the Contribution to Amateur Football Award by the East Tennessee Chapter of the National Football Foundation and Hall of Fame in 1998. He was a member of the UT Chain Crew for over 20 years.

As a walk on basketball player for U.T., he still holds the SEC single game rebounding record of 36, which was set in 1952. He also ran track and set records in high jumping. He was a U.T. Electrical Engineering professor.

entry.category: Male High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description: He played baseball, basketball, and football at Halls High School. He was selected as an All-KIL and an All-Region team member.

Todd is arguably the best distance runner in America. Recruited by Tennessee, he helped seal a national Track and Field title with outstanding performances in the 10,000 M and 500 M in 1991. Since college, he has won five national titles and competed in three World and Olympic finals in the 10,000 M. He placed tenth in the Barcelona Olympics and seventh in the World Championships in the 10,000 M. He later broke the American record for the 15K running 42:22. Williams is still training in the 10,000 and plans to race marathons in the future.

Bert Ackermann was the University of Tennessee's single-wing center in 1963 and holds the distinction of being the last single-wing center at a major college. The next year, he was UT's first center to use Doug Dickey's new T formation. He is the chief executive officer of Spinlab Utility Instrumentation, Inc., and CONINCO, Inc., both located in Knoxville. He earned his bachelor's, master's and doctorate degrees in nuclear engineering at UT. He has continued his football career as an official and currently serves as SEC head linesman.

A native Knoxvillian, this former executive sports editor of the Knoxville Journal had a long-time career in sports journalism, which included the publication of two books on UT football?The Big Orange and Vols. After 38 years in journalism, Russ Bebb retired in 1991. He has been a member of the Vol Football Network crew since 1958 and has been the official scorer for UT basketball games for the last 28 years. In 1982, he was recognized as the Tennessee sportswriter of the year, and he was named an honorary letterman by UT's Letterman's T Club in 1999.

Coached Austin-East to two high school championships in basketball during the 1980's. He joined Austin-East as assistant coach in 1971 and became head coach in 1981. He graduated from East High School, where he lettered in basketball and track.

In 1990, The Jim Thorpe All-Around Award recognized Willie Gault as the greatest athlete in the world. He gained early recognition as a freshman University of Tennessee wide receiver. Achieved the rare distinction of being named All-American in both football and track. In 1980, he was a part of the U.S. Olympic Track Team for the 100 and 200-meter sprint events, and he won a gold medal in the 4 x 100-meter relay at the 1983 World Championships in Helsinki, Finland. He was also a member of the 1988 Winter Olympic Team on the four-man bobsled team. He was a integral part of the Chicago Bears' Shuffling Crew, a dream team that won Super Bowl XX in 1985. He set a Super Bowl receiving record, and was also co-creator and producer of the Super Bowl Shuffle, raising more than a quarter million dollars for Chicago's neediest families. He is an entrepreneur, an effective communicator, an actor, dancer and producer, as well as television sports commentator. He has appeared in numerous feature films, TV shows and commercials.

World-class hurdler, four-time All-American while at the University of Tennessee. He won the U.S. Track and Field Federal national championship in the 120-yard high hurdles. He later became a physician with a Knoxville practice.

An All-American tennis player at Tulane, where he won 33 of 34 singles matches. He has been ranked in the top 20 in U.S. professional men's singles and in the top five in U.S. doubles. He also coaches and excels in distance running and bicycling.

A three-sports star at Bearden High School in the late 1970's, All-KIL in volleyball, basketball and track. She broke the state record in the discus, and was the U.S. Military Academy's Division III national champion in the heptathlon.

One of the biggest names in University of Tennessee history, John Majors was a standout player and coach. A single-win tailback, he finished second in Heisman Trophy balloting in 1956 and was later named to the 25-year All-SEC team (1950-1974). He coached the University of Pittsburgh to an unbeaten season and national championship in 1976. He won 185 games as a coach at Iowa State, UT and two stints at Pittsburgh. After 29 years as head coach, his career ranked tenth among collegiate coaches having coached 322 games. A two-time national coach of the year, he is special assistant to the athletic director and chancellor at the University of Pittsburgh.

A three-time All-American at Carson-Newman College, Carol Zachary Mitchell was a star pitcher and hitter. As a pitcher, she won 123 games with a career earned run average of 1.14. As a hitter, she had a career batting average of .497. At Gibbs High School, she was able to play five years because she joined the team as an eighth grader. In 1986, she pitched two perfect games, batted .658 and was named the KIL athlete of the year. She also played varsity basketball for four years. She recently was named KIL softball coach of the year after leading her Gibbs team to a third consecutive state championship. She is also active in coaching summer league softball and has led her team to win three ASA state championships.

In his tenth year as the Smokies' vice-president, Dan Rajkowski has worked in professional baseball for 18 years. He was named the Southern League's executive of the year in 1997, and his Smokies team received the award for excellence in 1996 for having the highest attendance increase in the league and the league's community relation's award. He got his start in baseball with Auburn Astros of the New York Pennsylvania League. In his second full year of professional baseball in Florence, South Carolina, he was named general manager at the age of 23. He later returned to New York for two seasons to run the Little Falls Mets of the NYP League. Prior to joining the Smokies, he was in Myrtle Beach where he was the club's general manager with the Blue Jays organization.

He didn't go out for track until his senior year at Fulton High School, when he won the regional championship and came in fourth place statewide in the 100-dash and 220-yard dash. Four years later, Robert Rovere was recognized as one of the fastest sprinters in the country. He ran a 9.2-second 100-yard dash and 20.6 220-yard dash to win the NCAA college division national championship in 1966 at East Tennessee State University, setting new school records. In 1967, he was a member of the Pan American team. A track coach at Powell High School for 20 years, he also works as a speech-language specialist in the Knox County school system.

A two-time All American wide receiver at the University of Tennessee, Larry Seivers was named the SEC athlete of the year in 1977, after being named All American and All-SEC in 1975 and 1976. He led UT in pass receiving three consecutive years and ranks fifth in all-time career reception yardage. He also ranks sixth in career receptions. The Knoxville resident is the general manager of the East Tennessee Division for Five Star Food Service, and he remains active in sports by coaching youth programs.

entry.category: Female High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description: A superlative swimmer who has been ranked as high as 16th in the world and sixth in the nation, Julia Stowers holds 14 Southeastern records for various age groups. She started swimming at age three, and she has competed in every USA Swimming National Championship since the eighth grade. A 2000 graduate of West High School, she helped her team win two state championships and she was named the Tennessee Female High School swimmer of the Year three times. She was a member of the USA swimming team at the 1999 Pan American Games. A member of the Pilot Aquatic Club, she also was a member of the USA national junior team in 1997. A contender for the 2000 USA swimming team in the 200m, 400m and 800m freestyle events, she will attend the University of Georgia in the fall.

Founder of the Greater Knoxville Sports Hall of Fame in 1982, Buck Vaughn has been involved with many sporting events in Knoxville. He was also a founder of the D.D. Lewis Golf Tournament in 1979 (the name changed to the Phillip Fulmer Classic in 2000). Each of these events has raised over $2 million for the Boys and Girls Clubs of the Tennessee Valley. He was one of several founders and vice chairman for the Greater Knoxville Sports Corporation. He has been involved in coordinating many major golf tournaments in Knoxville, and he has won many awards for his community service. These Awards include The Outstanding Civic Leader for East Tennessee in 1996, the 1999 Knoxvillian of the Year in 1999, and the Medallion Award in 1999 (the top award from the Boys and Girls Clubs of America). A leader in the lumber industry for more than 30 years, he is past president of Appalachian Hardwood Manufacturers, Inc.

A professional tennis player, Chris Woodruff has reached five ATP Tour tournament singles finals, winning two, on three different surfaces ? clay, hard-court and grass. He's also been in three ATP Tour doubles finals. After a knee injury in 1998, he was honored as the Comeback Player of the Year on the 1999 ATP Tour. He played on the United States Davis Cup Team in 2000, and he won the fifth and deciding match in Harare, Zimbabwe in February of this year. At Bearden High School, he won three national junior championships. While at the University of Tennessee, he was a three-time All-American in singles and doubles. Winning the NCAA Collegiate Tennis Championships in singles in 1993, the USTA Sportsmanship Award in 1993 and the Tennis Magazine Junior Sportsmanship Award in 1992.

entry.category: Male High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description: The only three-time state champion in the decathlon, he has won nine individual state championships and one relay state championship. He was also a strong basketball player for Farragut High School.

As captain of the University of Tennessee's 1952 basketball team, Hank Bertelkamp scored 301 points in one season and set an all-time Tennessee record of 20 rebounds in one game. An all-star athlete from DuPont High School in Louisville, Kentucky, Bertelkamp played forward on UT's team from 1949 to 1953 and was a three-year varsity letterman. In the 1952-53 seasons, he was voted by his teammates as the most valuable player and was invited to be the first UT player to participate in the Shrine East-West All-Star game in Kansas City. Bertelkamp has remained active in sports, serving as a member of the UT Athletics Board from 1974-77. He is currently vice chairman of Greater Knoxville Sports Corporation, and co-founder of the Orange Tie Club, a UT basketball booster organization. He is also active in numerous civic organizations, and was named Knoxvillian of the Year in 1996 by the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation.

With more than 22 years of NCAA and international experience as a world-class athlete coach, Doug Brown is now considered one of the nation's top track and field coaches. As a student at the University of Tennessee from 1970 to 1974, Brown won nine All-American honors in cross country and track and was a member of the Volunteers' 1972 NCAA champion cross country team as well as the 1974 NCAA champion track team. Brown is a three-time Olympian who ran the steeplechase at the 1972 Olympics in Munich and the 1976 Olympics in Montreal, and qualified for the boycotted 1980 Games in Moscow. He was the NCAA 3000 meter steeplechase champion in both 1973 and 1974. As coach of the UT track and field teams from 1985 to 1996, Brown led the Volunteers to seven SEC titles and nine top-five national finishes. In 1991, he was named NCAA Division I Coach of the Year. He was appointed assistant U.S. track and field coach for the 1996 Olympics in Atlanta.

Bobby Denton's broadcasting career spans more than 40 years, with 39 of those years at Dick Broadcasting Company as an announcer, music director, program director, operations manager and sales manager. Denton has been NASCAR's public address announcer at Talledega International Motor Speedway for 16 years and the public address announcer for University of Tennessee football for 31 years. His on-air line, "its football time in Tennessee!" is widely recognized. He now serves as vice president and general manager of Citadel Communications Corp., formerly Dick Broadcasting. Under his leadership, WIVK-FM has won six straight Associated Press awards for the state's most outstanding news operation. He was appointed by Gov. Don Sundquist to serve on the Tennessee Film, Entertainment, and Music Commission and served on the Country Music Appreciation Board for eight years.

One of the best golf instructors in Tennessee. Played at Central and Halls High Schools, and as a high school coach won every match in his career. He has given over 30,000 golf lessons over his entire career and has been a member of the Professional Golfers Association for 35 years.

At the young age of 27, Todd Helton has already gained a reputation as one of baseball's best. He was the Colorado Rockies' first-round selection in the 1995 draft. In the 1998 season, Helton was elected the club's player representative, marking the first time the team has named a rookie to that role. Also, in 1998, The Tennessee Sports Hall of Fame named him the Professional Athlete of the Year. Helton's career August batting average is the highest in any month among active major league players, and he is ranked among Major League leaders in 3-6-3 double plays. Helton is a 1992 graduate of Knox Central High School, where he lettered in both football and baseball. At the University of Tennessee, he remained a two-sport star, starting several football games in the 1994 season as quarterback for the Volunteers and, as first baseman/pitcher during baseball season, set 19 school records.

After playing guard for the University of Tennessee basketball team, Allan Houston joined the Detroit Pistons in the 1993-94 season. He is now known as one of the NBA's best outside shooters and all-around guards. In the 1995-96 season, after raising his scoring average more than five points to 19.7 per game, Houston signed as a free agent with the New York Knicks. The next season, he became the team's scoring leader and ranked second in the league in three-point percentage. In the deciding game of the first-round series in the 1999 playoffs, Houston sand an off-balance, eight-foot running jumper to defeat the Miami Heat and send his team to the NBA finals. In 1992, Houston was part of the elite eight-man USA Olympic Development Team that scrimmaged against the original Dream Team. In 1999, he joined the U.S. team that won the gold medal and a Sydney Olympic berth at the Pre-Olympic Tournament of the Americas.

As a member of the University of Tennessee's football team, Tim Irwin was a three-year letterman, a two-years starter, and team captain his senior year. As a senior, he was voted the most valuable player on offense. While at UT, Irwin was selected to play in the Japan Bowl and in the East-West Shrine Game. In addition to his athletic achievements, he was named an Academic All-American and received an NCAA post-graduate scholarship. After college, Irwin played professionally for the Minnesota Vikings for 13 years, followed by a year with Tampa Bay and Miami, and was elected to the 40th Anniversary All-Time Viking Team in 2001. Before his retirement, he started 197 consecutive games. He received his J.D. degree from UT, and became the first sports agent to be certified in Tennessee. Irwin is president of the Corporate Board of the Boys and Girls Club of Greater Knoxville.

Described as the most dominant runner in the Knoxville area, Jasmin Jones Keller has a long history of track success as a 10-time All-American. At the University of Tennessee, Keller set the college record for 800 meters with a time of 2:00.24, and was a 10-time All-SEC honoree. She was also a four-time SEC champion in the 3200-meter relay from 1989 to 1991, and a member of the 1992 Indoor World Champion team for 1500 meters. From 1990-1991, Keller was the NCAA runner-up in the 800-and 1500-meter races, and was a finalist in the same events at the 1992 Olympic trials. She is most recognized, however, for being ranked in the top 10 in the U.S. in both the mile and 800 meters for five consecutive years (1990-94). In local races, Keller's times place alongside the top five male finishers. She has also won every Knoxville road race in which she has competed from 1997 to 2000. Keller was the Expo 10k champion in both 1995 and 2000.

A sportswriter with the Knoxville News-Sentinel, he has covered a wide range of sports, including some of NASCAR's greatest drivers like Richard Petty and Jeff Gordon. He is most recognized for his coverage of Knoxville high school sports and was high school sports editor at the News-Sentinel for over 20 years.

entry.category: Female High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description: A star athlete in basketball, volleyball, and track, Julie Maples, a South-Doyle High School graduate, was named All-KIL for both basketball and volleyball in 2001. This recognition followed a four-year high school career as All-District IV AAA in both sports. She was also named All-KIL in track for the 4 x 200 relay in 2000 and finished sixth at the National YBOA Tournament in 2001. Maples was voted Co-MVP for both All-District IV AAA Basketball and All-District IV AAA Volleyball tournament in 2001. The same year, she was selected as All-East Tennessee in basketball and All-State in volleyball. While at South-Doyle, Maples was also involved in the Anchor Club, the National Honor Society, Fellowship of Christian Athletes, and the student government. She will attend Tusculum College on a basketball/academic scholarship.

With a legacy of sports and academic excellence behind him, Reggie McKenzie is now known as the Green Bay Packers' irreplaceable director of pro personnel, a position he has held for seven years. McKenzie was a football star and valedictorian of his Austin East High School graduating class. At the University of Tennessee, he earned a bachelor's degree in business administration with an emphasis in personnel management. After graduating from UT in 1985, McKenzie was drafted in the 10th round by the Los Angeles Raiders. During his first two seasons with the Raiders, he won all-rookie honors and was the team's second-leading tackler. After four years with the Raiders, McKenzie joined the Phoenix Cardinals for two seasons and the San Francisco 49ers for a year before a knee injury forced him to retire. McKenzie is the president of the McKenzie Foundation, that awards scholarships to Austin East graduates.

He was a member of U.T.'s first consensus national championship team, and played linebacker for three seasons. He was drafted by the Los Angeles Rams, then played with the Chicago Cardinals, appearing in 26 career NFL games. He was instrumental in the creation of U.T.'s Letterman Wall of Fame.

Once named the most valuable pitcher in all of AAA Baseball, Steve Searcy began his baseball career at Central High School. He was named All-State pitcher for Central in 1982, and was voted most valuable pitcher by his teammates. In the summer of 1982, Searcy played for the gold-metal-winning World's Fair Baseball Team. A member of the University of Tennessee baseball team from 1983 to 1985, he was named to the All-SEC team his sophomore year. The Detroit Tigers drafted Searcy in 1985 in the third round. Six years later, he was traded to Philadelphia Phillies. Searcy is one of nine players recently selected for the UT Baseball Wall of Fame. For the past 15 years, he has taught aspiring pitchers of all ages. Searcy currently operates Pratt's County Store, a family-owned business in Fountain City.

Now in his 22nd season as head coach of the Carson Newman Eagles, Ken Sparks began his coaching career in Knoxville, posting a winning record for the restart football team at Gibbs High School before moving to Tennessee Technological University to coach quarterbacks and receivers. In 1977, Sparks joined Carson-Newman to coach both football and track and was named Southern Collegiate Track Coach of the Year. In the same year, he became head football coach at Farragut High School, where he led the Admirals to a 29-5 record in three seasons and was twice voted KIL and KFA Coach of the Year. In 1980, Sparks returned to Carson-Newman as head football coach, leading them to five national championships and 15 South Atlantic Conference championships. He is the third winningest active coach in NCAA Division II, and his peers voted him SAC Coach of the Year nine times.

entry.category: Male High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description: In both 1999 and 2000, Sean Stevens was the cross-country champion for the KIL, Region AAA, and Tennessee AAA and was also KIL track champion for the 3200-meter and 800-meter races. He is a three-time KIL Track Distance Runner of the Year (1999 to 2001). In 2000, he set a meet record of 15:02 in a race against seven other state champions, set a KIL Cross Country a Cherokee Boulevard course record, and set meet records in the 1600- and 3200 meter events for the Tennessee Region III AAA. In April 2001, at the Mobil Meet of Champions, Stevens broke the 23-year-old Tennessee state record in the 3200-meter by a full second. While at West High School, Stevens was also in the top ten percent of his graduating class and was involved in Young Life and the National Honor Society. He will attend Wake Forest University on a track scholarship.

To date, Tate is the only world sports champion to claim Knoxville as his home. Tate, the Fighting Machine, won the vacant World Boxing Association title in 1979 in a box-off between four leading contenders. Four years earlier, he had caught the attention of Jerry Ace Miller, Knoxville Golden Gloves General Manager, at the 1975 National Golden Gloves Tournament in Knoxville, That year; Tate moved to Knoxville and dedicated himself to learning the craft of boxing from Miller. He went on to represent the U.S. at the 1976 Olympics in Montreal, Canada, where he received a bronze medal in the super-heavyweight division and won the hearts of the American public. Following his success at the Olympics, Tate turned professional. Over a period of three years, 15 of Tate's 18 victories were made by knockouts. He had a career record of 34-3 with 23 knockouts. In 1979, Tate won the WBA heavyweight championship in South Africa.

A charter member of the University of Tennessee's letterman club, Bill Deatherage was the East Tennessee Golden Gloves heavyweight champion for three consecutive years and the southern Golden Gloves heavyweight champion for two years. With an amateur record of 78 wins and 5 losses, Deatherage was inducted into the Tennessee-Alabama-Georgia Boxing Hall of Fame in 1980. In addition to his boxing achievements, Deatherage coached basketball at Knoxville Catholic High School, where he was named district basketball coach of the year for three consecutive years. As a senior game participant, Deatherage won 20 gold metals in the shot put, discus, and javelin on both East Tennessee and state levels. Past president of Golden Gloves Charities, Deatherage was an amateur boxing referee for 37 years on the local, southern, and national levels.

A native of Lawrence, Kansas, Keith DeLong was a three-year started at UT as inside linebacker and was Tennessee's nominee for the 1989 SEC "Athlete of the Year." Son of former Vol All-American and 1964 Outland Trophy winner Steve Delong, Keith recorded 159 total hits, including 117 solos in 1988, ranking his 1988 season 10th and third in Vol history in those categories. He was named first team All-American and All SEC and was a finalist for the Butkus Award. DeLong was a first-round pick of the Super Bowl champion San Francisco 49ers in the 1989 professional football draft.

entry.category: Female High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description: A member of the volleyball, track, and basketball teams at Halls High school, Ferris was named All State, District MVP, and Academic MVP in volley ball. She holds school track records and was named to the All District and All KIL teams in basketball as leading scorer and leading rebounder.

Fielden's officiating career, spanning six decades, began in 1959 after coaching basketball at Horace Maynard High School. When the TSSAA formed the Knox-Ridge Basketball Association in 1970, Fielden became the association supervisor, a position he has held for 32 years. Fielden worked junior college games for the Volunteer State, Trans-America, Metro, Ohio Valley and Southeastern conferences. In 1980, he advanced to the regional finals of the NCAA Division I Men's Championship in Houston, Texas. He worked the Tennessee vs. Temple "freeze" game that was recently featured in Referee Magazine. Fielden pioneered the now widely used computerized scheduling system and initiated the rotation of officials at the district and regional tournaments, a system later adopted by the TSSAA. He was inducted into the TSSAA Hall of Fame in 1996.

Two-time Major League All Star; Todd Helton was the Colorado Rockies' first-round draft pick in 1995.He has a career batting average of .334. A Gold Glove winner at first base, with only two errors, he is ranked among Major League leaders in 3-6-3 double plays. Helton was named Professional Athlete of the Year by the Tennessee Sports Hall of Fame in 1998. At Knox Central High School, Helton lettered in both football and baseball. He remained a two-sport start at the University of Tennessee, where he started several football games in the 1994 season. In baseball, Helton was a three-time All-American, set 19 school records, and led the team to the College World Series in 1995. Leading in home runs and RBIs, Helton narrowly missed the 1995 SEC Triple Crown. He was named Baseball America's 1995 Player of the Year, SEC's Player of the Year, and the Mizuno/Collegiate Baseball Co-National Player of the Year.

An SEC commissioner since 1990, Roy Kramer is credited with helping solidify the SEC an the NCAA's richest conference and with designing the Bowl Championship Series used to determine the national football champion. Kramer led the SEC in accumulating $95 million in revenues in 2000, the most of any collegiate athletic league. Captain of the 1946 Maryville High School team, Kramer went on to play football at Maryville College. While at Maryville College, he led the 1947 team to play in the first Tangerine Bowl in Orlando, Florida. After returning from the Korean War, Kramer returned to school and graduated from the University of Tennessee. He later became a football coach at Central Michigan and athletic director at Vanderbilt. Kramer twice served as chairman of the NCAA men's basketball tournament selection committee.

At six years old, Laugherty began swimming in the Knoxville summer Interclub League and had set regional records in several events by the age of 12. At Baylor School in Chattanooga, Laugherty was the Eastern Prep School champion in the 200-meter Individual Medley and second in the 100-breast stroke.
