In his four years at Baylor, he swam times that qualified him for All-American honors in every high school event. Laugherty was selected to join a U.S. National Team to compete against Russia and was a member of the team that set the national record in the 200 Medley relay. At the University of Florida, where he was an eight-time All-American, Laugherty's teams won four consecutive SEC titles and two NCAA titles. He set an SEC record in 1984 in the 200 IM and the 200 breaststroke.

Director of Southern Golf Associations since 1972, Milner won state titles in three sports at Knoxville High School. In 1942, he was named Football's Most Outstanding Blocker in the team at the University of Richmond and played football and baseball at the University of Tennessee. Milner was president of the Letterman T Club and co-founder of the Knoxville Quarterback Club. His 1946 football team became co-champs of the SEC, and he played shortstop in the 1948 baseball season. A nationally ranked golfer, Milner has been club champ at Dean Hill County Club and Fox Den Country Club, a member of the Mid South Cup Team, and has played four USGA and two British Open Senior Championships. He was ranked fifth in the nation by Golf Digest in 1981 and was the Eastern Seniors Champion in 1982.

entry.category: Male High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description: A football and track athlete at Fulton High School, Jeff Mitchell was named All Region 2AAA and the Region 2AAA player of the year in 2001. The 2001 team captain and MVP, Mitchell was All KFL, KFL Offensive Player of the Year, and All East Tennessee. He was also selected for the AP, Preptalk, and Sportswriter's AAA All-State Teams. With 44 career touchdowns, he was a TSSAA AAA Mr. Football finalist. In track, Mitchell was a TSSAA state track meet participant in the 4 x 100 and 4 x 200 relays and was named All KIL, All State, and All Region.

Head basketball coach and Assistant Athletic Director at Oak Ridge High School, Jill Prudden just completed her twenty-third year in the Oak Ridge school system. Prudden's coaching record of 672-115 includes 19 district titles, 17 regional titles, 18 state appearances, and 3 state championships. In 1988, Prudden served as head coach of the bronze-medal winning team in the USA Basketball Women's World Youth Games that competed in Moscow. In 1997, Prudden was named WBCA Coach of the Year and was inducted into the Oak Ridge Sports Hall of Fame in 1998. With a BS in physical education and a Masters from Lincoln Memorial University, Prudden has been named East Tennessee coach of the year five times. She currently serves on the USA Basketball Cadet and Youth Committee.

Credited with establishing the Florida Citrus Bowl as the "Best Bowl Trip in America," Chuck Rohe served as executive director of Florida Citrus Sports for nearly two decades. From 1982 to 1998, Rohe sold out 13 or 16 games and spearheaded an effort to expand and renovate the stadium in the late 1980's, bringing additional world-class sporting events to Orlando. As track coach at the University of Tennessee from 1963 to 1971, Rohe won 21 consecutive SEC Championships in cross-country and indoor an outdoor track. In 1967, he was the United States Track and Field Coach of the Year. The NCAA representative on the United States Olympic Committee from 1968 to 1976, Rohe has served in coaching and administrative positions at Southern Miss, Furman, and Virginia Tech.

The first African-American in the state to play on an integrated basketball team, Dwayne Simmons was also the first black athlete to play at Martin College and in the Birmingham Civic Coliseum. Simmons played basketball at Knoxville College, where he received a BS in Health and Physical Education. He was a basketball coach in Toledo, Ohio, where his teams were City Champions for three consecutive years. Simmons returned to Knoxville College in 1972, where he held several positions, including head basketball coach. In 1978, he was voted Coach of the Year when his team won the SIAC Conference and reached the Elite 8 Division III of NCAA. With a Masters in Administration and Supervision from Lincoln Memorial University, Simmons currently serves as principal of Northwest Middle School in Knoxville.

A high school All-American at Austin-East High School, LeRoy Thompson was named the number one college prospect in the U.S. and first team All-American by USA Today in 1986. At Austin-East, he had a total of 77 career-rushing touchdowns, 5,682 career-rushing yards, and 15 career receiving touchdowns. On defense, he had 41 interceptions and 15 fumble recoveries. He was first team All State both his junior and senior years. An All-American at Penn State University, Thompson was named MVP in the 1987 Florida Citrus Bowl and was the team co-captain, MVP and All-Big East Running Back in 1990. Thompson was a fifth round draft pick for the Pittsburgh Steelers, becoming co-captain in 1993 when he led the Steelers in rushing 763 yards. In 1994, he led the Patriots in kick-off returns and helped set an NFL record as one of five players to have 50 catches apiece or more.

A native Knoxvillian, Stanley Underwood has been a member of the Knoxville Track Club for more than two decades, where he has served as coordinator of track officials since 1992. Underwood has served as chief vault official and coordinator of officials at many outdoor championships, such as the Southeastern Conference Outdoor Championship from 2000 to 2002. At the Tennessee Association of USA Track and Field, Underwood serves as both board of managers and officials certification chair. He has also been the coordinator of officials for the University of Tennessee's Track and Field Meet Management since 1996.

Head pro at Holston Hills Country Club for more than two decades, he was the 1999 Teacher of the Year and state golf pro of the year in 1983. A member of PGA National Rules Committee, he was director of golf operations during the International PGA Cup matches. He has won several Senior PGA Championships.

A 400m hurdler by trade, Mike Barlow left his biggest mark as one of the finest relay men in the University of Tennessee track and field history. A 1979 UT graduate and team captain, he has seven All-America titles and two NCAA titles in the 4 x 400 relay. His 400m-hurdle time still stands sixth on the all time Vols list 25 years later. After college, he ran for Athletes in Action and participated in the 1980 Olympic Trials. He lives in Knoxville and owns a company called Barlow Installation Group, Inc., which designs and install permanent seating for stadiums and arenas. His wife is Connie and his children are Tanner, 18, and TY, 16. He lives in West Knoxville.

entry.category: Female High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description: Jennifer Bell is known as a versatile athlete at South Doyle High, lettering in golf, basketball, track and cross-country. In her senior year, she received All District in golf, basketball and All-KlL basketball. She currently holds her high school's records in golf, triple jump, long jump, pentathlon and relay. Other honors include the United States Marine Corps Distinguished Athlete Award, News Sentinel Inaugural Unsung Hero Award, and South Doyle High School Most Athletic Senior Superlative. She graduated in May 2003 with a 3.68 GPA. Her parents are Joe and Kelly Bell of Knoxville.

Known for her recruiting success, DeMoss spent 18 years as an Assistant Lady Vols basketball coach. Under DeMoss' tutelage, the Lady Vols amassed a 549-76 record, 6 NCAA titles and 12 Final Four appearances. In 2003 she accepted a head coach position at the University of Kentucky.

Mike DePalmer, Jr. made his name as a college tennis player at UT who went on to play professionally and then coach some of the biggest names in the game, including Boris Becker, Mark Philippoussis, and Knoxville's Chris Woodruff. DePalmer was a 1985 member of the U.S. Davis Cup team, as well as a two-time U.S. Open quarterfinalist and semifinalist. He finished No. 4 in the world in doubles with Gary Donnelly. He had 13 career doubles titles and played 27 Grand Slam events. He advanced past the third round in all four Grand Slams. His highest world ranking was No. 32 in ingles and No. 18 in doubles with Donnelly. He now lives in Knoxville and is currently working with Justin Gimelstob from Morristown, New Jersey. His wife is Angelique, and they have a son named Logan, 16.

Mike DePalmer, Sr. is an outstanding former University of Tennessee tennis coach and father of fellow honoree Mike DePalmer, Jr. He was inducted into the College Tennis Hall of Fame in 1995. At UT, his players won two SEC championships and bagged six NCAA appearances. DePalmer's coaching excellence produced 20 All-Americans and 25 All SEC tennis honorees. He developed and was director of the International Tennis Management Program for the Nick Bollettieri Tennis Academy. He retired in 1999 and lives in Bradenton, Florida.

Doug Dickey has been recognized as a football player during his collegiate career at Florida, as an assistant coach, as head coach at Tennessee and Florida, and as an administrator. His many honors and awards include recognition from the National Football Foundation's College Football Hall of Fame, as well as the John H. Toner Award, and Robert R. Neyland trophy, given by the Knoxville Quarterback Club. In 2000, he was named Tennessean of the Year by the Tennessee Sports Hall of Fame. He was head coach at Tennessee from 1964-69, at Florida from 1970-78 and was Director of Athletics at Tennessee from 1985-2003. He will be inducted into the College Football Hall of Fame as a head coach in December 2003.

A recipient of many of the sport of Volleyball's top awards, Bud has been responsible for organizing volleyball in the Knoxville area for 50 years. He played volleyball in the YMCA system, which was the highest level of the sport in the 50's ? 70's. He started the men and women's volleyball programs at the University of Tennessee.

Known as the "Dash Flash" he was awarded Knoxville Track Club's outstanding athlete award in 1963. An Austin East High School football player and Knoxville College student athlete, he consistently ran the 100-yard dash in 9.7 seconds. He later coached football at Knoxville College.

Becky Hartman was known for her tremendous versatility as a student athlete who grew up in Ashland City, Tennessee. She was a high school basketball player and was then recruited to play AAU basketball for Genesco and Cook's Goldblumes. The Cook's Goldblumes team won a National Championship, and Becky was named Honorable Mention All-American. She also played second base for the C.B. Ragland softball team that won a Southeastern Championship. Hartman garnered numerous national awards in the sports of basketball, softball, and golf. She has been president of both the Tennessee Women's State Golf Association and the Knox Area Women's Golf Association. She has lived in Knoxville since 1956 and is a member of the Cherokee Country Club.

As a student at Halls High School, Ian O'Connor served as varsity captain for both the soccer and football teams. He received All Region Football and Soccer honors, as well as All KFL Football, and several player of the week recognitions. He was named KFL Football Player of the Week, Associated Press High School Football State of the Week, WBIR Blitz Football Player of the Week, Texas Roadhouse High School Player of the Week, and Kia Sportage and Titans Radio field goals in one season, including one 52-yard field goal. He graduated in May 2003 with a 3.69 GPA. His parents are Bob and Renee O'Connor.

Chad Pennington earned all-district and all region selection as a student at Webb School of Knoxville. Attending college at Marshall, he set several records and led the team to a 13-0 record his senior year. Drafted by the New York Jets, Pennington took over the starting quarterback job in 2002, leading the team to an AFC Wild Card playoff game. He was named AFC Offensive Player of the Week three times during the season and was voted the team's Most Valuable Player by his teammates. He also won the Kyle Clifton Good Guy Award.

A Knoxville native, Pickens was an all-everything football star at Knoxville's Young High School in 1965. At the University of Tennessee he was a three-year starter leading the SEC in rushing in 1968. He was the Offensive MVP of the 1968 team and an All-SEC selection his senior year.

A standout at Knoxville's Webb School who graduated in 1980, Melissa Vaughn went on to become an All-American at the University of Kentucky in 1983, and was captain of the University's track and field team in 1984. She was ranked eighth in the world in the 1000m in 1984 and held 12 varsity letters at UK in cross country, indoor track and outdoor track. A four time All SEC. Melissa was also awarded the University of Kentucky Scholar-Athlete of the Year and Woman Athlete of the Year. She now resides in Boulder, Colorado.

A University of Tennessee gridiron standout, Bruce Wilderson was frafted by the Los Angeles Raiders in the second round of the 1987 NFL draft. A versatile lineman, he played 8 seasons for the Raiders, including 107 games with 86 starts. He briefly played for Jacksonville and Green Bay before ending his athletic career with the Oakland Raiders in 1998, having played 12 years as a professional football player.

He had a long and storied career as sports editor of the News Sentinel from 1926 to 1957. He organized the city's first amateur baseball leagues and the Golden Gloves boxing program. UT coach General Neyland once said, "No writer knew Tennessee football better than Bob Wilson."

entry.category: Female High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description: A Parade All-America and four-time All-KIL selection, Sade Buley scored more than 2,000 points in her basketball career at Knoxville's South-Doyle High School. She was named to the All-District and All-Region teams for four years running, and was an Adidas All-America and USA Today Top 30 player.In 2002, she was named Knoxville Sophomore Player of the Year and went on to amass a number of honors for her outstanding performance on the court, including a spot on the East Tennessee Prep-Xtra All Star Team and a nomination for the McDonalds All-America Team. Buley signed with University of Kentucky this year.

After starring in football for Rule High School, he became a three year-starter at defensive end for the University of Tennessee. He was a team captain his senior year and was named UT's outstanding lineman. He was taken in the third round of the NFL draft by the Detroit Lions and played in the NFL from 1983 through 1992.

A High School All-American at Anderson County, she is widely remembered as the captain of the Lady Vols first national championship team. Shelly Sexton Collier became UT's starting point guard in her sophomore season and held that position for the rest of her career. As a senior, she helped UT defeat Louisiana Tech for the first of its six national championships.A successful high school basketball coach for 15 years, Collier just finished her sixth season as Webb's head coach, where she led her team to two regional championships. She has also coached at Clinton and Karns.

A star basketball player at Austin High School from 1959 to 1960, Richard Davis was the first Knoxville area player recruited by Tennessee State University, where he had a double-figure scoring average for his four-year career. The first all-black team to play in the AAU National Tournament, TSU became the top-ranked small college team in the nation and defeated many internationals teams.Davis averaged more than 20 points a game his senior season at Austin High, where he was a team captain for two years. He was also a standout in baseball and football. As an adult, he coached recreation league football and was instrumental in ensuring that girls had opportunities to play league basketball. Davis worked for the Aluminum Company of America in Alcoa for more than 38 years before retiring in March.

Glenn Glass was a single-wing tailback and defensive back at the University of Tennessee in the 1960s before being taken in the second round of the NFL draft by the Pittsburgh Steelers. He led the 1959 UT team in rushing with 75 carries for 261 yards. He had 100 yards rushing against North Carolina in 1961 and 101 against Tampa in 1960.He played with the Steelers, Philadelphia Eagles, Atlanta Falcons, and Denver Broncos in his six NFL seasons. He now lives in Knoxville.

He captained the 1965 Warrior basketball squad and earned letters in golf at Knoxville's Holston High School. He graduated from Clemson University in 1970. He timed University of Tennessee wrestling from 1983 to 1986 and has timed UT basketball since taking over for his dad in 1984.

In 1944, Sid Hankins Jr. began a 40-year tenure as a timer under six head coaches at the University of Tennessee. He timed games for the Knoxville Knights hockey team, coached both boys and girls basketball at Knoxville's Catholic High School and led the Pepsi-Cola women's team to the Southern Appalachian Championship in 1948.Hankins had a 50-year career at Standard Knitting Mills, where he rose to the position of executive vice-president, and he was president of Knoxville's Holston Hills Country Club from 1973 to 1975.

As a University of Tennessee football player in 1957, Herzbrun regularly played 60 minutes a game as an offensive guard and defensive tackle. He later played service football and semi-pro ball with the Knoxville Bears before accepting a coaching job at Fulton High School.Herzbrun served as a linebackers and strength coach at UT for seven years and coached All-America Vols Steve Kiner, Jack Reynolds, Jackie Walker, and Jamie Rotella.

He won three state championships and 14 regional titles while coaching track at three different Knoxville high schools from 1959 through 1984. He won 37 Knoxville Interscholastic League titles and had a 217-44-4 record in dual and triangular meets.

He played four sports at Rule High School, played football at Maryville College, and later served Rule as a coach, teacher and administrator for 26 years. He coached four sports at Rule, and led the football team to two city championships. As a coach, he had a huge impact on junior high and high school athletics. He started the first Junior Athletics Program in Knoxville.He served in the U.S. Navy during World War II and later earned a master's degree from UT. He became a leader in Knoxville education serving as the assistant superintendent of the city's schools from 1976 until his retirement in 1982. He remains active in the educational community as a member of the Knox County School Board since 1996.

In 2003, Tom Pappas, a former Vol decathlete and NCAA record holder, had the most successful season by a U.S. decathlete in a decade. He won the Jesse Owens Award and the Jim Thorpe Award, earned gold medals in the decathlon at the World Outdoor Championships and in the heptathlon at World Indoors, and received a No. 1 ranking from the IAAF. In 2004, he defeated the decathlon world record holder, won the gold medal in the decathlon at the World Outdoor Championships and became the first American in 11 years to win the World Indoors. He will compete in the Olympic Games in Athens, Greece, this summer.

A Rule High School graduate, Roy Smith started at defensive tackle on the 1950 University of Tennessee football team, which went 11-1, including a 20-14 victory against Texas in the Cotton Bowl. Smith lettered as both an offensive guard and defensive tackle for four years, and went on to play on two national championship teams in the military while stationed at Carswell Air Force Base.

Max Springer, a former University of Tennessee professor, did not begin running competitively until age 64. He set world records in the 800-meter run, 3,000-meter run, and long jump for the 90-to-94 year-old age bracket in the USA Track and Field National Masters Indoor Championships this year in Boston, and his accomplishments were note in Sports Illustrated. He also set national records in the 200-meter run, 400, and triple jump. At 90, Springer is still going strong.

entry.category: Male High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description: A two-time American General Mr. Football finalist, Demarcus Stevens led Fulton High School to the Class 3A state football championship. As a threat on both offense and defense, his presence dictated the opposing team's game plan and earned him numerous titles and awards, including two years on the All-State and All-KFL teams, KFL Player of the Year, Prep Xtra Player of the Year, and Defensive Player of the Game in two consecutive state championship games.As a track athlete, Stevens was ALL-KIL in 2003 and 2004, the Region 110 high hurdle champion for three consecutive years, and the state champion in the 110 high hurdles in 2004. He recently signed with Carson-Newman College.

He was an award-winning sportswriter, a sports editor, and a managing editor in his 30 years with the Knoxville News-Sentinel. He then became the national sports editor for Scripps Howard News Service, where he was later promoted to managing editor.

entry.category: Female High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description: Stephanie Woodfin, KIL Athlete of the Year for 2003 and Carter High School student, has dominated high school track meets for the last three years. She won two consecutive state championships in the 200, three consecutive state championships in the 100, and won the 100 at the national AAU championships last summer. During her senior year, she earned the sixth best time nationally in the 55-meter dash, earned multiple first place finishes at meets around the southeast, and finished 11th overall out of 50 runners at the Nike Indoor Championships.

Bill Bates' sports career began at Farragut High School, where he played football, basketball, and ran track. At UT, Bates starred as a safety for four years and was known as the Vols' hardest hitter and surest tackler. In 1983, Bates was offered the opportunity of a lifetime, a place on the Dallas Cowboys roster as a long-shot free-agent rookie. Even with his numerous achievements in Dallasthree Super Bowl Championships, 12 consecutive years on the All-Madden Team, and induction into the Madden Hall of Fame?it was his unwavering perseverance that set him apart. Bates won several awards for his leadership and courage, including the Bob Lilly Award, the Ed Block Courage Award, the Unsung Hero award, and the Dallas All Sports Association Courage Award. The commitment Bates showed during his 15-year career extended beyond football to the needy children of the Dallas area. Recently, Bates created the Bill Bates Foundation For Children, which rases money for organizations that help kids.

Although he left the NFL after seven seasons, Ted Davis didn't leave the sport of football behind. In high school leagues in Memphis, Davis began his second sports career as a referee. He continued the work while attending the UT College of Veterinary Medicine and built such a reputation as a top-notch referee, he eventually landed a position as an official in the first SEC Championship Game in 1992.

In addition to his talents of enforcing the rules of football, Davis had a distinguished playing career. While an undergrad at Georgia Tech, he was elected to the All-Time Bobby Dodd's Era Team and the Georgia Tech Hall of Fame. He also played in the College All-Star Game and the Senior Bowl. After college, Davis joined the NFL and played linebacker for the then-Baltimore Colts, New Orleans Saints, and Miami Dolphins.

Davis currently lives in Knoxville where he owns and runs the Knoxville Animal Clinic.

From his boyhood in Michigan to the major leagues, Fred Gladding's talent on the mound secured him a place in baseball history as one of the best relief pitchers ever. Gladding's winning streak started in 1959 when he helped the Knoxville Smokies win the South Atlantic League Championship. In 1961, Gladding entered the majors where he played for the Detroit Tigers and the Houston Astros, both for seven years. With the Astros, Gladding led the National League in saves in 1969. Although he retired as a player in 1973, Gladding continued his involvement with the game as a minor league pitching coach. After 22 years in the minors, the bus rides got to be too long and Gladding retired to Knoxville where he volunteered his skills and experience to the Powell High School baseball team.

With nine Greater Knoxville Amateur titles and four City Men's Open Championships under his belt, Jeff Golliher is a local golf heavyweight. Golliher played for Bearden High School and the UT Golf Team. While in college, Golliher served as team captain and earned the distinction of Most Valuable Player. After graduation, Golliher unleashed his talent on the Knoxville circuit racking up 49 local titles. He also proved his talent on the road, with 17 appearances and three wins in the national amateur arena.

Golf also allows Golliher to serve the community by organizing and running charity tournaments like the Greater Knoxville Amateur Golf Tournament, as well as tournaments to benefit the Helen Ross McNabb Foundation and Children's Hospital.

A financial planner, Golliher lives in Knoxville with his wife, Andrea, and their two children Taylor and John.

Steve Golliher and golf make a wonderful combination. At his Kentucky high school, Golliher helped his team win the 1972 State Championship and was the two-time winner of the Paducah City Championship, Western Kentucky Amateur, and Irvin S. Cobb Championship. As a collegiate golfer at the University of Miami from 1975 ? 1978, Golliher served two years as team captain and won both the Bayshore and the Miami Biltmore Intercollegiate Championships.

Golliher's Knoxville golf career has been equally successful. He has 16 local championship titles, including the Knoxville City Championship and Greater Knoxville Amateur. Success is not limited to the local circuit for Golliher; he has participated in three mid-amateur competitions and five amateur games. He and his brother, Jeff, also won the J.R. Williams Four Ball Championship as partners.

Golliher and wife, Laura, live in Knoxville with their three children, Olivia, Christopher, and Caroline. He is a financial planner at Smith Barney.

Gary Lundy's journalism career started at UT's student paper, The Daily Beacon, where he was a sports editor. After graduation in 1977, Lundy went to work for several local newspapers before settling at the Knoxville Journal. At the Journal, Lundy covered UT sports, specializing in basketball. In 1991, when the Journal went out of business, Lundy began working at the News Sentinel where he continued his UT sports beat. Lundy's "Best and Worst" feature was one of the most widely read items in the News Sentinel's UT football coverage. In addition, Lundy wrote columns and covered other sporting events, including the Winter Olympics in Norway in 1994 and Salt Lake City in 2002. During Lundy's 27-year career, he won numerous writing awards, including Tennessee Sportswriter of the Year in 1999 and 2003.

Lundy died November 22, 2004, at the age of 49. He is survived by his wife Cindy Ross Lundy and son Christian.

Tim Mack began pole vaulting at his Canton, Ohio, middle school as an alternative to distance running and has never looked back. From his 1991 Junior Olympic championship to his 2004 Olympic Gold Medal, Mack has made a lasting impression in the world of track and field.

When Mack came to University of Tennessee in 1993, he made an immediate impact, earning All-American honors in 1994 and the 1995 NCAA Indoor Champion title. In addition to his track and field awards, Mack graduated with a Master's Degree from the university. Mack's career after graduation was just as impressive. He was a gold medallist and trial champion at the 2004 Olympics, gold medallist at the 2001 Goodwill Games, runner-up at the 2001 and 2002 U.S. Outdoor Track and Field Championships, and pole vault champion at the 2002 U.S. Indoor Track and Field Championships.

Mack lives in Knoxville where he coaches aspiring pole vaulters, including three male state champions and one female state champion. Mack credits his success to the unwavering support of his parents, Don and Arlene.

entry.category: Male High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description:
Austin-East Magnet School's Anthony McAlister graduates as a distinguished athlete and scholar. McAlister's achievements on the football field earned him the titles of American General Class 3-A Mr. Football and Prep Xtra's Defensive Player of the Year. In addition to helping the Roadrunners bring home the regional title, McAlister participated on the All-State KIL and Austin-East All-Star teams. McAlister also earned All-Regions recognition as a basketball player.

In the fall, McAlister plans to attend the University of Tennessee.

With 16 years of NFL experience, Raleigh McKenzie is a seasoned professional. While playing three different positions at Austin East High School, McKenzie was an all-state, all-conference, and all-city football player. His talent, however, wasn't limited to the turf; McKenzie also lettered in track, baseball, and basketball. But when McKenzie was offered a spot on the UT football team, he left the other sports behind.

After a collegiate career in which he was a four-time letter winner and a participant in the Japan Bowl all-star game, McKenzie entered the NFL and played every position along the offensive front while in the league. Two Super Bowl wins with the Washington Redskins, third place among NFL's most active offensive linemen, and 13 post-season starts are among McKenzie's most notable NFL achievements.

An active community member, McKenzie, and his twin brother, Reggie, run the Knoxville-based McKenzie Foundation, a non-profit youth foundation that awards academic scholarships to graduating seniors at Austin East. McKenzie also hosts an annual off-season football camp in town. He and his wife, Martha, have three children, Raleigh Jr., Malcolm, and Rachel.

Football has been a way of life for Reggie McKenzie, from his start at Austin East High School, to his days as a player at UT and in the NFL, to his current job with the Green Bay Packers.

At Austin East, McKenzie was a two-way football star and valedictorian of his 1981 graduating class. At UT, McKenzie played linebacker for Phillip Fulmer until he entered the NFL in 1985 with the then-Los Angeles Raiders. McKenzie's professional career began with all-rookie honors and two tackle-leading seasons. McKenzie left the Raiders in 1988 and spent two seasons with the Phoenix Cardinals and one year with the San Francisco 49ers before a knee injury forced him to retire.

McKenzie returned to Knoxville in 1993 and served as an assistant coach for the Vols while pursuing his Master's Degree in education administration. He landed a job in the Green Bay Packers pro personnel department, where he has worked for the last ten years scouting all of football's professional leagues, assessing current players, and evaluating potential free agents.

McKenzie and his wife, June, have four children: Jasmin, Mahkayla, Reginald Kahlil, and Jalen Elijah.

entry.category: Female High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description:
Erin Ogan doesn't discriminate when it comes to sports. With letters in four different sports, Ogan has proven her athletic talent.

In basketball, Ogan was named to the All-District Tournament team for four consecutive years and the All-Region Tournament team in 2004 and 2005. She was also District MVP for two consecutive years, a Prep Xtra Player of the Week, and KIL Player of the Year. Ogan holds Powell High School's all-time scoring record with 1,753 points.

In golf, Ogan made the All-District and All-District Tournament teams for three consecutive years and acquired four letters throughout her high school career. Ogan also lettered in volleyball and participated in the All-District Tournament in 2004. During the 2002 school year Ogan lettered in softball.

Ogan will attend UT ? Chattanooga in the fall.

A former football player, Pat Shires reserved his own sports legacy by keeping the story of all UT athletes and athletics alive through his work on the UT Lettermen's Wall. The Wall, which has become part of the Vol Walk, records the names of all past student-athletes and serves to promote and preserve the friendships of former UT players. In addition to his work on UT's sports history, Shires also served as president of UT's Letterman's T-Club.

Shires entered UT in 1949 on a football scholarship after earning top athletic honors at his West Virginia high school. As a starting tailback, Shires played in the 1952 Cotton Bowl and earned three letters as a Vol. After graduation, Shires served in the Army and then held coaching jobs at both Florida and Tennessee high schools. Shires took a job in 1961 as a pharmaceutical salesman, eventually retiring from Proctor and Gamble in 1994. During that time, Shires continued to coach, focusing his talents on Little League football, basketball, and baseball in Knoxville.

Shires lives in Knoxville with his wife of 52 years, Joy, and remains active in the Letterman's T-Club.

When Faye Rogers Stafford played for Porter High School in the late 1950s, guards were restricted to half court and could not shoot the ball, and there were no collegiate women's basketball programs available. However, Rogers Stafford found a way to shine. While captain of the 1959 state championship team, Rogers Stafford also captured the tournament's rebounding record. Throughout her basketball career, Rogers Stafford played on several all-star teams, including the Tennessee All-State and All-State Tournament teams, All-Region All-Tournament team, All-Blount Invitational Tournament team, and Jaycee All-Tournament team. More recently, the Maryville Daily Times named Rogers Stafford to the All-Time Blount County Team.

Rogers Stafford currently lives in Knoxville with her husband of 44 years, Pete. The couple has two children and six grandchildren.

With 31 seasons as the Lady Vols' head coach, the NCAA all-time winningest basketball coach record, 13 SEC Championships, six SEC Coach of the Year awards, seven NCAA Coach of the Year awards, and designation as Naismith Coach of the Century, Pat Summitt has done it all. Although Summitt's professional accomplishments are outstanding in their own right, it is her charisma, perseverance, and leadership that have enshrined her in the hearts of sports fans everywhere.

As a player, Summitt reached the pinnacle of her career at the 1976 U.S. Olympic games, where as co-captain of the women's basketball team, she helped capture a silver medal. That same year she returned to Knoxville and began building her coaching legacy, which includes 882 victories, 11 SEC Tournament titles, and prestigious acclaim for the Lady Vols throughout the sports world.

Summitt's ability to mold players into champions is overshadowed only by her ability to inspire personal success. As a motivational speaker, she boosts morale at large corporations; as a coach, she constantly challenges her players to reach their fullest potential as athletes and students, graduating each woman that she coaches at UT. Pat Summitt is a master motivator and terrific role model.

entry.category: Male High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description:
Cade Thompson's football career is defined by excellence. As quarterback for Maryville High School, Thompson led the Rebels to two state championships and two undefeated seasons. His personal statistics are impressive as well, with 374 career completions, 5,668 career passing yards, and 33 touchdown passes with only four interceptions in 2004. Thompson earned numerous distinctions including American General Class 4-A Mr. Football and Lawrenceburg Quarterback Club State Prep Player of the Year. Over the course of his career, he was named to All-Blount County, All-Region, and All-State All-Classification teams.

Thompson has signed with The University of South Carolina to play football for Coach Steve Spurrier.

Until someone else says "me too," Ginger Temple is Knoxville's only All-American in gymnastics.

Representing Southeastern Louisiana University, she was an All-American in floor exercise at the 1972 AIAW national tournament. A year later, she won national honors in the balance beam and uneven bars. After transferring to Southern Illinois University, Ginger and her team won national championships in 1974 and 1975. She was captain as a senior.

Ginger began competing in gymnastics at the Knoxville Y while a freshman at Central High. She stayed with the sport for more than two decades, coached Kansas teams to championships and founded the Knoxville Gymnastics Club. In 1989, she created Gymnastics Plus, a developmental program of tumbling and coordination skills that reached some 5,000 youngsters.

Ginger and her husband, Bill Baxter, live in Fountain City where they grew up and raised four children, Elizabeth, Jennifer, Joe and John. Ginger is managing partner for a real estate investment company. She is a director for Habitat for Humanity, is on the board of the Fountain City Art Center and has been a leader with Girl Scouts, PTA, the Knoxville Zoo and the Grand Teton National Park Foundation.

As good a shooter and defender as Bert Bertelkamp was in Tennessee basketball, the key word in describing his college career is "unselfish."

Three hundred and thirty-two times he made the Vols better by passing the ball to somebody else for a goal he might have scored.

Bertelkamp came from an All-State career at Bearden High to play in an interesting UT era, Ray Mears' final season, Cliff Wettig's one campaign and two seasons for coach Don DeVoe. He was a key man as Tennessee won the 1979 SEC tournament championship and the school's first NCAA victory. Bert helped the Vols win six of nine against Kentucky, go 6-2 against Alabama and 7-1 versus Vanderbilt. He set an NCAA record with 16 assists against Maryland.

Bertelkamp is many other things besides a former Volunteer. He is president of Bertelkamp Automation. He is basketball color analyst for the Vol radio network. He is chairman of Knox Youth Sports. And, he has a distinguished history with Big Brother/Big Sisters, YMCA and the United Way.

He is Sheila Bertelkamp's husband and father of Brownie, Lillie and young Hank. The family lives in Knoxville.

This classic overachiever broke his friend's middle-school mile record and got hooked on running. In his last three years at Central High, Tony Cosey didn't lose. When he heard that runners could earn money for college expenses, he really got serious. He sped on to All-American status at Tennessee, to the Sydney Olympics and on to a very profitable career as a professional steeplechaser.

There were running landmarks. In the 1993 SEC cross-country race, Tony took a tumble, scrambled to his feet, realized he was in last place and ran like crazy to finish fourth in a field of 90. His versatility as a Vol earned seven All-America certificates. His personal best in the steeple came when it mattered most, the 2000 Olympic Trials.

Cosey, 5-11 and 145, battled the big boys in main events. Some might say it was more with heart than wheels. He ran smart, invested his first check from adidas and soon applied his masters in management to become a financial advisor. That led to early retirement from the pro circuit.

Tony and Kathryn Cosey have two children, Taylor and Mason. He is owner and president of Cosey Financial Services. They are very active in church work.

This man has hall of fame experience.

Bud Ford, University of Tennessee Associate Athletics Director for Media Relations, was inducted into the College Sports Information Directors of America's Hall of Fame five years ago. This summer he received the distinguished Arch Ward Award for making an outstanding contribution to his professional field.

Ford, a UT graduate, has been with the university for more than four decades. While still a student, he signed on with the sports information department. He worked beside legendary director Haywood Harris for 35 years.

Ford was promoted to assistant athletics director in 1989 and to the associate athletics director in 2000. He directs an expanded staff of full-time and student employees in meeting the needs of media who cover the Volunteers. Based on Bud's ideas and management, 35 UT sports publications have been recognized as "best in the nation."

Others have recognized Bud's ability, dedication and loyalty. The UT Lettermen's T-Club elected him an honorary member.

Ford, a Knoxville native, is a graduate of West High. He and his wife, Sandra, reside in Halls. Son Brent is a UT graduate. Daughter Julie is a graduate of Carson-Newman.

The older he gets, the more races Bill Lauer wins.

This (retired) Navy commander and (retired) University of Tennessee engineering professor won four events in the 70-74 age group at the 10th World Masters swimming championships in Riccione, Italy. He was best in the 100 and 200 butterfly and 400 and 800 freestyle.

Bill Lauer went college swimming at Virginia Tech after four years in the Navy. In 1959, he placed fifth in three Southern Conference championship events but soon moved on to serious business, a masters at Iowa State and a teaching career at Ohio University and UT.

He returned to competitive swimming in 1973 and was a national contender at U.S. Masters events across the country. He went international at age 58 and placed in five events at the World Masters in Indianapolis. Ten years later, he did it again, in Christchurch, New Zealand, a mere warm-up for turning 70 and invading Italy.

He has officiated at international meets and is referee at UT competitions. In return for decades of swim leadership and 25 years of coaching youngsters, the Gulf Park pool is named for Bill Lauer.

Bill and his wife Gayle live in Knoxville.

Few have done more and given more in tennis.

Tommy Mozur, best in Tennessee tennis as a Sweetwater boy, grew up to be captain of the 1970 Volunteers, several times Southeastern Conference champion and All-American.

He played Wimbledon and the U.S. Open and once was locked into a record-setting Newport, Rhode Island, doubles match on grass that lasted six hours and 20 minutes. The Guinness Book of Records and Sports Illustrated joined in applause.

This tennis lifer played major tournaments for decades and was nationally ranked in each age group. He and Turner Howard III were a strong doubles team as 11-year-olds and were second in the country as 35-year-olds. Tom was USTA 55 doubles champ on clay in 2003.

Mozur was a tennis teaching pro in Tampa and St. Petersburg. He was director of tennis at the Knoxville Racquet Club for 12 years and general manager after that. He created a unique junior development program that has been widely copied. He is presently director of tennis at Beaver Brook Country Club.

Tom and his wife, Brenda, live in Knoxville. Their children are Kimberly Heagerty and Thomas Jr., who is a tennis coach at North Carolina State-Greensboro.

Forty-six years ago, Rabbit Grove conducted a first golf lesson for a bright, young woman at Oak Ridge Country Club. It was simple enough?Tina do this, Tina do that. No way could the pro have known that he was starting a fire.

Tina won the first tournament she entered, in Palm Beach, Florida. She played at the championship level when she lived in Seattle. She set the course record and was Fairwood club champ for six years.

In 1977, when she returned to East Tennessee, Tina won the Oak Ridge title. Three times she was runner-up for the Knox Area Women's Golf Association championship. She was Fox Den club champ five times and runner-up seven times. And, she regularly made the championship flight in the Tennessee Women's Amateur.

Tina became a leader at all levels of golf -- local, state and national. She has officiated at the USGA Women's Open, the Women's Amateur and NCAA championship matches. She endowed a scholarship for the Lady Vols.

Tina grew up in Greenback and attended UT, LSU-New Orleans and Green River Community College in Seattle. She completed an assortment of management courses during her 30-year career with The Boeing Company.

There are many spectacular landmarks in Bobby Scott's sports career. He was a prep star in three sports at Rossville, Georgia. He was quarterback for Doug Dickey's final Tennessee team, nine times a winner. And, he was quarterback of Bill Battle's first Tennessee team. It won 11 games, including a delightful romp over Coach Dickey's first Florida team.

Scott shot down the Air Force in the 1971 Sugar Bowl and was named most valuable player. He earned a very nice living, an NFL pension and considerable fame as Archie Manning's backup with the New Orleans Saints.

Incidentally, Scott did more than observe pro football. He started 11 games in 1976, completed more than half of his passes for more than a thousand yards and even ran for a touchdown or two!

After football, Scott worked in the construction industry in Chattanooga. He has been a sales rep with the Balfour Company since 1991. He was a factor in the recruitment of Peyton Manning to Tennessee.

Bobby and Pat Scott have two children, son Benson, a doctor in Chattanooga, and daughter Taylor, a student at UT.

Besides being a winning quarterback, Dewey Warren was one of the most colorful characters in Tennessee football history. His nickname, Swamp Rat, says a lot. He once went out to play without his helmet. And, he became the subject of a huddle song, "Come on Dewey, hum that tater."

He dreamed up the race between Richmond Flowers and a quarter horse. He was the star in the Vols' longest one-yard run, the play that beat UCLA in 1965. He passed for 1,716 yards as a junior, was MVP of two bowls and eighth in Heisman voting the year Gary Beban won.

Dewey took the first snap and completed the first pass for the Cincinnati Bengals. He played one season with the Las Vegas Cowboys, coached Tennessee freshmen for two years and created the passing tree that forever changed Brigham Young University football.

The Swamp Rat also coached at Kansas State, Copper Basin High, University of the South and Grundy County High -- in that illogical order. Since football, he has been a salesman and sports talk show host.

Dewey's daughters are Monica Warren and Angela Rayner. He has two grandsons. His money game is golf.

It has been said that Tony White exceeded expectations. At least a hundred college coaches miscalculated his basketball potential as a high school senior in Charlotte. Don DeVoe made the correct read. Once Tony arrived at Tennessee, there was no way to miss the talent show.

Tony twice led the Southeastern Conference in scoring. He was SEC player of the year in 1986-87. He scored 32 points in a victory over Kentucky. On one spectacular evening, he hit almost all his shots and scored 51against Auburn to take the school record from the legendary Ron Widby. At 6-2 and 170, White could do it all. He was Mr. Inside and Outside.

Perspective? White still ranks third in Tennessee career scoring. His 2,219 points put him behind Allan Houston and Ernie Grunfeld and ahead of Reggie Johnson and Dale Ellis. Three of White's four seasons were before the three-point shot.

White played briefly in the NBA with the Chicago Bulls, New York Knicks and Golden State Warriors and had a 10-year pro career in Europe. He made it back to Knoxville in time to see the emergence of another White scorer, son Tony Jr.

There is a wonderful difference in just doing something and doing something that matters. For 35 years, John Lee has mattered with the Boys and Girls Club. He has touched thousands of lives, provided rock-solid leadership and a clear vision for a better tomorrow.

John is President and CEO of Boys and Girls Clubs of the Tennessee Valley, an organization that has grown by leaps and bounds without losing the personal touch, from two clubs to 18 facilities with 8,800 members in six East Tennessee counties. The goal never changed during this rocket ride: youth welfare and development, offering children a chance for a changed life.

John has a collection of service medals and battle stars. With an eye on child safety, he led the charge for a law that requires a stop sign on the side of any bus loading or unloading precious passengers.

John Lee is a giant in his field and still the guy next door. He was born in Charleston, South Carolina, and is a graduate of Samford University. He is married to Phyllis and has three children, Amanda, Maria and Phillip. John enjoys the outdoors, especially hunting and golf.

Nobody, NOBODY, has done more volunteer work for the Boys and Girls Clubs of the Tennessee Valley than Buck Vaughn.

Three decades ago, this former paratrooper founded the D.D. Lewis Golf Tournament, which evolved into the Phillip Fulmer Classic, with youngsters as the beneficiaries. This event has raised more than $1 million for Boys and Girls Clubs.

Buck created this hall of fame in 1983. Annual induction dinners have raised more than $1.5 million for youngsters. He shared the leadership role for two major capital funds drives that generated more than $12 million. In return, he received pats on the back, thank-you plaques and "The Medallion," the highest national honor awarded by the Boys and Girls Clubs of America.

In his day job, Buck has been CEO of the Emmet Vaughn Lumber Company and a national leader in the hardwood industry. Some of his spare time has been devoted to Rotary, the Helen Ross McNabb mental health facility, Juvenile Diabetes Foundation, Interfaith Health Clinic and the Lady Vols. He has been everything from Sunday school teacher to trustee in the Methodist church.

Co-chairing the Vaughn family is wife Linda. The children are Suzanne, Melissa and Lee.

The Knoxville Open golf tournament has generated more than $2 million for Boys and Girls Clubs, and Sandy Hull deserves a large chunk of the credit.

Sandy has been a force behind the tournament since 1991. In the beginning, she was assistant to Jimmy Walls. For 11 years, she was tournament director. She also served as Vice President of Corporate Relations and Marketing at the Boys and Girls Clubs of the Tennessee Valley and recently accepted a job as the Executive Director of the Legacy Foundation, which was established by Knox County and the City of Knoxville to raise money for local parks and greenways.

As her career has centered on golf, so has her volunteer work. She is on the board of the Knox Area Junior Golf Association and the greens committee at Three Ridges golf course. She is a charter member and past president of the Knoxville chapter of the Executive Women's Golf Association. And, she was a member of the Leadership Knoxville Class of 2000.

Sandy is a native of Wichita, Kansas. She attended Wichita State on a volleyball and softball scholarship and earned a degree in physical education. She added a masters in education from the University of Kansas and a masters in marketing from Webster University.

Her athletic activities include running, golfing, snow skiing and bicycling. She recently ran her ninth marathon and qualified for the Boston Marathon.

If the world is really divided into givers and takers, Melvin Tate is up front among those who give. The pattern started early. After Nelson Merry High School, he enlisted in the U.S. Marines.

Later, armed with whistle and striped shirt, Melvin was a high school sports referee -- football, basketball and softball -- for a decade or more. He officiated college sports for 12 years.

He has been commissioner of the Baby Roadrunners Youth Football Organization for 25 years. He is a hands-on leader who plans activities and stays around to see that they are carried out successfully. His mission statement is "every child gets an opportunity."

The Greater Knoxville Sports Hall of Fame is not the first to notice that Melvin Tate is a giver. He has been recognized for distinguished community service by Kappa Alpha Psi fraternity, the East Tennessee chapter of the National Football Foundation and the NAACP.

Melvin and wife Mary live in Knoxville. They have seven children. He is retired from the Knoxville Utilities Board. Greater Knoxville Sports Hall of Fame member Raleigh Wynn describes Melvin Tate with two words: "Phenomenal man."

entry.category: Female High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description:
Since age nine, Meredith Anne Ayres has been bouncing out of bed at 5:30 a.m. to practice swimming. From the beginning, her parents took the position that they would support but not push. Supporting led to a lot of lost sleep.

Meredith became a year-round swimmer for Gardner Howland at Pilot Aquatic Club, practicing 25 hours per week. She skipped a lot of cookouts and slumber parties in favor of training. That is called dedication and determination.

At Webb, she was a 13-time high school All-American, a peer counselor and Wendy's nominee for the High School Heisman. As a senior, she was Tennessee's Swimmer of the Year and state champion in the 200 individual medley and 500 freestyle. She broke the state 200 IM record that was once the property of the legendary Tracey Caulkins.

Meredith's skills and academic grade-point average of 3.98 earned her a swim scholarship to Stanford University. Her college application essay was about a landmark event, the first time she qualified, at age 15, for the U.S. Senior Nationals. It was a beautiful use of 500 words.

Meredith is the daughter of Dr. Mike and Martha Ayres.

entry.category: Male High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description:
All-State honors in two sports earned Nick Reveiz the distinction of male athlete of the year in the Knoxville area and the spotlight at the 25th anniversary celebration of the Greater Knoxville Sports Hall of Fame.

Nick was twice state champion in wrestling and a very tough linebacker at 5-10 and 225. He's on his way to the University of Tennessee with the determination to be a football Volunteer. His father was one of distinction, kicker of many college and NFL field goals and extra points.

Nick Reveiz won an assortment of football honors while at Farragut High. He was All-Knoxville Football League, All-Region and All-State at the 5-A level. He was a finalist for Mr. Football recognition in Tennessee.

He was TSSAA wrestling champion in the 215-pound class as a junior and senior. His overall record was 115 victories and 10 defeats. This past winter, he went undefeated with 35 wins with 29 pins.

Nick will study business at UT. His high school grade point average was 3.6. His parents are Fuad and Gail Reveiz.

Big Zo Butler has a very large goal. He wants to be heavyweight boxing champion of the world. He has the size at 6-3 and 253, and he possesses exceptional athletic talent. His professional record is 22-0-1 with 17 knockouts. He already has the Mid-South title, and he is 1-0 on ESPN.

Zo's teacher and trainer is legendary boxing manager Ace Miller, commander in chief of Golden Gloves Arena in Chilhowee Park. You may recall that Big John Tate went from there to the world championship.

Zo's path to this point has not been easy street. He was born in Chattanooga and raised by his father in a notoriously tough neighborhood. Zo's big smile and All-City football and wrestling talent got him through Chattanooga City High without having to knock knots on too many heads.

Joe Smith of Chattanooga Westside Knockouts introduced Zo to boxing in 1997. Smith saw a basically good guy with great potential but no focus. He thought Ace Miller might solve that problem. After training with Miller, Big Zo, 26, is now considered one of the more promising heavyweights in the country.

University of Tennessee softball pitcher Monica Abbott ended her 2007 season leading the nation with a 50-5 overall record along with a 0.68 ERA and 29 solo shutouts in 358.1 innings. Over the course of the ESPN broadcast of the Women's College World Series, Monica became the face of the emerging Tennessee program.

A four-time NFCA All-American who holds NCAA Division I career records for wins (189), appearances (253), strikeouts (2,440), shutouts (112) and innings pitched (1448.0), Abbott established the single-season strikeout record with 724 during her senior year.

As the 2007 USA Softball National Collegiate Player of the Year, Abbott led the University of Tennessee Lady Vols to the program's first three Women's College World Series appearances, three straight top-three national finishes, the 2007 Southeastern Conference regular-season title and the 2006 SEC Tournament Championship. Abbott threw 23 no-hitters and six perfect games over her four years in the Orange and White. Additionally, she helped the Lady Vols achieve a sterling overall record of 246-51, the best of any four-year class in the school's softball history. She was the three-time Southeastern Conference Pitcher of the Year and a four-time All-SEC selection. She was chosen as the 2006-07 Roy F. Kramer Southeastern Conference Female Athlete of the Year.

Abbott came to UT from Salinas, California.

entry.category: Female High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description:
Angelo Puleo began her senior season at William Blount High School in Maryville by signing a national letter of intent to play basketball at the University of Georgia. In that senior season, she averaged 25.3 points per game, with nearly four assists and more than five rebounds.

Over the course of her career, she averaged 22.1 points per game and hit 80 percent of her free throws. She finished with 2650 points.

In 2007, she scored in double figures in all 27 games with a high of 46 against Alcoa, breaking her personal best mark of 43.

Angela was a Street and Smiths College Basketball Magazine honorable mention All-America selection, a Hoopgurlzs.com No. 40-ranked player, a Blue Star Report No. 49-ranked player and a McDonald's All-America Final 40 nominee. And, she was a TSWA All-State team selection in 2006 and 2007.

entry.category: Male High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description:
Fulton High School's Dennis Rogan was a two-time TSWA all state (2005-06) selection and MVP in the Falcons' 24-14 state championship win over David Lipscomb.

As a senior in 2006, he ran for 2,876 yards and 44 touchdowns. As a junior, he rushed for 2,261 yards and 39 touchdowns and caught 12 passes for 211 yards and two touchdowns, while adding 31 tackles on defensively. He is a member of the University of Tennessee's 2007 football signing class.

Dennis had back-to-back 200-yard rushing games to end his high school career and was named MVP of the state title victory game over David Lipscomb High School. He ranks second all-time in Tennessee with 19 consecutive 100-yard rushing games from 2005-06.

He was a member of The Tennessean's dream team and holds the TSSAA record for points scored in a season. Dennis is second in TSSAA state history in rushing touchdowns in a season (42) and total touchdowns (47) and fourth in TSSAA history in season rushing yards (2668) in 2006.

Cleveland, Ohio, native Anthony Hancock came to the University of Tennessee with plans of becoming a running back. However, he secured a position as wide receiver, and the position change apparently worked out well for him. He was part of the tradition of "Wide Receiver U" at Tennessee.

His best season at UT was in 1979 when he caught 34 passes for 687 yards and averaged 20.2-yards per reception. While at UT, Hancock became a four-year letterman in football and a three-year letterman in track.

In addition to his success on the football field, Hancock was a three time All-American hurdler and was the 1980 SEC Champion in the 60-yard high hurdles. Hancock played five years for the Kansas City Chiefs after being the 11th pick in the 1982 NFL draft.

After retiring from the NFL, he returned to Knoxville, where he currently resides. His business ventures led him to become a District Executive with the Boy Scouts of America, Marketing Consultant for UT's Center for Industrial Services, and educator at Whittle Springs Middle with Knox County Schools.

Hancock is married to the former Paula Lynn Bryant, and they have two daughters, Somer and Shauna, and two grandsons.

A 1953 graduate of Central High School, Barbara Bordinger was among the Knoxville area's top women golfers in the late 1950s and early-to-mid 1960s.

She reached the Knoxville Area Womens Golf Association finals eight times between 1957 and 1967, winning in 1957 and 1965.

She won the club championship at Deane Hill Country Club five times and was runner-up seven times between 1953 and 1970.

Golf wasn't the only sport at which she excelled.

Barbara won the Mid-South diving championship in 1950 and the Knoxville City diving championship from 1950 through 1953.

She had a hole-in-one on the always-tough No. 14 hole at Holston Hills Country Club in 1950.

She was married from 1953-1973 and has two children, Larry and Michelle Bordinger-Jackson, and 2 grandchildren, Morgan Leigh and Garett. Her son-in-law is Scott Jackson.

Chris Woodruff is in his third year as an assistant coach at UT, where he won the NCAA singles championship and was the No. 1-ranked player in college tennis as a sophomore (1992-93), a season in which he was honored as the SEC player of the year.

gWoodruff turned pro after his sophomore year. He was named the Association of Tennis Professionals (ATP) comeback player of the year in 1999 after missing the 1998 season with a knee injury.

During his professional career, Chris developed a reputation for outstanding work ethics and powerful ground strokes. He used these skills to win consistently and often on the ATP tour.

Chris gives back to the Knoxville community working with local charities. Over the years, he has brought Jim Courier, Todd Martin, and Taylor Dent to town to participate in tennis exhibitions for the Boys & Girls Clubs of the Tennessee Valley and Habitat for Humanity.

A 1953 graduate of Furman University, Dick Campbell has been successful wherever he has coached. He made a name for himself as a college, junior college and high school basketball coach from 1953 through 1991. His collegiate coaching stints included time at Carson-Newman, The Citadel, Xavier (Ohio) and Belmont.

He had a record of 110-13 from 1953-58 at North Greenville Junior College, now North Greenville University, in Tigerville, South Carolina, with trips to three national tournaments, three junior college All-America selections and a place in the North Greenville Hall of Fame.

Campbell went from there to Carson-Newman, where he was 227-63 from 1958-65, the latter year being named National Coach of the Year.

During his time in Jefferson City, he coached six All-America players and took his team to five National Tournaments, finishing third in one tournament. He is a member of the Carson-Newman Hall of Fame.

He was also at Halls and Carter High Schools in Knoxville.

Campbell is a member of the KIL Hall of Fame.

A three-time SEC coach of the year, Don DeVoe coached basketball at UT from 1979 through 1989. He led the Vols to five consecutive NCAA tournaments (1979-83) and nine post-season appearances in his 11 seasons. He recruited and coached both Dale Ellis and Tony White, two of the top scorers in school and SEC history.In his rookie season at Tennessee, the DeVoe-coached Vols bounced back from a 12-16 record in 1977-78 to defeat Kentucky three times and Vanderbilt twice. The Vols also won the SEC Tournament in its renewal after a lengthy absence.The Vols also defeated Eastern Kentucky for the school's first NCAA Tournament win in school history.

DeVoe, who played on Ohio State's NCAA Final Four runner-up team in 1962, was an assistant coach on Bobby Knight's Army staff before becoming head coach at Virginia Tech and at Wyoming. He then succeeded Ray Mears as UT's head coach.

DeVoe, who was 204-137 at UT, served as an interim coach for one season at Florida before finishing his career as head coach at the United States Naval Academy.

Don Labelle is a legendary name in the history of professional hockey in Knoxville and is one of the most popular players to grace the ice at the Civic Coliseum. He will be the first hockey player inducted into the Greater Knoxville Sports Hall of Fame.

Labelle was the first coach of the Knoxville Knights, coaching and playing defense from 1962 through 1964. The Knights finished second in their division three consecutive seasons and made the playoffs each year.

Labelle also played for the Knights in seasons from 1966-68, and coached the Knights again with no pay for a few weeks in 1967-68.

One of his best coaching jobs came in December of 1963, when he led the Knights in a 4-4 tie against the Soviet Union National Team with the USSR before a full house at the Coliseum. It was one of the most exciting games in Knoxville hockey history.

He remains active on his small farm and plays golf regularly. Don and his wife, Shelia, have two sons, Larry and Ray.

From 1981-84, Fuad Reveiz, a late 1981 University of Tennessee football signee, kicked field goals from all over the gridiron in Knoxville and elsewhere.

The legendary George Cafego, the Vols kicking coach, called him "Frank" only because he said he was too old to pronounce his given name. Only Cafego could have gotten away with that.

Fuad had a 60-yard field goal just before the half at Georgia Tech in the 1982 season, and, during his career, was a weapon from the time the Vols crossed their opponents' 40-yard line. He was no wisp of a kicker, like many of the breed. He was linebacker size 5-feet, 11-inches, 220 pounds.

Reveiz led the Vols in scoring from 1981 through 1984. He ranks behind only Jeff Hall and John Becksvoort in career scoring at UT.

He kicked 11 years in the NFL after his UT career, for Miami, San Diego and Minnesota. He was selected for the Pro Bowl after the 1994 season with the Vikings.

Reveiz finished his NFL career with 188 field goals and 367 extra points.

Most of Knoxville's best baseball players, including Todd Helton and Phil Garner, played for Jimmy O'Brien, who coached high school, city and county league baseball for 35 years.

He started coaching at Fountain City in 1956, and coached at Knoxville Catholic High School from 1961-1969, winning two distinct titles. He coached the city and county league and was awarded The Pap Dukes Award given by the City Bureau of Recreation in 1978.

During his career, his teams won more than 1000 games, while losing fewer than 300. His teams combined to win 22 city and county championships, 10 state championships and three regional titles.

His 1974 and 1975 Vulcan Materials teams finished second and third, respectively, in the Stan Musical World series in Battle Creek, Michigan. His Benco Plastics and Vulcan Materials teams of the 1970s dominated Stan Musical baseball in the city, county, and southeast.

Coaching along with Bob Polston, these teams only lost three league games in 10 years, won four state championships, two regional titles and appeared in two World Series. He coached girl's softball in the Gibbs community in the 1980s. These teams won three county championships and finished second twice in tournament play

O'Brien died in 1991.

Neal Ridley, owner of Knoxville's C&S Laundry, brought minor league baseball to Knoxville more than once. If anyone deserves credit for baseball being played over the years at Bill Meyer Stadium, it was Neal Ridley.

It all began in 1956, when Ridley was among the investors who helped bring a South Atlantic League team to Knoxville. He took over the team three years later.

The Smokies, as they were known in the early days, were first affiliated with the Baltimore Orioles, then with the Detroit Tigers in 1959, and had an exciting run that season to the pennant with Johnny Pesky as the manager.

The Tigers and New York Yankees played at Bill Meyer Stadium in 1963 on their way to opening day. Many of the Tigers who won the World Series in 1968 came through Knoxville on their way up.

After the team folded in 1967, Knoxville was without minor league baseball until 1972. Ridley then hooked up with Chicago White Sox owner Bill Veeck to bring a Southern League team to Knoxville. The K-sox won the Southern League championship in 1974 and 1978.

Ridley died in 1983. A year later, the playing surface at Bill Meyer Stadium was named in his honor.

Phil Hatcher has dedicated more than 40 years of service as a multi-sport official at a variety of levels. In 1963, he registered with the Tennessee Secondary School Athletic Association (TSSAA) and began a career that has included youth, recreation, high school and college athletics.

He was involved in the first committee meeting of the Knoxville Football Officials Association to adopt the crew concept. Phil was the first supervisor elected by the Knoxville Umpires' Baseball Association to assist in training officials.

He organized the first college softball officials association in this area, one still functioning today. In 1996, he was recognized by TSSAA as a recipient of its distinguished service recognition for officials. In 2006, Phil was inducted into the Knoxville Football Officials Association Hall of Fame.

Hatcher has umpired the JUCO World Series and officiated in the Ohio Valley and South Atlantic Conferences. He has worked the TSSAA state softball tournament five times and the state baseball tournament twice.

He played competitive softball for more than 40 years and was a five-time All-America selection.

entry.category: Female High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description:
Jenae Anderson showed promise as a track and field athlete early in life. As a nine-year-old, she set a national record, winning gold in the Junior Olympics 100-meter finals and silver in the 200-meters. In middle school, she was undefeated in the 100- and 200-meters.

As a high school athlete at Austin East Magnet High School, she won the state 100-meters three times, and the 200- and 400-meters two times each. She is the only athlete to win the 200-meters three consecutive years at the Volunteer Track Classic, the largest meet in the southeast.

During her senior year, she led her team to the TSSAA state track and field championship and was a member of Austin-East's state championship basketball team, which won 36 of 38 games.

Jenae graduated with a 3.96 grade point average and will attend Georgia Tech University on a track and field scholarship. She is the daughter of Sam and Jean Anderson.

entry.id: Summit, Pat and The Lady Vols
entry.description:
Winning never seems to get old for Pat Summitt's University of Tennessee Lady Vols basketball team. That was definitely the case when the national championship trophy headed back home to Knoxville for the first time since 1998, seventh time overall.

In the Final Four in Cleveland, Summitt's squad beat North Carolina in the NCAA semi-finals, 56-50, avenging a loss earlier in the season, then topped Rutgers in the championship game, 59-46.

The other Lady Vol championships came in 1987, 1989, 1991, 1996, and 1997. Summitt took the team to its first Final Four in 1977.

Summitt is the all-time winningest coach in NCAA basketball history, with 947 victories and only 180 losses (34-3 this season). By comparison, Bobby Knight has the most victories for a men's Division I coach, ringing up 889 wins.



In addition, the Lady Vols have made 26 consecutive appearances in the NCAA Sweet 16 and produced 12 Olympians. Summitt's teams have compiled a 100% graduation rate among all Lady Vols completing their eligibility.

Summitt's entire coaching career has been spent at Tennessee. Summitt graduated from Tennessee-Martin in 1974 and became coach of the Tennessee Lady Vols beginning with the 1974-75 season.

Knoxville's Chad Pennington, who prepped at Webb School of Knoxville, later led the Marshall Thundering Herd to a 13-0 record in 2000 and was a finalist for a Rhodes Scholarship, is one of the rising stars in the National Football League.

After making token appearances in his first two years with the New York Jets, Chad emerged as the Jets' starting quarterback in 2002 and currently owns the highest career passer rating and the highest completion percentage in team history.

He returned from injured reserve to be named NFL Comeback Player of the Year in 2006 after overcoming two rotator cuff injuries.

Chad and his wife, Robin, created the 1st and 10 Foundation to fund initiatives to better communities in West Virginia, Tennessee and the New York Metropolitan area. The Foundation raised more than $160,000 in 2006.

Chad and Robin have two children, Cole and Luke.

entry.category: Male High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description:
Anthony Anderson was a four-year starter for the Austin-East High School football team that compiled a record of 38 wins and 12 losses over that time.

He was an all-state selection in his junior and senior years. Anthony's career football statistics included 117 catches for 1,926 yards and 24 touchdowns as a wide receiver. He returned 16 kicks for touchdowns and had 22 interceptions, and his total yardage was more than 4,500 yards during his career.

Anthony was a three-year starter at point guard on the Austin-East basketball team that had an overall record of 81-17 and two state tournament appearances. A member of the track and field team, Anthony was a part of the 4x400 meter relay that was runner-up at the state championships last year.

Anthony was voted captain of both the football and the basketball teams his senior year, proving that character does count. He graduated with a 3.1 grade point average and will be attending the University of Tennessee on a football scholarship this fall. He is the son of Sam and Jean Anderson.

entry.category: Male High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description:
Maryville High's Tyler Maples knows something about winning, given he was on four TSSAA state championship teams during his high school career, in football from 2004-2006 and in basketball in 2006-07, giving credibility to the Maryville athletic program as one of the state's finest.

There's something more to be added to the Tyler Maples resume, however. Not only was he voted "Best Male Athlete" of his senior class, but he also had perfect school attendance for four years.

Maples won nearly every conceivable honor on the gridiron, leading to him accepting a football scholarship offer from the University of Tennessee. He was an all-state selection in football in 2005 and 2006 and was Mr. Football 4A Back of the Year, a Prep Nation All-America in football, PrepXtra Defensive Player of the Year, and Blount County football player of the year in 2006. He was also an all-district selection in basketball in 2006 and was an all-tournament team selection at the 2007 TSSAA state tournament.

entry.category: Male High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description:
West High School's Will Coley is a talented athlete, who combines athletic ability with superior performance in the classroom.

He did it all for the Rebels on the gridiron. He was an AP All-State linebacker who is headed to the United States Air Force Academy on a football scholarship. Captain of the 2007 Rebel squad, he was a first team PrepXTRA selection named by the Knoxville News Sentinel and was the unanimous Region 3 4-A Defensive Player of the Year.

He led the team in tackles in 2006 and 2007. Just to show his versatility, he was All-District in baseball in 2007.

Coley has been involved in giving back to his community through 5th Quarter, a West High School "Play It Smart" initiative that gives students an alternative, safe and drug-free place to hang out after football games. He has donated time to tornado relief projects, the Empty Stocking Fund, and Positively Living, a center for HIV/AIDS patients. He is a peer leader for the Fellowship of Christian Athletes, a 2007 state qualifier for the DECA Marketing Club, and as a member of the National Honor Society and "Play It Smart" Leadership Council.

entry.category: Male High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description:
The CAK athlete made a name for himself in prep soccer as a forward/midfielder, earning-first team All-State honors in 2005 and 2007 and adding first team All-Region and All-District honors in those years and in 2008.

The 2005 and 2007 CAK teams won state championships and was in the finals in 2008. He was Prep XTRA "Player of the Year" in 2005, ALL-KIL in 2005 and 2007, and All-PrepXTRA team in 2005 and 2007.

He was a member of the U-15 men's national soccer team in 2005 and on the U-17 men's national soccer team in 2006-2007. He was invited to attend the United States Soccer Residency Training Program from September 2005 through May 2006. He participated with U-15 and U-17 national and regional Olympic development program teams in Argentina, Mexico, Belgium, the Netherlands, England, Northern Ireland, and Wales. He was a two-time invitee to the prestigious adidas ESP Camp in 2006 and 2007.

He was affiliated with the Knoxville Futbol Club from 2001-2006 and the Tennessee Futbol Club from 2007-2008. He was on the Tennessee Division 1 State Champions in 2001 and 2008 and the Region III Premier League Championship team in 2007.

He is a 2008 signee of the University of South Carolina.

entry.category: Female High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description:
Jackie Coward has captured nearly every award a prep track athlete could imagine.

The graduate of Knoxville's West High School is an 8-time state champion in the TSSAA meet over the course of her career, winning the 100-meter hurdles, the 100-meters, the 200-meters, and the 400-meters, twice each.

She is the state record holder in the 100-meter hurdles and was the Tennessee State Gatorade Track Athlete of the Year in 2007. She won a bronze medal in the Pan-Am Junior Games in the 100-meter hurdles. She ran a U.S.-best time in the indoor 60-meter hurdles and won a bronze medal at the Pan-Am Junior Games in the 100 hurdles. She is the Nike indoor champion in the 60-meter hurdles.

Coward has maintained a B average in the classroom. In addition to donating her time to the Knoxville Track Club's Youth Athletic Program, she volunteers as part of multiple community service initiatives on behalf of her church. Coward is a member of an interpretative movement performance team at her church, and she was also a member of the Knoxville West High chorus.

She has signed to run track at Central Florida.

entry.category: Female High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description:
Glory Johnson, a 2008 Parade Magazine All-America selection, is a two-time Gatorade Player of the Year in Tennessee and Division II Miss Basketball (2007, 2008). She was a four-time All-State selection and the 2007 state tournament MVP.

She was a three-time All-Tournament team selection at the state tournament (2005, 2006, 2008) and was a four-time regional tournament MVP.

She was one of 24 players chosen for the USA Summer Basketball Program in 2007 and was also one of 24 players selected to play in the McDonald's All-Star Game March 26, 2008. She was one of 20 players tabbed for the WBCA High School All-American game, presented by Nike.

She was a two-time MVP of the Greene County Bank Classic Christmas Tournament, with her team winning the team crown in 2006 and 2007.

She is also a two time state champion in track in the long jump in 2006 and 2007, and was also state champion in the 100 and 200.
