At Webb, her teams finished 102-25. Johnson holds school records with 2239 points, 1375 rebounds, 387 steals, and 219 blocks. The 2007 state championship was the first in school history.

She has signed to play collegiate basketball at the University of Tennessee.

During his three years at Tennessee (2000-2002), Jason went from being a defensive end prospect to a tight end defenders would prefer not to deal with. He had six catches for 125 yards and one score, coming on a 64-yard reception from Casey Clausen in the 2002 Florida Citrus Bowl game against Michigan.

Jason has been a starting tight end for the Dallas Cowboys since 2003, setting a single season receptions mark with 96 catches in 2007. He is also the first Dallas tight end ever to gain more than 1,000 receiving yards in a season.

Jason was one of the NFL record 13 Cowboys players selected to the 2008 Pro Bowl. He has been selected for the Pro Bowl four years in a row.

Jason is very active in his foundation SCORE, providing support to families and individuals affected by domestic violence. Each year, Jason still gets back to Elizabethton, where he hosts a yearly free football camp with more than 2,000 children attend.

In the midst of all this, Jason is very much a family man and always seems to find time for his wife, Michelle, and their sons C.J. and Cooper. They reside in Southlake, Texas.

He came to the University of Tennessee wanting to be a linebacker, but ended up as an offensive guard, seeing Steve Kiner, Jack Reynolds, fellow inductee Jackie Walker and others on the way. He was an alternate captain of the 1971 team, and then began the assistant coaching journey that led him to Wichita State, Vanderbilt, and finally home to Knoxville in 1980.

In November 1992, he was named head coach at Tennessee, after serving as interim head coach earlier that season. The dean of Southeastern Conference coaches, Fulmer has claimed a national championship, two conference titles, and seven divisional crowns while winning better than three-quarters of his games. He also tops the winning percentage list for coaches with at least 10 years experience in major college football.

And while his on-field accomplishments -- such as advancing the Vols to the 2007 SEC Championship Game and claiming 10 wins for the ninth time in 15 full seasons -- have obvious allure, it's the personal relationships that register most sincerely for Tennessee's native son.

Fulmer's most cherished responsibility centers around the teaching and guidance of young student-athletes. He has built Tennessee football on a platform of "Family First" -- considered the program's greatest attribute.

Mack Gentry not only played football at the University of Tennessee, but went on from there to become an SEC football official. He lettered at Tennessee as a defensive tackle from 1964-66 and was present and voting when Vol defenders stopped LSU four times near the Vol goal in the 1964 season to preserve a 3-3 tie.

He was an Academic All-America and Academic All-SEC selection in 1965. He was the 1966 Knoxville Journal Scholastic Award Winner and was president of the University of Tennessee Letterman's club in 1965-66.

He earned a bachelor of science degree in accounting from the University of Tennessee (1966), a doctor of jurisprudence from the University of Tennessee College of Law (1968), and a master of law, taxation, from New York University (1976).

After a stint at the United States Military Academy from 1969-72, he was part of the Knoxville Football Officials Association (KFOA) from 1972-80 and 1999-2005 and was part of the Southeastern Conference Football Officials Association (SECFOA) (1979-1997), was Chief of Referees (1988-1990), and on the Executive Committee of SECFOA (1990-1992). He officiated in the Alamo, Fiesta, Freedom, Gator, Holiday, Rose, and Independence Bowls. He also worked the 1991 Kickoff Classic and the 1993 SEC Championship.

He is now a Knoxville attorney.

As a youngster, Drew "Buddy" Gilbert was batboy for the Knoxville Smokies of the Tri-State League. He was a standout four-sport star athlete at Knoxville's Central High, where he was an All-County end in football, a center/forward in basketball, an All-City and All-County selection in baseball as a catcher, outfielder, pitcher, and first baseman, and as a high hurdler on the track team.

Gilbert had a sensational debut in pro ball, batting .335 for Douglas (Ga.) in 1954, leading the circuit in runs (134), hits (173), and total bases (275). Promoted to Ogden (Utah) in 1955, Gilbert continued his outstanding play, batting .300, hitting 15 home runs and coaxing 97 walks. He was selected as the league's "best major league prospect."

He moved to Savannah in 1956, connected for 13 homers and drew 81 bases on balls. He continued his pro career with stops at Nashville (1958-59), in the big leagues at Cincinnati (1959), and stops at Seattle, Indianapolis, and Nashville to conclude his baseball career.

He worked in mortgage banking from September 1961 to spring of 1983. He started Eagle Realty Corporation late spring of 1983 and is president and owner. He has also developed four single-family subdivisions.

All Ricky Gregg, a graduate of Young High School and the University of Tennessee, did during his golf career was win. He won more than 50 golf tournaments, from his early days as a junior golfer, through his amateur career, at the University of Tennessee, and through his time as a professional.

He was Knoxville City Junior Tournament winner three times and won the Bays Mountain Men's Club Championship five times, the first at age 13. He won the District High School championship four years and played in the United State Junior Championship. He won the Knoxville Open Amateur Division twice and the Knoxville City Men's Championship and Southern Appalachian Match Play three times each.

He won the Knox County Amateur Champion four times and the Knoxville Green Turf three times. He won the Amateur Division in the State PGA twice.

At Tennessee, he played No. 1 each of his four years. He was twice team captain and a three-time team MVP. He was twice selected All-SEC. He is the only Tennessee golfer chosen to play in NCAA Championship individually three times.

He is currently Director of National Accounts for Eljer Plumbing Company. His wife is Kim, and they have two children, Kristin, 23, and Morgan, 21.

Ron McCartney joined a long line of West Virginians who have made it big at the University of Tennessee, notably Dick Huffman, Bob Davis, Abe and Pat Shires, Sam Bartholomew, and George Cafego, when he arrived in Knoxville in 1972. He was a three-sport star at Stonewall Jackson High School in Charleston, also playing basketball and being the state runner-up in the discus, with a school-record mark of 172'-4".

Playing defensive end, he lettered from 1973-75 and served as team captain in his senior season. He was an All-SEC selection in 1975 and won the Simpson Theatres Award that season as the team's outstanding lineman. He played in the 1976 College All-Star, East-West All-Star and Coaches All-American Games.

He was a second round draft pick of the Los Angeles Rams and played in Los Angeles on a Western Division championship team in 1976 and in Atlanta 1977-79. He played in 45 games for the Falcons and in the 1979 Pro Bowl.

During the offseason, he helped to start Sports World Ministries in 1978, a ministry alive and well today of pro athletes ministering to high school students. After retiring in 1980, he finished his master's degree from Tennessee and made Knoxville home.

Tim Priest was part of the "glory days" of Tennessee football in the mid-to-late 1960s and early 1970s, playing on teams that compiled a record of 28-5-1 and won the SEC title in 1969.

He came to Tennessee as an All-State quarterback from Huntingdon. When he and fellow freshman Joe Thompson arrived in 1967 and saw teammates Bobby Scott and Jim Maxwell throwing the football, he told Thompson, "We'd better find another position."

Find another position he did. He was a three-year starter in the secondary. He was team captain and earned All-SEC honors in his senior season of 1970. He was the leader in the secondary on a defense that set a school record with 36 interceptions and caused an NCAA record 57 turnovers. In addition, he earned Academic All-SEC honors each of his three years on campus and was an Academic All-America selection in 1970.

Nearly 40 years after his final game as a Vol, Priest still holds the Tennessee interception record, with 18 picks for 305 yards and one score.

He is now a Knoxville attorney, who co-hosted "Football Finals" on Knoxville radio station WIVK from 1975-98, and is now color analyst on the Vol Network.

Sevier Countian Lisa McGill, now Lisa McGill Reagan, played on Lady Vol basketball teams that compiled a 74-25 win/loss record and finished third in the nation twice 1976-77 and 1978-79, over the course of her career.

As a member of the Lady Vol swim team, she competed in the butterfly and freestyle and finished twelfth in the region in the 200 freestyle.

She was named 2000 University of Tennessee Bell South Entrepreneur of the Year and competed in the 2003 Tennessee State Racquetball Championships, finishing in second place in singles and doubles. In 2005, she was inducted into the Sevier County Athletic Hall of Fame.

She co-owns Brookside Resort with husband Beville Reagan. She is vice-president of Reagan's Brookside LLC. She is a member of the National Tour Association (NTA), American Bus Association (ABA), Pennsylvania Bus Association, and Travel South. She was awarded the Environmental Design Award for Landscaping Design Excellence in 1986. The Reagans have approximately 45-50 employees in the regular season and approximately 20-25 in the off-season.

The Reagans live in Gatlinburg and attend First Baptist Church. She holds a bachelor of science degree in education with a minor in physical science. She, Bridgette Gordon, and Daedra Charles started The Pat Summitt Scholarship.

Running had to have been in Coppley Vickers' blood. He won his first competitive race as a Fulton High School junior in a dual meet at Baylor, defeating the Mid-South mile champion with time of 4:36, two seconds over the state high school record.

In his senior season, he was not only regional mile and half-mile champion, but was also Tennessee state mile champion. In the half-mile, he broke the state record, while coming in second. He finished third in the Tennessee State Decathlon and was champion in the mile in the Chattanooga Invitational Indoor Meet. That year, he was also named All-City in basketball under Bob Fry.

At Furman, he won the 1961 Southern Conference cross-country championship and was the 1962 Southern Conference 2-mile champion, and was the second-place finisher in 1963 in Southern Conference cross-county competition.

At the University of Tennessee, he was SEC 1-mile runner-up and 2-mile champion in 1964. In 1965, he was SEC indoor 1- and 2-mile champion. He also earned a bachelor's degree that year.

He was an accomplished Marine Corps runner and tri-athlete from 1966-68.

He earned a law degree from UT after his return from Vietnam (1972) and practices law in commercial transactions in Sevierville.

Jackie Walker was a man of his word, even the night before the 1969 Alabama game. Then a sophomore, Walker told linebackers coach Lon Herzbrun's wife, Wilma, that he would score a touchdown for her the next day in honor of her birthday. He did, taking a fumbled pitchout in for a score.

Walker, who prepped at Fulton High School, had a distinguished career at the University of Tennessee, twice earning All-America and All-SEC honors as a linebacker and becoming captain of the 1971 team. Walker intercepted 11 passes and took five in for scores, the latter a modern NCAA record that has lasted 37 years.

He was a speech and drama major in college, appearing in the production of "Fiddler on the Roof," cast as Russian student "Sasha," dancing and singing a short solo. He also was a member of the Fellowship of Christian Athletes and was invited to sing at a conference in Florida his senior year.

Following a brief time with professional football, he relocated to Atlanta in 1972.

He completed his undergraduate degree in 1982 at Georgia State University in Atlanta. After working with Sprint and AT&T in Atlanta, Ga. Jackie retired in 1998.

He died Dec. 5, 2002.

The Durham, North Carolina native joins his father, John Wylie, Class of 2002, as a member of the Greater Knoxville Sports Hall of Fame.

As a junior golfer, Randy won the 1982 Tennessee PGA Junior Championship, the 1983 Tennessee Father-Son championship, and played in the USGA junior championship and the national PGA junior championship.

At Texas A&M, he played four years and led Texas A&M to the Southwestern Conference Championship in 1987. Following that win, the Aggies played in the 1987 NCAA Championship.

He developed his teaching skills via extensive work with top golf instructors Rick Smith and David Leadbetter.

He was U.T. Men's assistant golf coach from 2000-2001. He played professionally on the Asian, Canadian, South African, and Jordan golf tours. He played in four PGA Tour events. The highlights of his playing career include playing 72 holes in both the 1990 U.S. Open at Medinah and the 1997 U.S. Open at Congressional.

He was "Knoxville PGA Teacher of the Year" in 2005. He won the Knoxville PGA Chapter Championship in 2006. He was named one of Golf Digest's Top Ten Teachers in Tennessee 2001 through 2008. He is currently a PGA golf instructor and coach at Fairways and Greens in Knoxville and, from 2002 forward, he has been a volunteer coach for the UT men's golf team.

He is married to the former Jennifer Schneider.

entry.category: Female High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description:
Kayla Christopher, who graduated third in her class at Oliver Springs High School with a 3.95 GPA and has signed basketball scholarship papers with the University of Tennessee, Chattanooga, has distinguished herself in the classroom and on the court."

A winner of the 2006-2008 TSSAA Academic Achievement Award and Beta Club member, she was named to "Who's Who in American High School Students." She has been involved with the "Coats for the Cold" project, providing winter coats for the needy and has worked in "Operation Reach," a program for indigent children in Roane County."

In 2008-09, she was All-District and District Tournament MVP, Class A Miss Basketball Finalist, and nominated for McDonalds All-American Team. She was also on the school's first soccer team and earned All-District honors in 2007 and All-Region honors in 2008."

She was often chosen by the faculty of Oliver Springs High School as a role model for younger students. She is very active and committed to her church youth group. She is an active member of P3, a program designed to influence youth with Positive Peer Pressure, especially in the areas of being drug and alcohol free.

entry.category: Female High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description:
Faith Dupree of the Webb School of Knoxville had big shoes to follow, those of Glory Johnson, the Greater Knoxville Sports Hall of Fame's Female Athlete of the Year in 2008, and not only did so, but did so admirably.

Dupree, who signed basketball scholarship papers with the University of Tennessee Lady Vols for 2009-10, finished her high school career with 1,820 points, 861 rebounds, 260 blocks, 210 assists, and 178 steals, while playing on teams at Anderson County (2005-06) and Webb (2006-09) that complied a record of 106 wins and 21 losses.

In 2009, she was a WBCA All-American Honorable Mention and McDonalds All-American Honorable Mention. She was Tennessee Gatorade Player of the Year and "Miss Basketball" for Division II.

She was a three-time All-State selection. She was TSSAA State Tournament and Region MVP in 2009. Region coaches voted Dupree "Player of the Year." She was named KIL Player of the Year by the coaches, and the Knoxville News Sentinel named her PrepXtra Player of the Year.

She was KIL sophomore of the Year 2007, was first team at the Green County Bank Classic All-Tournament 2007, and was first team Naples All-Tournament Team in 2008.

entry.category: Male High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description:
Fulton High School's James Gallman left his mark on the Fulton Falcon basketball program, finishing a distinguished prep career in 2008-09 when the Falcons won their second consecutive TSSAA state championship.

Described as an athletic lead guard who can finish at the rim or penetrate and kick it to an open teammate, Gallman proved to be a tremendous ball defender.

He finished his high school career as the second leading scorer in Fulton history, etching his name among the greats who have played at the North Knoxville school.

His statistics are mind-boggling, reflecting his love for the game and his abilities on the court.

He was All-District selection four years and All-Region for three. He was the 2007 PrepXtra Sophomore of the Year, the 2008 PrepXtra Player of the Year, District Player of the Year, and All-State selection. He was a 2009 PrepXtra first team selection.

He was named to the All-State Tournament team in 2008 and in 2009. In 2009, he was also named honorable mention on the McDonald's All-American Team.

He was the MVP in the 2009 Tennessee East-West All-Star game.

Gallman signed basketball scholarship papers with Middle Tennessee State University, as announced April 16, 2009. His future coach, Kermit Davis, says, "James Gallman is all about winning."

entry.category: Male High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description:
Caleb Leonard, headed to the United States Air Force Academy on a football scholarship, now takes his place as one of the great athletes produced by Halls High School. He did it all for the Red Devils in three sports throughout his prep career.

In football, he is a two-time All-State selection, Region 3-4 Linemen of the Year, First Team All-PepXtra, and First Team All-KIL. He was also two-time first team All-Region 3-4A.

He played in the Toyota East-West All Star Game and was on the 2008 Nashville Tennessee Dream Team.

In wrestling, he was 2009 State Champion, with a record of 50-0, the first wrestler to go undefeated in school history. Leonard won the state championship in the 285-pound division. In a dramatic match that went into overtime, Leonard was able to get a takedown to defeat Adam Peters of Cleveland, 4-2.

He was a three-time First Team All PrepXtra selection, First Team All-KIL, and state medalist. He was a two-time Region 2 Champion.

He was a four-year Honor Roll selection, wrestling team captain for two years, lettering in wrestling four years and three years in football. He also lettered three years in track.

Knoxville Webb's Chad Pennington was named 2008 NFL Comeback Player of the Year and finished second in MVP voting behind Peyton Manning.

Chad signed a two-year contract with the Miami Dolphins on August 9, 2008, and started every game of the season. He helped lead the Dolphins to their first division title since 2000.

Chad was a first-round draft choice of the New York Jets in the 2000 draft. He was the 18th overall pick and the first quarterback chosen that year.

Named the Associated Press 2006 Comeback Player of the Year, Chad recovered from not one, but two rotator surgeries, to play in each of the New York Jets' 16 games that season, including a playoff appearance.

A Heisman Trophy finalist in 1999, Chad led Marshall University to a perfect 13-0 season. Chad was also a Rhodes Scholar finalist. Chad was a GTE/CoSIDA Academic All-America first-team pick, and a two-time recipient of the Anson Mount Award.

In addition to the 1st and 10 Foundation he and his wife started in 2003, Chad is also active in the United Way program. He hosts a football camp in Knoxville each summer.

Chad and his wife, Robin, have three sons, Cole, Luke and Gage.

After being an All-State selection in football at Covington (Tenn.) High School, John Cook signed a football scholarship with the University of Tennessee in 1945 at age 17.

After he turned 18, he enlisted in WWII and served two and half years in the Navy. He signed with Southern Methodist University coming out of service and played on some great teams there with Doak Walker. Later, Mr. Cook attended U.T. and received his master's.

Mr. Cook went to work for General Motors in 1953, after marrying Harriett Callaway. Frank Callaway offered him a job at the Athletic House where he began selling socks and jackets and worked with area coaches and administrators for more than 50 years.

He was on the original boards of the Knoxville Track Club and Cedar Bluff Farragut Optimist Club.

Mr. Cook was chairman of the National Sporting Goods Association in the early 1980s.

Mr. Cook is a very caring and giving person who helped many people along the way. He takes care of his handicapped daughter Carry Cook, as well as many other special needs individuals. He's been very involved with the Sertoma Center and Sequoyah Presbyterian Church.

He and Harriett have four grown children and nine grandchildren.

Pat Summitt, head coach of the University of Tennessee Lady Vols, is the winningest basketball coach, man or woman, in NCAA history.

Her teams have won eight national titles since she began coaching the Lady Vols in 1974, 1987, 1989, 1991, 1996, 1997, 1998, 2007, and 2008.

On February 5, 2009, Summitt became the first coach (man or woman) in NCAA history to record 1000 wins as a head coach with a 74-44 win over Georgia at Thompson-Boling Arena. Her record heading into 2009-10 is 1005-193 (.839).

Summitt grew up on a Tennessee farm in Cheatham County and played basketball throughout high school and college. She graduated from University of Tennessee-Martin in 1974, the same year she was hired as the head coach at Tennessee, a position she's held ever since.

She played on the US Women's Olympic team in 1976 and won a gold medal as coach of the 1984 Women's Olympic squad.

Summitt is famous for her fierce intensity, signature icy stare, and her success in turning Tennessee into a national power. She won her 880th game March 22, 2005, surpassing North Carolina's Dean Smith to become the NCAA's alltime wins leader.

She was inducted into the Women's Basketball Hall of Fame in 1999 and into the Basketball Hall of Fame in 2000.

Valerie Bachmann, a 1991 honors graduate of the University of Tennessee with a degree in business administration, ran track and cross-country for 1986-1990. She was a track and field All-America in 1988, 1989, and 1990 in the 800 meters and 3200-meter relay. In 1990, she placed sixth at the NCAA championships in 800 meters in a time of 2:04.

She earned 1989 Cross Country All-America honors by running a personal record of 17:27 over 5 kilometers and was member of a team that placed sixth in the country. She earned the "Most Improved Team Award" for cross-country in 1989. She was the 1990 SEC champion for indoor track in the 800 meters and was on All-SEC cross-country team in 1990.

She also earned Academic All-SEC honors in 1989. She was a 2004 honors graduate from the University of Tennessee with a master's degree in curriculum and instruction.

She has taught second grade the last three years at Maynard School and has been head of the Hospitality and Wellness Committees.

She and husband, Jay, have been married since 1993 and have two children, Kenton, 9, and Ellie, 6. They are members of Peace Lutheran Church. She leads the Witnessing and Welcoming Committee.

Harry A. "Cotton" Berrier, is a graduate of Central High School, where he was a member of their first golf team. Cotton joined the Air Force and served thirty months in Japan during the Korean War. He was a member of the base golf team.

Upon his discharge, he returned to Knoxville for a brief stint at U.T., but when the opportunity to go to work as an assistant at Oak Ridge Country Club presented itself, he was off and running and never looked back.

Cotton, whose nickname comes from the fact that his hair was almost white as a child, grew up near Whittle Springs Municipal Golf Course in Knoxville. He and his brothers caddied there as kids, and he helped in the pro shop when his friend "Rabbit" Grove ran the operation.

In 1955, Berrier was hired as the first golf professional at the newly opened Gatlinburg Golf Course, where he remained until he retired as director of golf in 1999.

Berrier and his wife, Sarah Rudolph, are the parents of two daughters: Harriet, principal at Sevierville Primary School, and Katherine, an employee of the FootJoy Company. She and her husband, Chris Everett, a pilot, live in Nashville.

A 1972 graduate of Knoxville's South High School, Craig Colquitt not only became a three-year letterman as the punter for the University of Tennessee, but also went on to a 7-year career with trips to Super Bowl XIII and XIV.

Colquitt walked on in 1974 and punted from 1975-77. He is fourth on the career-punting list, with 204 punts for a 42.4-yard average.

What do the top four punters in Tennessee have in common? Each of them is named Colquitt. His nephew, Jimmy, is No. 1 with a 43.9-yard average, younger son Britton is No. 2 with a 42.6-yard average, and son Dustin is third, also with a 42.6-yard average.

In 1978, the Pittsburgh Steelers drafted Craig in the third round. He not only punted, but also held for placekicks as well. Just to show the passage of time, Craig's ball boy with the Steelers, Todd Haley, is now Dustin's head coach with the Kansas City Chiefs.

He has been with GCA Services Group, a private custodial company that cleans schools, since 1995.

He and his wife of 29 years, Anne, are parents of two former Vol punters, Dustin, 27, and Britton, 24.

A native of Beckley, West Virginia, Ted Cook, Sr., was an All-State basketball player in 1939. He was also West Virginia Marbles Champion in 1936. He was one of a number of West Virginia natives to make it big at Tennessee. He was a favorite of the crowds in his days at Alumni Gym with his all-out effort and hustle.

During his basketball career at Tennessee under John Mauer, he was known as a "defensive stopper," holding Vandy's Dave Scobey and LSU's Frank Bryant well below their averages and shutting out Kentucky's Milt Ticco as the Vols won the post-season tourney in 1943. Very few players, in and out of the SEC, relished going up against him.

Cook was named to the 1943 All-SEC Tournament Team and, after a stint in World War II, was co-captain of the 1946-47 Tennessee basketball squad.

He was captain of the Tennessee golf team in 1947.

He played professionally for the Minneapolis Lakers in 1948, then served in the Korean War. He was assistant golf coach at Tennessee from 1957-1964.

In his business career, he opened Toddy's Liquor Store in 1962 and Toddy's Backdoor Tavern in 1983.

He died May 19, 1990, at age 69.

A Knoxville native and 1958 Austin High graduate, John Dean retired as head football coach and athletic director of Detroit Northern High School after serving 32 years.

He holds a bachelor's degree from Knoxville College (1962) and master's from the University of Michigan (1968).

He played football and basketball at Austin High School and football at Knoxville College. He was a co-captain of the Austin football squad in his senior season.

During his tenure at Northern, his team's record was 191-99-1. His accomplishments included 15 Public School League Championship appearances, five PSL Finals, one PSL Championship, and two State playoffs.

He was Detroit Public Schools "Coach of the Year" in 1978. He was Michigan Football Regional Coach of the Year in 1984 and 1989. He received Eastern Michigan University's Lifetime Achievement Award in 1998.

He has worked football camps around the state of Michigan and speaks at football clinics for Michigan youth and high school coaches.

Dean was the first African-American president of the Michigan High School Football Coaches Association and was inducted into the Michigan High School Football Coaches Hall of Fame in 1995.

He and his wife, Norma, have two children, daughter, Kelly and son, Erik.

A 1967 graduate of Knoxville's Central High School, John Heatherly was head baseball coach at Farragut High School from 1980-1993, compiling a 232-84 (.724) record. Under his tenure, the Admirals won 8 District Championships and 3 Regional Championships. Farragut won the 1982 State Championship and was runner-up in 1988.

He was an 8-time District Coach of the Year, AAA Coach of the Year, State of Tennessee in 1982, Knoxville Interscholastic League Coach of the Year in 1987, Knoxville Area Baseball Coaches Association Coach of the Year in 1982 and 1988, and Head Coach, Sportsfest Gold Medal Team in 1992.

He was an inductee into the East Tennessee Baseball Coaches Association Hall of Fame in 1997 and an inductee into the Tennessee Baseball Coaches Association Hall of Fame in 1998.

The Farragut High School baseball field was named in his honor in 2002. Thirty-three (33) of his players received college scholarships, with four playing professional baseball.

He is a lifelong member of Central Baptist Church of Fountain City and a member of the Fountain City Lions Club.

He and wife, Nancy, have been married since 1969. Their children are John A. Heatherly, III, and his wife, Devereux, Oklahoma City, and Cynthia A. Heatherly, Brentwood, Tennessee.

Now in her 32nd year at the helm of the Media Relations Office, Debby Jennings is the first and only Director of Media Relations for the University of Tennessee Lady Vols. Since 1977, Jennings has built the department into one of the nation's best, producing outstanding work while helping train aspiring students of the profession.

In the summer of 2008, she won the Arch Ward Award from the College Sports Information Directors of America (CoSIDA), becoming only the second woman to receive the award that honors outstanding contributions to the field of college sports information, along with bringing dignity and prestige to the profession.

Under her leadership, the Lady Vol media relations staff has accumulated almost 400 national publication awards, with more than half representing "Best in the Nation" distinction.

She is the author of "The University of Tennessee Basketball Vault: The History of Lady Vols Basketball." She also coauthored "Basketball with Lady Vol Basketball Coach Pat Summitt" and "Lady Magic: The Nancy Lieberman-Cline Story."

Jennings directed publicity and media relations for the 1990 NCAA Final Four hosted by UT. She has also served a two-year stint as the president of the Southeastern Conference sports information directors.

In 2008, the UT Letterman's Club selected her as an honorary member.

Born in San Diego, Calif., Aug. 16, 1925, Al Neil had a successful career in youth sports before joining the Navy at age 17. In 1947, after being honorably discharged, he played professional baseball with the minor league affiliates of the St. Louis Cardinals, Philadelphia Phillies, Cleveland Indians, and New York Giants, playing through 1956.

During his professional career, he was a four-time All Star, a three-time league Most Valuable Player. He won two batting titles and was twice voted the Most Popular Player. He played in 1,075 games, with a lifetime batting average of .318, 255 home runs and 1,184 RBIs.

Neil played with the Knoxville Smokies on two occasions, in 1950 and 1954. After his professional baseball career ended, he coached more than 17 years in the Knoxville community.

Al has received numerous professional awards and has belonged to numerous social and community organizations. Al and wife, Jean Bailey Neil, have been married for 58 years. He is the proud father of a daughter, Carol Raxter, and two sons, Scott and Russ. He is also the grandfather of Richard Neil, James Raxter, Issac Neil, and Elliott Raxter, and is the great-grandfather to Scotty Neil.

Pat Ryan came to the University of Tennessee from Oklahoma City in the recruiting class of 1973, lettering in his senior season of 1977.

He played professionally for the New York Jets from 1978-89 and the Philadelphia Eagles in 1991.

Ryan's career in New York, although overshadowed at times, was nothing short of inspiring. He left the Big Apple after 11 seasons of grooming younger promising quarterbacks and being ready when called upon.

"Pat is one of the premier backup quarterbacks in the NFL," said former Jets head coach Joe Walton in 1989. "He is always prepared at a moment's notice to come into a game and execute the game plan flawlessly."

From 1999-2004, Ryan served as an analyst with Mike Keith on the Tennessee Titans Radio Network. His most memorable moment came with the "Music City Miracle," the decisive play in an AFC Wildcard Game between the Titans and Buffalo Bills Jan. 8, 2000.

In more recent years, he has worked as an analyst on delayed and pay-per-view telecasts of Tennessee football.

He and his wife, Debra, have two children, Caitlin, 23, a former Lady Vol softball player now in graduate school at Tennessee, and Jake, 19, a student-athlete at Austin Peay.

Born in Mexico City in 1957, Phil Savage started gymnastics in 1965, beginning elite gymnastics in 1971. He earned a full gymnastics scholarship to Southern Illinois University in 1975 and graduated in 1980 with a bachelor of fine arts degree.

He moved to Knoxville that year and bought the Knoxville Gymnastics Club in 1982. He started Knoxville's first cheerleading tumbling program in 1984. He built and started Knoxville Gymnastics Training Center in 1983. Between 1990 and 1994, he and wife, Lisa, led the way to build a 32,000 sq. ft. building on Western Avenue.

They developed Knoxville's first Special Olympics for gymnastics in 1990 and the first gymnastics scholarship program with Knoxville's Community and Development Corporation from 1990-2000. They partnered with the Knoxville Sports Corporation in presenting the 1992 Women's U.S. Classic, a qualifier to the Olympic Trials.

In 2006, he was the first coach inducted into the Tennessee Gymnastics Hall of Fame. He speaks to gymnastic groups on motivating children and teachers.

He is in the Guinness Book of World Records for the 1-mile handstand walk, 4-man relay, in 1987.

He married Lisa Avril in 1984. They have three children, Ben 21, Morgan, 18, and Austin, 15, celebrating their 25th anniversary in August.

A native of Powell and a 2009 inductee to the College Football Hall of Fame, John Cooper is the second most successful coach in OSU history, trailing only the legendary Woody Hayes. Cooper also has the third longest coaching tenure in Ohio State annals - behind Hayes and John W. Wilce (16).

He compiled a record of 111-43-4 in 13 years as head coach of the Buckeyes and compiled an overall head coaching record of 192-84-6.

Prior to coming to Ohio State, Cooper coached for eight years at Tulsa (1977-84) and three years at Arizona State (1985-87). He compiled a 56-32 mark at Tulsa, leading the Golden Hurricane to five consecutive Missouri Valley Conference titles before moving to Arizona State. He was even more successful at ASU, guiding the Sun Devils to three-consecutive bowl berths, including their first ever appearance in the Rose Bowl, and a three-year record of 25-9-2. He was named National Coach of the Year in 1986 after leading ASU to a 10-1-1 record.

In terms of championships, Cooper has coached nine teams to conference titles (including the 1993, '96 and '98 Ohio State teams) and another five to second-place finishes.

Highly respected by his peers, Cooper is a past president of the American Football Coaches Association and has coached in the East-West Shrine, Hula Bowl and Japan All-Star games.

In the early 1960s, Austin Denney was a legendary prep athlete in Nashville, named to the Metropolitan Nashville Public Schools Sports Hall of Fame in 2008. He was named All-Nashville (NIL) in football, basketball, and baseball, and was named Nashville's "Athlete of the Year" in 1962.

He was awarded a football scholarship to the University of Tennessee, lettering in 1965 and 1966. He was co-captain in 1966 (with Paul Naumoff) and was named All-SEC and All-America.

He defined the tight end position at Tennessee, holding the record for the most career touchdown pass receptions (9) by a tight end at Tennessee, one later tied but not yet broken. He had seven TD catches in 1966, a record also surviving more than 40 years. He was selected as the tight end on Tennessee Football's "Best of the 60's" team.

He was drafted by the Dallas Cowboys in the 11th round of the 1967 NFL draft, was traded to the Chicago Bears, and became the Bears' starting tight end from 1967 through 1969. He received "Player of the Game" honors in 1968 against the New Orleans Saints. He played for the Buffalo Bills in 1970 and 1971 and was selected as the most popular player in 1970.

A native of Vincenza, Italy, Foster started the University of Tennessee's first women's club volleyball team.

Before, during, and after graduate school at Tennessee, she played on Adult USA volleyball teams. She received a USA Carolina Region (North and South Carolina) Award as MVP. She won two gold medals and one silver medal at the USA Adult Volleyball National Championships playing for the team Kwick-eez out of Pennsylvania.

She played grass and beach volleyball for many years, competing in numerous amateur and several professional tournaments.

She became involved with the Smoky Mountain Junior Olympic Volleyball Club (SMJVC) as a coach in 1994, which was being run at that time by the University of Tennessee Volleyball Department.

In 1997, she became the full-time director for SMJVC. It grew from the original three teams to an all-time high of 17 teams last season (2009). Girls from eight counties come to play for the club. Through the Club, more than 90 girls have been awarded college scholarships.

She is currently employed at the Oak Ridge National Labs in the Systems Genetics group.

This fall, she will start as the new head volleyball coach at Oak Ridge High School.

Jerilynn Harper Carroll began playing basketball at age 12 in New Market. She was an All-State and Parade All-America selection in 1977 and 1978. She broke the state of Tennessee single season scoring record in 1978 with 1,562 points and had her No. 30 jersey retired.

At Tennessee Tech, she was All-Ohio Valley Conference for three season and a two-time OVC player and scholar-athlete of the year. She was an NWSF first team All-America selection.

She was the 1980-81 Division I National Scoring Champion with a 29.7 average. In 1982, she was named to the Kodak All-America team, was named Academic All-America, and again had her jersey retired.

As a teacher/coach for 24 years in the Knox County School System, she was head girl's basketball coach at Halls High School, compiling a 261-246 overall record. In 2004, she was inducted into the KIL Basketball Coaches Hall of Fame.

She was District Coach of the Year in 1994 and KIL Coach of the Year in 1993 and 2000.

She has been married for 17 years to retired Gibbs High School football coach and present Webb assistant coach Randy Carroll.

Bill Higdon, a graduate of Knoxville's Holston High School, follows his father, Joe Higdon (1989, inducted as a coach), as an inductee into the Greater Knoxville Sports Hall of Fame.

The younger Higdon has had a distinguished professional career at Volunteer State Community College, Western Kentucky University, and the University of Tennessee.

A 1970 University of Tennessee graduate, Higdon earned a master's degree (1972) from Western Kentucky University (1970-72), where he was an assistant coach on the 1971 NCAA Final Four team.

Before coming to Tennessee, Higdon was also on the staff at Volunteer State Community College (1973-74), as assistant coach in both baseball and basketball.

He was on Tennessee staff from 1975 through 2009, starting as assistant recruiting coordinator and finishing as assistant athletics director for game management, overseeing the behind-the-scenes workings of athletic events at Neyland Stadium, Thompson-Boling Arena, and Lindsey Nelson Stadium. He and the late Haywood Harris, honored this year in the "Thanks for the Memories" category, were well known for their noontime runs, later walks, across campus.

He worked closely with new head coach Johnny Majors when the former Vol star came home to Knoxville in late 1976 and early 1977. Higdon retired in 2009.

Higdon is married to the former Susan Wolcott. They have two children, Julie and David. There are three grandchildren, Reese, Jonathan, and Anna.

When the definitive history of Knoxville golf is finally written, the name of Jim Kerr will have to be there, right at the top.

Kerr was probably the hottest golfing news in the local Knoxville Golf scene during the mid-1950s. Local Knoxville Golf news was covered as well or better than the Masters or the British Open in the 1950's. Golf had a vibrant following on the course and in the local print media.

Jim lettered in golf at the old Knoxville High School and at the University of Tennessee.

In 1956, he won Knoxville's three major golf championship trophies at one time, at Cherokee Country Club, Deane Hill, and the Knoxville Golf Association.

"His 6-5 victory over Rodney (Frosty) Snow yesterday in the Cherokee finals completes his own grand slam for 1956," Tom Siler wrote.

"He already has the city title and the Deane Hill championship. Jim has been a finalist at Deane Hill for six consecutive years, winning three times. In four cracks at the Cherokee title, he now has won two championships."

Kerr also won the Royal Winchester Golf Club championship in Winchester, England, in August 1951.

Kerr was instrumental in the founding of the Sertoma Center in 1961. Following his lead, his four sons are also members and supporters of Knoxville Sertoma Clubs and the Sertoma Center in Knoxville.

Carolyn Peck, a native of Jefferson City, was a two-time prep All-America at Jefferson County High School and by her senior year was averaging 35 points and 13.2 rebounds a game. That season, Peck was named Tennessee's "Miss Basketball," an honor recognizing the state's top high school girl's basketball player and was voted the top recruit in the nation by one scouting service.

From Jefferson City, Peck went on to Vanderbilt University where she also played from 1985 to 1988. During her career at Vanderbilt, Peck averaged 10.6 points and 5.8 rebounds per game.

After assistant coaching jobs at Tennessee and Kentucky, she went to Purdue and became head coach when the job opened up in 1997. She led Purdue to the Elite Eight in 1998 and the Boilermakers grabbed the brass ring in 1999, leading Purdue to the national title.

She has also coached the Orlando Miracle and at the University of Florida.

She joined ESPN in 2001 as a basketball analyst for men's and women's college basketball, NBA and WNBA. In her role, she contributes to studio shows and games across ESPN, ESPN2, ESPNU and ESPNEWS.

Dirk Pohlmann grew up in Alexandria, Va., and moved to Knoxville, to attend the University of Tennessee in pursuit of an industrial engineering degree, attained in 1986. During his cycling career he raced in 15 different countries, has competed in over 800 hundred races winning 81 times.

As an amateur, Mr. Pohlmann won the 1991 Meurth-et-Moselle stage race in France, the 2007 National Road Championships (men 40-44) in Seven Springs, PA, and was the vice champion in the 2007 World Championships (men 40-44) in St. Johan Austria.

As a professional cyclist, he has won stages of the Tour of Argentina, Tour of Costa Rica (held leaders jersey for 2 days, sprinter jersey for 2 days), Tour of Peru (held leaders jersey for 4 days), Tour of Venezuela, and Tour of Chiriqui Panama (held leaders jersey for 2 days, sprinter jersey for 6 days). He competed in the 1991, 1992, and 2007 (6th place) U.S. National Elite Amateur Championship, the 1992 and 1996 U.S. Olympic Trials, and the 1993, 1994, and 1996 U.S. Professional Championships. He retired from professional cycling in 1996 and returned to UT to obtain an additional degree in BioSystems Engineering. Pohlmann currently races in many of the amateur and Pro-Am invitational races in the southeast and Midwest for Texas Roadhouse Cycling Team presented by Motorex.

As a student-athlete at Oak Ridge High School from 1955 until his graduation in 1959, Jackie Pope established himself as an outstanding all-around athlete and an All-State and All-America tailback.

He played tailback on the powerful single wing teams coached by legendary East Tennessee coach and Bob Neyland disciple, Jack Armstrong. More importantly, the Wildcats were 28-2 with Pope as a first-team performer.

In 1956, ORHS completed the season undefeated, ranked number one and was declared State Champions by the Litkenhous Ratings. During the 1957 season, Pope emerged as one of Tennessee's premier backs and began to set new school records, leading his team in rushing, passing, and return yardage that season. In 1958, the Wildcats again went undefeated, were State Champs, and Jackie Pope was recognized as an All-America running back by The Sporting News.

He went on to a distinguished football career at Middle Tennessee State University where he was selected as an All-America in 1962, also lettering in track and baseball. Pope continued his success in athletics with an accomplished coaching career, culminating in a post at the college level at Western Kentucky University. Eventually, he pursued a multi-faceted career in secondary and higher education, banking, Tennessee state government, and transportation.

Pope is retired and resides in Oak Ridge, with Jane, his wife of 41 years. Their son Robbie, a Webb School, Emory University and UT College of Law grad, is a corporate attorney with Regal Entertainment Group in Knoxville.

Knoxville West High School graduate Chuck Ramsey attended Wake Forest University from 1971-73, where he served as the starting quarterback, punter and place-kicker. He led the nation in punting during his senior year with a 44.8-yard average, earning him All-America status. Ramsey played in five postseason All-Star bowl games, an NCAA record, the Blue-Gray Game, North-South Shrine Game, East-West Shrine Game, Hula Bowl, and the Coaches All-America Game.

Ramsey signed with the New York Jets in 1977 and served as the team's punter for eight seasons. He punted a record 568 times, with the longest traveling 79 yards against the Colts. Ramsey was also the team's back-up quarterback and place-kicker. In 2003, he was selected to the All-Time New York Jets team as the punter.

He was also inducted into the Wake Forest University Sports Hall of Fame and will be a member of the radio broadcast team for the Demon Deacons during the 2010 football season.

Ramsey co-founded Next Level Prep, a national recruiting service for both male and female high school athletes. He also conducts several punting and kicking camps and clinics throughout the southeast. Ramsey is very active in various charity events such as the Special Olympics, children's hospitals, and several charity golf tournaments.

entry.category: Female High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description:
West High School's Patavia Lowery, headed to South Carolina State on a track scholarship, collected a passel of awards and memories from her time as a West High School Rebel, respected by both students and teachers alike.

A very personable and hard-working student on and off the track, she was All-State in cross-country, ranking 11th in the state in 2010, and was All-State in track. She was a state meet qualifier all four years of her time at West.

Described as a self-motivator who is always looking to improve her skills, she was a 2009 and 2010 regional champion and All-KIL in cross-country in 2009. She is the school record holder in the 800-meter run. She was the 3A 800-meter state champion on 2010. She was a first-team PrepXtra track and field selection in 2010.

She had an eighth-place finish in the AAU Junior Olympics in 2009. She had a sixth place finish, American status, in the New Balance Nationals Elite Division, and was named to the Footlocker Cross-Country Championships All-South Region team.

She was a member of two state championship teams in track at West in 2008 and 2010.

entry.category: Female High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description:
Taylor Mills, a Kenesaw State University basketball signee, assembled an enviable record for her four years at Gibbs High School.

She was a two-time All-State selection and while graduating tied for fifth in her class, taking honors and advanced placement classes.

She was KIL Player of the Year in 2009-2010 and a four-time All-KIL selection. She was a "Miss Tennessee Basketball" finalist in Class AA in 2010, one of three so honored. She was a four-time All-District selection and selected KIL "Sophomore of the Year" in 2008.

She was tabbed the Knoxville News-Sentinel's Player of the Week seven times. Her career highs, points-wise, were 47 against Gatlinburg-Pittman and 45 against Union County. She had 2,166 career points, 585 assists, and 279 three-pointers, all school records.

While participating with the AAU - K.G.C. "Lady Pride," her teams won four state titles and went to three national final fours. She played in the Boys & Girls Clubs program, coached by Special Recognition Award Winner Mike Capps, for eight years.

She was her junior and senior class vice-president. She was part of the FCA, the Special Olympics, and Young Life, and was an assistant coach in the Boys & Girls Club Junior Pro League. She was in the National Honor Society, the Spanish Honor Society, and Mu Alpha Theta.

entry.category: Male High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description:
Jalen Steele, a Mississippi State basketball signee for 2010-11, ended his Fulton High School career as one of the leading players in school history, being thought of in the same breath with Ron Widby, Bill Justus, and the other greats in Falcon history. From his freshman season on, Falcon fans saw that he was something special.

He ended his career as the leading scorer in Fulton High history with more than 2,400 points.

Steele was a three-time Class AA All State selection and was the Knoxville News Sentinel's PrepXtra Player of the Year in 2009 and 2010. He was PrepXtra "Sophomore of the Year" in 2008. He was a three-time Region 2-AA tournament MVP.

He was a member of state championship teams in 2008 and 2009. He was state tournament MVP in 2008 and 2009. He was Class AA "Mr. Basketball" in 2010.

He was a three-time selection as District 3-AA "Player of the Year" and was District 3-AA tournament MVP in 2008 and 2010.

Steele was also a Class AA Tennessee Sportwriters Association All-State selection in 2008 and 2009. In 2010, he was won the U.S. Marine Corps Distinguished Athlete Award.

entry.category: Male High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description:
As a four-year starter for the Webb High School Spartans, Dwight Tarwater scored over 1,800 points and gathered over 1,000 rebounds, averaging a double/double for his high school career.

He was a two-time first-team All State Selection. He was a three-time first-team All-Region Selection. He was the Region MVP in 2010. Locally, he was first-team All-KIL and Knoxville News Sentinel PrepXtra.

In 2010, Dwight led Webb to a 25-8 record and to the TSSAA state semi-finals, a first for the Spartan program. He was named Tennessee's Division II-A "Mr. Basketball."

"Dwight is the poster boy for a high school student-athlete," head coach Ricky Norris said. "Not only is he a tremendous player (evidenced by his accomplishments), but he is also an incredible teammate. I think that being a good teammate is the best compliment that a young man can receive."

After a lengthy recruitment, Dwight, who is also a good student, committed to Cornell University where he will continue his education and his basketball career. Cornell is the reigning Ivy League Champion, advancing to the Sweet 16 in the 2010 NCAA tournament this year.

Coach Norris said, "Dwight exemplifies everything the award is about. His teammates love him. I love him as a coach. I just think he fits the award, for what it is."

entry.category: Male High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description:
A running back and linebacker for Alcoa High School, JaRon Toney finished his prep career with a flourish, by being named the 2009 PrepXtra Offensive Player of the Year, breaking the state record with 50 touchdowns in 2009 along with 2358 yards. JaRon also broke the state for rushing TDs in a season. And, he was named the 2009 Gatorade Player of the Year.

He was an All-State selection in 2007, 2008 and 2009 and was a finalist for "Mr. Football." He averaged 8.7 yards per carry en route to leading Alcoa to a sixth consecutive state championship. He was chosen Most Valuable Player for the 2008 and 2009 state title games.

Other accolades include All-County selections in 2007, 2008 and 2009. JaRon was also "Blount County Athlete of the Year" and was chosen to play for the East All-State Team. He also went to the state track meet two consecutive years in four different events.

JaRon attended American Legion Boys State in the summer 2009. His community service includes work with Alcoa Youth football camp and youth leadership team. He will walk on with the University of Tennessee football team this fall.

Garrett Willis is a lifetime member of the PGA Tour, one of only three players in history to win his first ever event, the 2001 Tucson Open.

Before coming to the PGA Tour, Garrett was successful at every level, winning on both the Nationwide and Hooter's Tour. He is one of only two Tennesseans to win the State High School, the State Amateur, and the State Open.

As a collegiate golfer at East Tennessee State, he was a three-time All-America, earning first team in 1996 with Tiger Woods. He won four college tournaments that year, second most in the nation behind Tiger.

After he finished school, he won his first professional tournament, the Hooters Tour Championship. He went on to win the Canadian Amateur Championship, the Panama Open and two out the sixteen events he played on the Hooter's Tour.

Currently, Garrett is having one of his best seasons ever on the PGA Tour. He finished tied for fourth at this year's Saint Jude Classic in Memphis. He has had five top 25 finishes in 16 events this year. He is 87th on the money list and 91st in the Fed Ex cup standings.

Mike Capps has had a distinguished career as a youth sports coach with the Boys & Girls Clubs from 1971 through 2010. He has made a career of helping young athletes learn how to win on and off the court and learn how to win (and lose) the right way.

He has coached AAU Basketball for the Knoxville Girls Club (KGC) Lady Pride team in association with the Boys & Girls Clubs from 2002 through today, Junior Pro Basketball for the local Boys & Girls Clubs from 1971-2007, and Baseball in the A.A.B.C. Willie Mays leagues (Ages 9 and 10) from 1972 through 2001 for the boys team.

He also coached youth football (ages 7-11) for 18 years, was the Boys Club or Baby Falcon head coach from 1972-85, and was Halls Youth Assistant Coach from 1995-98.

His teams have been national champions six times, national finalists three times, state champions 19 times, state finalist nine times, and have made four national final fours.

There are uncounted young men and women in the Boys & Girls Clubs programs he has mentored and who owe him a tremendous debt of gratitude. His teams have been sportsmanship award winners in more than 25 state or national tournaments, a statistic reflecting his influence among his players.

Haywood Harris promoted, wrote about, and enjoyed an association with University of Tennessee athletics for nearly 50 years, before his death at age 80 June 2, 2010, at his home in West Knoxville.

Harris, who oversaw the UT Athletic Department's sports information office and served as an assistant athletic director from 1961 to his retirement in 2000.

After retiring, Harris continued to work part-time in the athletic department as an assistant athletic director until he suffered a stroke Nov. 14, the morning of UT's homecoming game against Memphis.

He and longtime friend Gus Manning hosted a sports radio show entitled "The Locker Room" from 1961 until 2009. It was considered to be the longest-running radio sports show in the country. It was a not-to-be missed part of game day for Vol fans across the decades.

Harris was a 1951 UT graduate, who worked at the Charlotte Observer and as a Knoxville Journal sportswriter before starting as UT Alumni Office field secretary in 1959. When athletic director Gen. Robert R. Neyland promoted Manning to ticket manager, Haywood took Manning's place.

Harris was born in Blount County Aug. 26, 1929, but he lived his boyhood days in Knoxville and attended Knoxville High School, which honored him as one of its top 100 outstanding graduates earlier this summer.

The legendary Oak Ridge coach led the ORHS athletic program from 1943-1971. He coached football for five years, basketball for 17, and track and field for 22 years. He served as Athletic Director at ORHS from 1943-1971.

In track, he won seven track and field state championships at ORHS (1952, 1953, 1956, 1957, 1958, 1961, 1962), had two second place finishes (1959, 1964), and two third place finishes (1954, 1955). He won 12 region and 14 district track and field championships. He served as the East Tennessee representative on the TSSAA Track Committee. During his tenure as athletic director, ORHS teams won 14 boys' state championships, including the seven he won in track and field.

His teams won one region basketball championship with one state tournament appearance (1958). His overall ORHS coaching record in basketball was 261 wins, 162 losses.

He selected the ORHS team mascot (Wildcats) and colors (Cardinal and Gray) in the school's first year.

The ORHS on-campus track facility was named the "Ben Martin Track and Field" in 1977. He was inducted into the Oak Ridge Sports Hall of Fame in its first year in 1986. He was inducted in the TSSAA Hall of Fame in 2010.

He died Jan. 16, 1979.

Bill Redding, longtime Knoxville News Sentinel Human Resources Director, had not only a distinguished career with the newspaper, but also distinguished himself on Knoxville area golf courses.

Mr. Redding, a longtime Holston Hills resident and native of Logansport, Ind., was involved with several newspaper associations and was the city golf champion in 1957. He began working for the Knoxville News Sentinel in 1966.

He helped found the Tennessee Valley Personnel Association. He was also past president, club champion and board member of Holston Hills Country Club, as well as director of the Tennessee Golf Association and founder of the Greater Knoxville Amateur Golf Championship. He officiated at State Amateur Tournament from 1981 on.

In 1996, at age 61, he qualified for Match Play at the USGA Senior Amateur Tournament, advancing to the Sweet 16. He defeated defending champion James Stahl before being defeated by reigning British Senior Champion Joel Hirsch.

He served as a delegate to the 1971 Constitutional Convention and as chairman of the Metropolitan Planning Commission. He was also involved with the Republican Party.

He was on the varsity golf team at Purdue University, graduating in 1957. He also did graduate work at the University of Tennessee.

He died Nov. 18, 1997, at age 62.

Fielden's officiating career began in 1982 with the Knox-Ridge Basketball Officials Association, working district, regional and sub-state tournaments for 15 years. She was the first female to officiate in the TSSAA Boy's State Basketball Championship (1994). Her collegiate career in women's basketball began in 1985 with the Volunteer State Athletic Conference and the Tennessee Junior College Athletic Association.

She has called the Junior College National Championship in 1993 (Jackson, Tenn.) and the NCAA Division III National Championship in 1995 in New York City. She also officiated in the Mid-South, Gulf South, South Atlantic, Old Dominion and Great South Athletic Conferences.

Her career as an NCAA Division I official has spanned the Ohio Valley, Big South, Sunbelt and Southern Conferences. She has called the NIT and several conference tournaments, including the finals of the Ohio Valley Conference in 1996 and 1997.

She has been an official in four NCAA Division I Tournaments, advancing to the Sweet Sixteen in 1998. Has also refereed the Women's Basketball Coaches Association/Nike High School All-American Game for the last 11 years and has called numerous AAU National Championship games.

Aside from officiating, she has assigned and supervised officials for two AAU National Championships in Knoxville and for numerous Special Olympic State Basketball Tournaments.

She is currently an assistant principal at Knoxville's West High School. Her father Elbert Fielden is a member of the Greater Knoxville Sports Hall of Fame Class of 2002.

Poore is a 1962 graduate of East High School and native Knoxvillian, who followed an exceptional Mountaineer prep career by earning a full-ride basketball scholarship to the University of Florida.

He played at "Alligator Alley" from 1963-67.

He graduated from Florida in 1967 with a bachelor's degree in health and physical education and earned a master's degree in administration and supervision in 1976 from Central Florida University.

Then began a more than 30-year career in public education, as Poore wore a variety of hats in working his way up the ladder. Only a two-year stint as a medical sales representative in Johnson City interrupted his public service in education.

He spent more than 30 years in public education in Gainesville and Hernando County school systems as teacher, assistant principal, principal, and assistant superintendent. He also served as director of Human Resources and Chief Negotiator for the Hernando County School System.

For Elizabeth Henderson, tennis has been a lifelong journey, from the junior, prep, and collegiate ranks to coaching, teaching, and administrative capacities.

She won the TSSAA doubles title (with Rebecca Garcia) in 1973 and the singles title in 1975.

At the University of Tennessee-Chattanooga, she was a three-time All-America selection (1977-79), a three-time Team National Champion (AIAW-Small College, 1977-79), a three-time Singles National Champion (AIAW-Small College, 1977-79), a three-time Doubles National Champion (AIAW-Small College, 1977-79), and was third in AIAW-Division I Doubles in 1980.

Since 1987, she has been a teaching professional and club manager at the Peninsula Club in Knoxville.

She was head women's coach at William & Mary (1982-84) and the University of Tennessee (1984-87). She was inducted into the UTC Sports Hall of Fame in 1992, the Tennessee Tennis Hall of Fame in 2010, and the Tennessee Sports Hall of Fame in 2011.

Since 2003, she has been a member of the Junior Team Tennis Committee for the Knoxville area, and in 2011 became a member of the Tennessee Junior 10 & Under Junior Competition Committee.

She holds a bachelor's degree from the University of Tennessee-Chattanooga (magna cum laude) in health and physical education and a master of sciences degree in sport administration from the University of North Carolina.

U.S. Rep. Shuler's career on the football field began at Swain County High School, where he led the Maroon Devils to three North Carolina state championships and was named the North Carolina High School Player of the Year. From Swain County, he continued his football career just over the Great Smoky Mountains at the University of Tennessee.

During his three years at UT, Rep. Shuler set numerous passing records, was selected to multiple All-America teams, and was named the Southeastern Conference Player of the Year. He made the All-SEC Academic Team, was named NCAA Male Athlete of the Year and in 1993 was runner-up for the Heisman Trophy. Currently, he ranks eighth all-time in total offense and in career passing yards at UT.

In 1994, the Washington Redskins selected him with the third pick in the first round of the National Football League Draft. He played three seasons for the Redskins before moving to the New Orleans Saints. While playing for the Saints in 1997, he suffered a severe injury to his foot that ended his professional football career.

After his football career, Rep. Shuler began a successful career as a real estate entrepreneur, building one of the largest real estate firms in Tennessee.

In 2006, he was elected to the U.S. House of Representatives from his home district in western North Carolina.

Rep. Shuler is married to Nikol Davis of Waynesville and they have two children, Navy and Island.

Bemiller began his coaching career as an assistant football and track coach in Mansfield, Ohio, at Malabar High School. He was hired by Tennessee head coach Doug Brown and coached pole vaulters at the University of Tennessee from 1986-2005.

He coached Tim Mack, the 2004 Olympic champion in the pole vault, and has coached athletes in the pole vault at Tennessee who have won five NCAA Championships and 15 Southeastern Conference Championships and 21 All America Certificates.

He also coached Randy Jenkins in the high jump. Jenkins became a UT legend by winning three NCAA Championships and helping the Vols win an NCAA team title in 1991, all after battling and beating Hodgkin's Lymphoma.

Under Bemiller's guidance, Tennessee vaulters have rewritten the record books. They have broken the SEC, American Junior, NCAA, American, World Athletic Final and Olympic records.

The capstone of Bemiller's career came at the 2004 Olympic Games in Athens, Greece as Mack won the Olympic Gold Medal in an epic four hour contest on his final attempt, setting an Olympic Games Record of 19' 6 1/2".

He is married to UT Lady Vol Olympian and Greater Knoxville Hall of Fame member Missy Kane and is the proud father of daughters Gracie and Kelsey.

Jim Smelcher was an outstanding football and basketball player for Lake City High School. In 1953, he was selected for the All-State Football Team and was in the State Basketball Tournament in 1951-1953.

He received a football scholarship from the University of Tennessee in 1954, playing for head coach Bowden Wyatt from 1954-1957. The Vols won the SEC title in 1956.

Tennessee played in two bowl games during Jim's time at Tennessee, losing to Baylor, 13-7, in the 1957 Sugar Bowl, and in the 1957 Gator Bowl, defeating Texas A&M 3-0.

After receiving his degree in 1958, he coached in Georgia for three years. In 1959, he coached at West Rome High School, in Rome, Ga., and at Richmond Academy in Augusta, Ga. in 1960 and 1961. His teams played for the Georgia State Championship in 1960 and 1961.

He coached in Tennessee for 12 years, two years at Franklin High School, and 10 years at Bearden High School in Knoxville from 1964-74. He was 1966 KIL "Coach of the Year."

In 2009, he was inducted into the Anderson County Hall of Fame. In 2010, he was honored by Bearden High School with the naming of the "The Jim Smelcher Fieldhouse."

Currently he is the owner and manager of his own life insurance company, THE INSURANCE STORE. Jim has four children: Steve, Lisa (deceased), Jana, and Dara.

After a stellar prep career at Knoxville's Central High School, Cobb broke in as a redshirt freshman in 1987 and rushed for 1197 yards and 17 touchdowns, giving the Vols a dimension of speed and power from the tailback position.

The Vols compiled a 10-2-1 record that season, and Cobb's abilities to get inside and outside with the football were one of the big reasons. Whenever the Vols needed to make a play, Cobb proved capable of delivering the goods.

On a rain-swept afternoon at Neyland Stadium in a nationally televised game against No. 4 Auburn, Cobb gained 225 yards rushing and had a 79-yard touchdown run.

He ranks No. 10 on the career rushing list with 2,360 yards, averaging 5.23 yards per carry and scoring 26 touchdowns. He had ten 100-yard games during his career.

He was selected in the second round of the 1990 NFL draft by Tampa Bay. He rushed for 3,743 yards and 27 touchdowns. He played professionally for the Tampa Bay Buccaneers (1990-93), Green Bay Packers (1994), Jacksonville Jaguars (1995), and New York Jets (1996-97). He rushed for 3,743 yards and scored 27 touchdowns in seven NFL seasons.

He is now a scout with the San Francisco 49ers.

Galyon was a hometown product who made it big as a linebacker at the University of Tennessee. He grew up in nearby Seymour, playing football, basketball and baseball at Seymour High School and signed scholarship papers during his senior year.

Galyon led the team in tackles during his junior and senior years and was voted team captain for his senior season. He capped his Tennessee career as the Vols took a 20-14 victory over the highly touted Ohio State Buckeyes and Heisman Trophy winner Eddie George.

Scott was then selected by the New York Giants in the sixth round of the 1996 NFL draft. He played four years for the Giants, being voted "Special Teams Player of the Year" in his second season and helping the Giants to an NFC East Championship.

In 2000, he signed with the Miami Dolphins. In 2001, he was the recipient of the "Ed Block Courage Award" for athletes who have overcome adversity. He retired after the 2002 season.

He joined the FCA staff in December of 2007, responsible for FCA activities in Claiborne, Cocke, Grainger, Hamblen and Jefferson counties. He is married to the former Chasity Smith who is also from Seymour. They have been married for 11 years and have two children Elijah, 8, and Gracie Mae, 7. He follows his grandfather, Milo Fisher, into the Greater Knoxville Sports Hall of Fame.

Gus Manning and Haywood Harris, each distinguished ambassadors for the University of Tennessee, were slated to receive this award jointly at last year's banquet, but when Haywood died on June 2, 2010, Gus graciously stepped aside to let his good friend have the spotlight shine on him, just as everybody knew he would.

It's Gus' turn this year to be honored for his service to his university and the Knoxville community.

Not only has Gus held nearly every position the athletic department offers, starting as sports information director, but he also joined Haywood in 1961 for the ever-popular "Locker Room," highlighting the game at hand wherever the Vols were playing. It was "don't-miss" radio.

There were a number of great duos throughout history, Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid, the Lone Ranger and Tonto, and Andy Taylor and Barney Fife, but Gus and Haywood have to be there somewhere near the top. You can't imagine one of them without the other.

No one knew the legendary Gen. Robert R. Neyland better. No one from Tennessee is more respected across the world of intercollegiate athletics.

Gus is not without a delightful sense of humor, as evidenced by one specific incident.

When a Kentucky fan told him the Wildcats were going to end the losing streak to Tennessee on the football field, all Gus could say was, "That's what your grandfather once told me."

When James Allen Dick, Sr. died peacefully at his Knoxville home on February 6, 2011, his family and friends could look back at a lifetime of dedicated community service.

Mr. Dick came to Knoxville in 1947 for a job in radio broadcast sales. From that point on, the sky was the limit.

In 1953, the FCC granted him a license for a 1,000-watt daytime station he named WIVK. When the FM radio band became available, though others doubted, he launched WIVK-FM, which became a legend in East Tennessee and throughout the nation in the broadcasting industry.

He oversaw the growth of Dick Broadcasting Company to 15 stations in Tennessee, North Carolina, and Alabama, before selling the company in 2000. He believed strongly in giving back to the community, and always tried to serve and better the community.

In doing so, he was chairman of the United Way, co-chair of the Dogwood Arts Festival, and president of the Knoxville Symphony Society and Knoxville Junior Achievement. He worked with the Boys & Girls Clubs and Habitat for Humanity, and was on numerous boards including Valley Fidelity Bank, Knoxville College, Child and Family Services, Knoxville Chamber of Commerce, Knoxville Tourist Bureau, and the Tennessee Association of Broadcasters. His last great gifts to the community were his support for the historic Tennessee Theatre and the Joy of Music School.

Link has been a leader in youth league baseball since the 1970s, doing everything from lining fields to distributing flyers about baseball programs.

Every year from early April to mid-June the past 35 years, he has pitched baseball to 5-7 year-old ballplayers. Not only does he pitch, but calls the games ("six innings or an hour, no walks, adult catchers, all the kids play, all the kids bat"), keeps the coaches and parents in line, and makes certain everyone is having a good time.

"I usually pitched five or six games each Saturday," he says, "plus a double-header on Wednesday nights." He says he throws overhand (75%) or underhand (25%), depending on the ability level of the hitter.

By his own estimate, Link has pitched to more than 600,000 prospective young baseball players over the years, either overhand or underhand, depending on their ability level.

He has led the growth and development of programs at Sequoyah and Lakeshore Parks and taught young players lessons that go well beyond the baseball diamond. He has received numerous awards for his unique brand of community service.

Where Trevor Bayne is concerned, it's hard to imagine a young driver with more championships (22) than his age. And now to add to his list of accomplishments, he is the newest, and record-breaking youngest, Daytona 500 Champion.

Bayne competed for eight years on the go-kart circuit earning three World Championships, with over 300 feature wins and 18 state and track championships combined. During that time, Bayne also learned the value of dedication and discovered the joy of success that would transform him into the fierce competitor that has defined his career.

From there, it was the Allison Legacy Race Series, where a 13-year-old Bayne became the youngest top rookie in the series. Over his two-year stint in the series he notched 14 wins, 19 pole positions and 30 top-five finishes in only 41 starts. Additionally, the young phenom became the series' National Champion in 2005.

Bayne made a successful transition to the USAR Hooters Pro Cup Series Southern Division. At 15, he again was the youngest in series history to earn top rookie honors.

Bayne started the first 28 races of 2010 for Michael Waltrip Racing. During the second half of that tenure, he drove to three poles, five top-fives, and nine top 10 finishes in 14 starts before making the move to Roush Fenway.

entry.category: Male High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description:
From the time he arrived at Bearden High School, Bulldog fans knew instinctively that Devrin Young had the ability to be something special, and lead the Bulldogs to new heights on the gridiron. Give him the ball, and something good usually happened.

A blend of speed, quickness, and power, Young played as effectively defensively as offensively. Young was a "can't miss" prospect who didn't. Opposing defenses had to account for him on every play.

A threat to go all the way any time he touched the ball, either rushing, receiving, or returning kicks, Young was one of the more heralded prospects to come out of Knoxville in years, honored by the Tennessean, PrepXtra, and the Tennessee Sportswriters Association.

For his career, he had 7,433 all-purpose yards. He was named Mr. Football AAA "Back of the Year" and was PrepXtra "Back of the Year." He was District 4AAA "Player of the Year" as a senior and "Offensive Player of the Year" as a junior. He was PrepXtra "Player of the Year" as a sophomore.

Defensively from 2008-10, he had 54 tackles (43 solo, with 11 assists), three interceptions for 63 yards, and six pass break-ups.

Young has signed football scholarship papers to attend the University of Tennessee.

entry.category: Male High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description:
When Carter High School fans think about the great players who have passed through the program, the name Lester Wilson will have to be near the top of the list. Wilson has etched his name into Carter history with a career that still has fans talking about him as being one of the great ones to play at the east Knox County school. Talk about a player creating memories for the ages for the community.

Wilson was named All-State each of the last three years and was a finalist for Class AA "Mr. Basketball." He led Carter High to the TSSAA State Basketball Tournament in 2009 and 2010.

He was a four-time All-District and All-KIL selection and was named District 3AA "Player of the Year" in 2011. He is the all-time leading scorer and rebounder at Carter High School. He was PrepXtra "Sophomore of the Year" in 2009.

He is the all-time leading scorer and rebounder at Carter, with 2,872 points (25 ppg) and 1,452 rebounds (14 rpg) for his career.

He has signed basketball scholarship papers with East Tennessee State University.

entry.category: Female High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description:
Treasure won the 2010 Nike Indoor Nationals in the Pentathlon, earning Indoor All-America status. She has served as Track Team Captain for three years and has helped lead her team to two state titles and one runner-up berth in the Division I-AAA class.

She ran on the 4x400 relay team that set a state record (3:51.19). She has earned two All-American honors and 14 All-State honors. She was twice named Knoxville Interscholastic League Field Event Athlete of the Meet and holds the KIL record in the triple jump. She holds school records in the pentathlon, 4x400, triple jump, high jump, heptathlon, and javelin.

She was the school's valedictorian with a GPA exceeding 4.5, having taken 13 Advanced Placement classes. She served as the Student Body President and was Class President for two years. She is a member of the National Honor Society and Key Club.

She participated for four years in Youth in Government and Model United Nations and has won several awards in each including top attorney team, best appellant brief, and most outstanding justice.

Maddie is an active participant in the community working as a volunteer on a daily basis at Tennessee Donor Services, averaging six hours per week with that organization. She also works with many other organizations, including Habitat for Humanity, Pond Gap Elementary School, and the Salvation Army.

She has earned a track scholarship to Stanford University.

entry.category: Male High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description:
Wormsley was awarded 11 letters in three sports at the Webb School of Knoxville. He was a four-year starter at quarterback, leading team to a 25-1 record during junior and senior seasons, winning back-to-back state championships. He was All-KIL and All-State in 2009 and 2010.

He won the Spartan Award in 2010, was named Best Offensive Player in 2009 and 2010, and was 2010 team captain. He also had a distinguished career in baseball, being a three-time All-State selection and University of Tennessee baseball signee.
