He was a 5-year starter for the Spartans at shortstop, beginning in the eighth grade. He was named All-Region in 2008, 2009, and 2010 and was the Region Player of the Year in 2010 and Regional Tournament Most Valuable Player in 2010.

He was the Division IIA State Player of the Year in 2010.

He won the Gold Glove Award in 2009 and 2010, had the highest batting average in 2008 and 2010, and was captain of the 2011 team. He was ranked as the No. 5 high school prospect in Tennessee for the 2011 Major League Draft. He was selected to play for the Oakland A's prospect team at the East Coast Professional Baseball Showcase in Lakeland, Fla., in 2010.

He played basketball for the Spartans in his eighth and ninth grade years.

Has literally given his life to the fortunes of Fulton High School athletics. Has been part of three state championship football teams (2003, 2004, and 2006) and two second place finishes (1974 and 2002). Member of TSSAA Hall of Fame and has been an official and clinic director. Has been in charge of chain gang for University of Tennessee football since 1967.

A respected coach who has accomplished great things for the Belmont University basketball program in his 26-year tenure with 545-284 (.657) record. Led Belmont's transition from an NAIA institution to a perennial headliner and championship program in NCAA Division I. Has led Belmont to five Atlantic Sun titles in the past seven years. Has won 637 games against 339 losses (.6812) in 31 years overall.

Fleming began playing golf at age 10 and garnered first hole-in-on at age 13. Won the ladies club championship at Green Meadow Country Club in 1999, 2000, 2001, and 2005. Has won seven Knoxville Area Womens Golf Association Championships and has been a finalist for five. In 2010, she won the Tennessee State Four Ball Championship.

Bearden High School alumnus who overcame injury that cost him nearly all of his collegiate career to serve as SEC referee since 1990. Was Crew Chief of SEC Referees and served as a Director for the Southeastern Conference Football Officials' Association. He is currently serving as a Replay Official for the SEC. Has served on the Championship Committee of the Knoxville News Sentinel Knoxville Open.

Earned All-SEC honors and was co-captain of the 1992 Tennessee team. First round selection of the San Francisco 49ers in 1993 NFL Draft and earned a Super Bowl ring in 1995. Was color analyst for CSS Comcast Sports on the McDonalds High School Games of the Week from 2006-09. Has participated as a local scout for The U.S. Army All-American Bowl in 2009-10.

Was outstanding in track and football in the mid-1950s in Knoxville. Went on to collegiate track scholarships, first at Tennessee, then at ETSU. As a senior in 1957-58, he was chosen first team All-City and tied for the citys top scorer, playing running back and safety. Has worked with many area track and field athletes over the past 50 years.

All-SEC cornerback and Academic All-SEC selection at the University of Tennessee in 1987. First round selection by Los Angeles Raiders in 1988, the No. 9 overall player taken. Received the Commitment to Excellence Award three times as voted on by his coaches and teammates while with the Raiders. Played with the Raiders 10 years and with the Seattle Seahawks for one year.

Began radio career at Fulton High School in Knoxville in mid-1960s, working under legendary broadcaster George Mooney, at that time the Voice of the Vols. Broadcast Fulton games in 1966 on the Fulton High frequency. Began broadcasting Lenoir City High School football in 1967, and has done so on WLIL ever since. Broadcast the first Lady Vols basketball game. Has broadcast 414 Lenoir City High School football games.

In 22 years as University of Tennessee swimming and diving coach, Parrington has achieved unparalleled success coaching on the collegiate, national and international levels. Has scholarship endowed in his name at Tennessee. Helped select the 2008 U.S. Olympic Diving Team. Has coached 33 SEC title-winning divers. A 1983 graduate of the University of Houston, where he holds a variety of Cougar diving records.

Lettered in five sports at Knoxvilles Central High School. Became part of the Tennessee legend when he and teammates Bill Majors and Wayne Grubb stopped LSUs Billy Cannon on two-point conversion attempt in 1959. Served in the Tennessee General Assembly from 1980-94. Lifetime member of the University of Tennessee Letterman's T-Club and serves on the organization's Board of Directors.

Elliott Stroupe began attending the Boys Club on Caswell Avenue in 1960 and has lived the lessons taught at the Club throughout his life. Stroupe played basketball at East High School and later graduated from Fulton. He received the Clubs Boy of the Year Award his senior year. He later became full time Physical Director and organized one of the most prestigious sports programs in the area, winning acclaim at the state and national level. In 1976, he received the distinguished Man and Boy Award. Later, in addition to teaching science at Webb School, he served as head varsity boys basketball coach for five years. He also served as middle school track, football, tennis, and basketball coach. In 2011, Stroupe was inducted into the KIL Basketball Coaches Hall of Fame. In 2007, he was a winner of the Don Tarvin Award, given annually to members of the Webb School faculty and staff who exemplify the qualities of moral, ethical, and spiritual leadership that the school seeks to impart to its students.

Athletic Director for Knox County schools after coaching at East, Austin-East, and Rule High Schools. Named KFL Coach of the Year five times and East Tennessee Coach of the Year three times. Civic minded and interested in the welfare of our citys youth, he served as a director and board member of the Knoxville Boys and Girls Club. Was head of the selection committee that chose each years awardees at this banquet.

Ace Miller was the face of Knoxville boxing for more than 40 years. Everybody seemed to know him, whether by his given name, Jerry Wayne, or his alter egos of Ace or Colonel. Miller defied the naysayers, first by taking John Tate to the heavyweight championship of the world, then by hosting a world championship bout telecast by ABC, Tate against Mike Weaver, at Stokely Center. The Ace Miller Golden Gloves Arena on Ace Miller Way just off Magnolia Avenue in East Knoxville stands today in tribute to his life and example. He changed the lives of many young people across the community. He might not have believed he was a legend, but everyone else knew full well that Ace Miller, who died suddenly on March 8, 2012, definitely was one.

Oak Ridge High School alumnus burst onto the PGA golf scene in 2008 and won his first PGA Tour victory at the Greenbrier Classic in 2011. Made 19 cuts in 28 events on the Nationwide Tour. Won 2012 True South Classic. Two-time Ohio Valley Conference selection at Tennessee Tech, winning seven tournaments. Was All-America selection in 2006.

To her peers, she is forthright, well-respected, ethical, and a winner who serves as a shining example in the sport of collegiate basketball. Lady Vols made unprecedented 31 consecutive appearances in NCAA Tournament. Lady Vols won eight NCAA titles as well as a combined 32 Southeastern Conference tournament and regular season championships. Compiled record 1,098-208 (.840) that included the most victories in NCAA basketball history.

entry.category: Male High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description: Twice named the Division II-A BlueCross Bowl Offensive MVP (2009-10). Versatile and talented athlete who was successful in football, basketball, and track. Selected as team captain this past season and Region MVP his senior season. Three-year letter winner in track. Won the "Spartan Award" in football and basketball in 2011-12. In his junior season in track, was a member of three relay teams that placed in the state meet.

entry.category: Female High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description: University of Georgia basketball signee was named Division II-A Miss Basketball, the Knoxville News Sentinel's PrepXtra Player of the Year in 2011, and the PrepXtra Female Track Athlete of the Year in 2009. Was the 2009-12 All-Region MVP. Was the 2010-11 Division II-A Regular Season MVP in 2011. She was a TSSAA State Tournament All-Tournament Player in 2009, 2010, and 2011.

entry.category: Female High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description: Carter's High Schools first Division I softball signee. Named Most Athletic Senior Superlative. Was named District Defensive Player of the Year in volleyball in 2012. Was elected team captain in softball and volleyball. Won the 2010 TSSAA Distinguished Scholastic Achievement Award. Was a 2012 selection to "Whos Who of CHS Senior Class." Won a 2011 Presidential Award for Community Service.

entry.category: Male High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description: University of Tennessee baseball signee helped Farragut High School win TSSAA state titles in 2009, 2010 and 2011. Was the Knoxville News Sentinel's PrepXtra "Player of the Year." Rated the No. 1 Player in Tennessee by Perfect Game-Baseball. Drafted by the Colorado Rockies 32nd round. Selected for the Baseball America Second Team All-America and the American Baseball Coaches Association/Rawlings Third Team All-America.

entry.category: Female High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description: Track signee at University of Alabama was multiyear pick to Knoxville News Sentinels PrepXtra's cross-country, soccer, and track teams. Holds state records at Bearden High School in 800, 1,600, 3,200 and 5K cross-country. Was a two-time All-State selection. Earned a 3.931 GPA while at Bearden. Was team captain in soccer and All-District IV and All-Region II TSSAA selection.

Plays for WNBA team Indiana Fever, and Turkish team Galatasaray. Seven-time WNBA All-Star, five-time All-WNBA selection. Famous for recording the first-ever quintuple double (25 points, 18 rebounds, 11 assists, 10 steals, and 10 blocks) in 1997. Scored her 2,000th point for the WNBA in 2005. Founder of the Catch the Stars Foundation.

As an athlete at Farragut High School, Neil Clabo was honored for his many achievements in baseball, basketball and football. He went on to play football at the University of Tennessee, where he was named to the All-SEC Freshman team and was an All-SEC punter his senior year. He was drafted by the Minnesota Vikings in 1975 and was Rookie of the Year. Clabo played in the 1977 Super Bowl against the Oakland Raiders.

entry.category: Chad Pennington Professional Athlete of the Year
entry.description: Set a franchise single-season record while playing for the Green Bay Packers with a league-high 2,342 combined net yards in 2012. With 954 receiving yards and 964 kickoff returns in 2012, he became the first player in NFL history to post 900-plus yards in each category in the same season.

entry.category: Chad Pennington Professional Athlete of the Year
entry.description: Third baseman for the San Diego Padres. Led the National League in RBIs in 2012. Was the eighth third basemen in NL history to win a Gold Glove and a Silver Slugger in the same season.

entry.category: Male High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description: Quarterback at Christian Academy of Knoxville led team to 2011 and 2012 state championships. Had 28-3 record as a starter and led team to three victories in four tries against archrival Alcoa. Holds 10 TSSAA records and three state championship records.

Pitching coach for the Los Angeles Dodgers. Was a left-handed pitcher for 21 years from 1977 to 1997, playing for the Seattle Mariners, Texas Rangers, Los Angeles Dodgers, Oakland Athletics, New York Yankees, and St. Louis Cardinals. Played for the Tennessee Volunteers baseball team from 1973 to 1976, where he was an All-America first baseman-pitcher and won the Southeastern Conference batting title with a .404 mark.

entry.category: Female High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description: Four-year letter winner and three-time All-State selection in golf at Farragut High School. Division 1AAA regional champion and team MVP. Was the Bonnie Blackburn Knox Area Junior Girls Champion and was a semi-finalist in the Welsh Girl's Golf Championship in Wales. Won 2013 Bridgestone Golf/Brandt Snedeker Music City Junior at Richland Country Club in Nashville.

Doyle Human began his sports career playing and lettering for three years in football, basketball, and baseball at Rule High School. He went on to coach midget softball, basketball, and football as well as Rule Junior High basketball. Human was highly respected as a top official in football, baseball, and basketball at high schools throughout Knox County. In 1987, Human was awarded the Ed Harris Memorial Award, and in 2001, he was inducted into the Knoxville Football Officials Association Hall of Fame.

Ed Irvin recently retired following a 33-year-long career in coaching high school volleyball. For the past eight seasons, Irvin coached at Seymour High; before that, he coached at Catholic, Doyle, and South-Doyle. He coached the South-Doyle team to a 36-9 record in 1991 and claimed the Class A/AA state title. Irvin finished his coaching career with a 723-327 record.

Bernadette Locke-Mattox was the first woman ever named to the coaching staff of a major men's college basketball team. A former All-America guard at the University of Georgia, Locke-Mattox has been an assistant coach with the Connecticut Sun women's basketball franchise of the WNBA since 2004. Previously, she served as the University of Kentucky Women's Basketball head coach from 1995 to 2003 and the University of Kentucky Men's Basketball assistant coach from 1990 to 1994.

Virginia Ann McGrath-Weaver swam for four years for the University of Tennessee and received many honors. McGrath-Weaver was a fifteen-time All-American and won three SEC Championships. She also holds four UT records: 200-IM, 200-freestyle, 800-freestyle relay and 200-freestyle relay. As a coach, McGrath-Weaver earned the honors of being a three-time Collegiate Swimming Coaches Association Academic All-American (1989, '90, and '91).

entry.category: Male High School Athlete of the Year
entry.description: Was a four-year starter, two-year captain, and Tennessee's Mr. Football 2012 at Grace Christian. Was class president and voted "Most Likely to Succeed." Was three-year member of National Honor Society. Won the Association of Christian Schools International Distinguished Student Award in Academics, Leadership, and Athletics in his sophomore and junior years. Served internship with orthopedic surgeon Dr. Sean Grace.

Holland Phillips began boxing at the YMCA when he was 12 years old. He won the Knoxville Golden Gloves Open Welter Weight Titles in 1959-1963. In 1961, he won the Southern Golden Gloves Welter Weight Championship in Nashville and he competed in the National Golden Gloves Tournament in Chicago. He was the Knoxville Golden Gloves Middle Weight Champion in 1964.

As a high school tennis player, Mary Ellis Richardson earned honors of TSSAA High School District and Region Singles Champion in 1971, '72 and '73 and was the TSSAA State Singles Champion in 1971 and '72. During her college career at Furman University, she was the South Carolina State AIAW Collegiate Singles Champion from 1974 to 1977. She was the Head Coach for the University of Tennessee Women's Tennis Team from 1978 to 1981, where she compiled a 53-17 record and coached the team to its first ever national ranking.

In 1972, Bill Schmidt won the bronze medal for the javelin throw at the Munich Summer Olympics. He remains the only American to medal in the javelin event in the last 56 years. He won the USA National Championships on the javelin throw in 1978 and was named "Javelin Thrower of the Decade" in the 1970s by Track and Field News. He went onto a career in sports marketing, where he was named by The Sporting News as one of "The 100 Most Powerful People in Sports" in 1996 and '98.

Jay Searcy began his sports writing career as a high school junior, stringing together articles for the Oak Ridger for $1 per story. He was a sports writer and editor for the Kingsport Times-News and Chattanooga Times as well as for the New York Times before becoming executive sports editor and writer for the Philadelphia Inquirer. Under his leadership, the Inquirer was honored by the Associated Press Sports Editors three times for best daily sports section. Searcy was inducted to the Tennessee Sports Writers Association Hall of Fame in 2007.

George Underwood played basketball at Austin-East High School and was a member of the 1976-1977 team that won the TSSAA State Championships in the AAA division and was honored as All-KIL, All East Tennessee Region and All State. Following his dynamic high school basketball career, he attended East Tennessee State University on a four year athletic scholarship, where he once outrebounded both Melvin Turpin and Sam Bowie during a game at Rupp Arena during the 1980-1981 season.

This Powell grad had a dream of playing football at Tennessee. Part of 1985 SEC championship season and Sugar Bowl victory over Miami. Drafted by Tampa Bay in the fourth round, 86th pick overall, playing for Bucs from 1988-1991, Philadelphia in 1992, and New York Jets in 1993, before an injury forced him to retire. Now active in Camp 76, honoring former teammate Harry Galbreath.

Coming to the University of Tennessee as walk-on from Spring City, Tenn., played on 1985 SEC and 1986 Sugar Bowl championship teams. Drafted in eighth round of 1986 NFL Draft by Cincinnati, playing Bengals from 1986-88 and New England 1989-90. Earned 1982 Volunteer award given each spring to a player who entered UT without a scholarship and then earned one

Former major league pitcher attended East Tennessee State University, playing both baseball and basketball. Drafted in the first round of the 1979 amateur baseball draft by the Kansas City Royals. Played for the San Francisco Giants (1982-1990), the San Diego Padres (1990-1991) and the Chicago White Sox (1994-1995). Selected to the National League All-Star team in 1983.

An Oregon State football signee, Hawkins led Knoxville's Fulton High School to consecutive Class 4A state football championships. A two-time all-state performer and All-PrepXtra choice, finished as Fulton's all-time leader in receiving yards (2,405) and touchdown catches (39). He was the 2013 BlueCross Bowl MVP for Class 4A and the Knoxville News Sentinel's PrepXtra Offensive Player of the Year.

Knoxville Rule High 1966 graduate was head football coach at Knoxville's Central High School from 1984-2010, mentoring such talented players as Reggie Cobb and Todd Helton. Compiled record of 194-105 and coached the Bobcats to a runner-up finish in the 1999 Tennessee State Championship. Was head soccer coach at Central from 1986-1996 with a record of 122-37-14 and head baseball coach in 2001, compiling a 22-5 record and winning the district championship.

Initial winner of Will McKamey Spirit Award, Anderson County quarterback suffered brain trauma injury after sophomore season, but returned as a senior to play well and contribute to team's success. Maintained 3.5 grade point average despite his injury. As senior, he accumulated over 3,500 total yards, with more than 1,000 rushing. Played three playoff games with broken hand and thumb on right hand.

Multi-talented athlete who excelled in basketball, softball, and volleyball, and is headed to Carson-Newman on a basketball scholarship. Graduated third in her class with 4.0 grade point average. She finished as Grainger High's all-time leader in points (2,056) and rebounds (1,366). Was 2014 Class AA Miss Basketball finalist and two-time all-state selection by the Tennessee Sportswriters Association (TSWA).

A graduate of Hall High School in Alcoa, where he was named an All-State basketball player and averaged 28.9 points a game as a senior. In 1962, was first African-American to sign a basketball scholarship with the University of Louisville. Played and coached professional basketball in Strasbourg, France, from 1970-171. Served as assistant basketball coach at the University of Louisville and head basketball coach the University of Tennessee.

Suffered life-threatening injury, a paralyzed right arm, daily pain, and constant physical challenges, in 2006 Tennessee-Air Force game, but has proven to have indomitable spirit thereafter, being a mentor to athletes and underprivileged children. Told his story in book titled, Inky: An Amazing Story of Faith and Perseverance. Earned a master's degree in sports psychology from the University of Tennessee

Won three medals, two gold and one silver at 1984 Olympics in Los Angeles. Had stellar career as Stanford University swimmer, winning NCAA title in her senior season. Was assistant coach of U. T. Lady Vols swim team 1993-98, helping team crack the Top 10 for the first time. Currently working as swim coach and teacher to children and adults of all ages at Knoxville YMCAs

A University of Tennessee signee and one of the more highly decorated football players from the Knoxville area this year, helping Webb School win three Division II-A state titles. Was the Knoxville News Sentinel's Defensive Player of the Year (2012), a two-time TSWA All-State selection, State of Tennessee Mr. Football Division 2A 2013 and 2014, Division 2A Most Valuable Player (2013), U.S. Army All-America (2013), and Gatorade Player of the Year (2013).

Auburn golf signee had exceptional prep career at CAK and received more than 80 offers from Division I schools. Was a three-time TSSAA Class A/AA individual golf champion, in 2010, 2012, and 2013 and was twice PrepXtra Girls Golfer of the Year (2011, 2013). Was a 2012 Rolex All-America selection and finished seventh at that year's USGA Girls Junior Amateur Stroke Play event.

A Collierville, Tenn., native was two-time Naismith and Kodak All-America during Tennessee Lady Vol career (1991-95). Inducted into Women's Basketball Hall of Fame in 2012. Member of the 1996 and 2000 Gold Medal Olympic teams and America's 1998 FIBA World Championship team. Joined Dawn Staley's staff as an assistant basketball coach at the University of South Carolina, serving since 2008-09.

Retired figure skater Peter Oppegard and partner Jill Watson won three national titles together and captured the bronze medal in Pairs Skating at the 1988 Winter Olympic Games in Calgary. With Watson, Oppegard is a 3-time US National Champion. Has coached skaters to 10 national singles and pairs titles. He is a 2004 member of the US Figure Skating Hall of Fame.

Jimmy Pitkanen played tennis at Oak Ridge High School (placed 3rd in state as a senior) and for 3 years at the University of Tennessee. Now the head tennis coach at Webb School of Knoxville, he began his coaching career in 1976 and coached at both the Cedar Bluff and Knoxville Racquet Clubs. He has been a USTA Training Center Head Coach and a USTPA and PTR Master Pro. He coached the Webb Girls team to six state championships and the boys team to four.

Wrinkle was football and track coach at Fulton High School in Knoxville from 1959-1964. Was instrumental in founding the Knoxville Track Club in 1962, that administered track and field programs in Knoxville. Served as the head finish judge for events held at Tom Black Track. Was co-director of the Volunteer Track Classic, an annual high school track and field meet, now in its 51st year.

Brian Brophy, a Tennessee track and field letter winner from 1990-92, transferred to Tennessee in 1990 after his true freshman season at George Mason University. In his first meet as a Vol, he set a school record in the decathlon with 7,627 points at the Florida State Invitational. In 1990, Brophy won the SEC Championship in the decathlon, posting a total of 7,537 points. He went on to All-America honors after finishing runner-up at the NCAA Championships. In 1991, as team captain, Brophy again earned All-America status after finishing in third place in the decathlon at the NCAA meet. He and teammate Aric Long combined to provide 16 points for the Vols out of the decathlon, helping the Vols to the 1991 national title. In 1992, he achieved the NCAA Championship, posting a score of 8,276 points to win NCAA gold and set a Tennessee program record. He currently ranks as the No. 2 decathlete of all-time at Tennessee, trailing only Olympian Tom Pappas (8,463). He was a two-time Ed Murphey Award winner, given annually for the best performance from the previous year's competition. He was on the United States Decathlon Team from 1990-2000 and was a 1990 Olympic Sports Festival gold medalist. He was also an alternate on the 1992 Olympic Team.

It came as no surprise that UT Chancellor Jimmy Cheek named Women's Athletics Director Joan Cronan as the interim Vice-Chancellor and Director of Athletics on June 9, 2011. Cronan served in that position until Sept. 5, 2011, when Tennessee introduced Dave Hart as its Vice Chancellor and Director of Athletics. Under Cronan's vision and direction, the University of Tennessee Lady Vols garnered a reputation as one of the most visible and respected programs throughout the nation. During her tenure, the Lady Vols won 8 national titles in basketball and 2 national titles in indoor track. Over the years, she worked diligently to not only keep the University of Tennessee as one of the premier women's athletics departments in the nation, but also to improve women's athletics on the local, regional and national levels. The University's success speaks volumes to her decision-making and leadership ability, as demonstrated by her appointment to the 2010 NCAA Division 1 Leadership Council and selection by her peers as the president of the National Association of Collegiate Directors of Athletics (NACDA) in 2008-09. In 1998, Cronan's work earned her plaudits from the Greater Knoxville Sports Hall of Fame, as she was named its Administrator of the Year. At its 2013 Tribute To Women, the YWCA of Knoxville bestowed her with Lifetime Achievement Honors. In 2014, the YWCA voted her among its Top 30 Women in the past 30 Years. She and her late husband Tom, who passed away on Aug. 18, 2006, after a valiant battle with pancreatic cancer, have two daughters, Kristi (Mrs. Rhett Benner) and Stacey (Mrs. Kent Bristow), both 1994 graduates of UT, three grandsons, Chase Thomas and Reed Kent Bristow and Quinn Leighton Benner, and two granddaughters, Reese Lauren Benner and Larkin Ann Bristow.

Antone Davis is entering his fourth year as director of the University of Tennessee's Vol For Life program. With the Vols, Davis manned the outside of a highly touted offensive line, lettering from 1987-90. He earned the Jacobs Blocking Trophy, emblematic of the SEC's top blocker in his All-America season of 1990. Davis helped create holes for tailback Tony Thompson in 1990, allowing him to rush for 1,261 yards that season. Davis was a part of two SEC Championship teams, in 1989 and 1990. Davis spent seven years in the NFL with the Philadelphia Eagles (1991-95) and Atlanta Falcons (1996-97). He started 87 of his 97 NFL games on the offensive line. Davis was a first-round draft pick by the Green Bay Packers in 1991, which selected him eighth overall. The Vols captured three bowl games in his tenure, winning the 1988 Peach Bowl over Indiana (27-22), the 1990 Cotton Bowl over Arkansas (31-27), and the 1991 Sugar Bowl over Virginia (23-22). The Volunteers were ranked eighth in the final Associated Press poll of his senior season and fifth in his junior year. A native of Fort Valley, Ga., Davis and his wife Carrie currently live in Knoxville and have four children, Cailyn, Dakota, Braden and Carley.

Herman Goddard has been synonymous with the local, regional, and national dirt track racing scene more than 50 years. One of nine children, Herman grew up in South Knoxville and was raised by his single mother when his father passed away at age 56. Herman's interest in cars began at age 11. When he was 19, Herman ran his first car race at Broadway Speedway in Knoxville in 1955. From there, his career spanned five decades, taking him to hundreds of events across the southeast, and securing a countless number of wins and awards. He won more than 400 feature races. At the top of Herman's most memorable list is a speeding ticket he received from the Cocke County Sheriff's department after wrecking during a race and sliding-upside down-from the track into an adjacent parking lot. Other memorable moments would include his induction into the Atomic Speedway Hall of Fame as well as the National Dirt Track Racing Hall of Fame in Florence, Ky. But to the family, friends, and fans of Herman Goddard Racing, the highlight of his career came at age 72, when, in one of the final races he ever drove at Bulls Gap, Tenn., he crossed the finish line with the checkered flag.

Bob Kesling, Vol Network Director of Broadcasting since 1999, is the radio play-by-play announcer for Tennessee football and men's basketball for the 70-plus station Vol Network. He hosts the Butch Jones Television Show and the Vol Calls and Big Orange Hotline radio shows. A four-time winner of the Tennessee Sportscaster of the Year award, Kesling began his association with the University of Tennessee as a walk-on fullback on the 1972 freshman football team. In 1974, he began working on the Bill Battle Show for John Ward as film editor and joined the Vol Network in 1976 as a pre- and post-game host and served as Ward's spotter. After graduating from UT in 1977, Kesling was named sports director for WIVK radio and began his play-by-play career as the voice of the Lady Vols basketball broadcasts in 1978, a position he held through the 1999 season. In 1980, he became sports director for WBIR-TV and served as the 6 and 11 p.m. anchor until 1999. In 1992, he became a member of the Jefferson-Pilot Sports broadcast team as a play-by-play announcer and sideline reporter. During that time, he was also the play-by-play voice for the SEC football and basketball championship games on the SEC Radio Network. Kesling and his wife, Tami, live in Knoxville and have two daughters, Allison and Melissa.

Charles McRae, a two-year starter in football and basketball at Clinton (Tenn.) High School, played college football at the University of Tennessee where he earned first team All-SEC and Academic All-SEC honors as an offensive tackle in 1990. McRae studied physics, computer science, and history, graduating with a Bachelor's degree in history in May 1991. McRae was drafted in the first round of the 1991 NFL Draft by the Tampa Bay Buccaneers joining fellow honoree Antone Davis, marking the first time in NFL Draft history that one school produced two top-10 selected offensive tackles in the same year. He played for the Buccaneers and Oakland Raiders during his career. McRae returned to the University of Tennessee in 2000 and earned a Master of Business Administration (MBA) degree in December 2002. During his MBA program, he worked as a Labor Finance Analyst at CSX Transportation, overseeing the analysis and modeling of labor trends. Upon graduation, McRae was chosen to be the first Administrator for Vista Radiology, PC, in March 2003, ]a position he held until October 2011. He also served as the Chief Manager of Integrated Practices, LLC in Knoxville. In November 2011, McRae joined Columbus (Ohio) Radiology Corporation as Chief Executive Officer. He has been inducted into the Anderson County (Tenn.) Hall of Fame and enshrined on the Clinton High School Wall of Fame. He married Lori Beth Baxter June 27, 2008, and they currently split time between Knoxville and Columbus. In addition to working and playing with their six children, McRae is a licensed pilot, PADI scuba certified, boater, and outdoorsman

Vernon Osborne was head boys basketball coach at Alcoa High School for 39 years, from the 1950-51 season through 1988-89. During that time, he established a record of 855-340, a .715 winning percentage. When he retired, he ranked among the Top 10 boys basketball coaches in the nation for wins. His 1959 and 1967 teams won the TSSAA State Tournament in the days before classification. Alcoa had runner-up finishes in 1965 and 1982. His teams had five 30-win seasons, nine 25-win seasons, and nine 20-win seasons. Osborne accomplished all of this at a high school that usually had a student population in the range of 300 to 500 students. He has been inducted into the TSSAA, Union College, East Tennessee Sports, Tennessee Sports, and Blount County Sports Halls of Fame, being an inaugural inductee into the latter. Following World War II service in the Army Air Corps as a pilot and bomber pilot instructor,Osborne earned his B. S. degree from Union College in Barbourville, Ky., where he played basketball and baseball, and his M.A. degree from the College of William and Mary, where he coached baseball and freshman basketball. Osborne is married to Margaret Ann Osborne, and he has two daughters, Betty Haile and Judy Davis.

Eddy Powers, a three-time Tennessee Vol football letter winner (1975-77), played quarterback and safety at Clarksville (Tenn.) High before signing with Tennessee under head coach Bill Battle in 1974. His officiating career started with the Knoxville City Recreation Dept. working youth games in the early 1980s. He then worked as a high school official in the Knoxville area, worked one year of Division III college football, three years in the OVC, and 13 years in the SEC. He was a field judge for 13 years in the SEC, gaining a reputation as one of the top SEC officials and officiating in the Rose, Sugar, and Fiesta bowls. During his time as an SEC official, Powers went through the arduous process toward becoming an NFL official. He worked games in NFL Europe during his last four years in the SEC and was constantly being evaluated by the NFL. His call to the NFL came in 2002, calling games there until 2008 as a field judge. His responsibilities were to monitor deep receivers, punt returners, and to stand under the crossbar and give signals on field goal attempts. He's not through with football, however, working Tennessee home games as the red hat, the coordinator for media timeouts throughout the game. Eddy and wife, Jay Ann, have three children, Clay, Dyland, and Gracy Jayne.

Knoxville native Gloria Ray is a graduate of Fulton High School, East Tennessee State University, and the University of Tennessee. She learned to play tennis from her brother, Danny, at the Boys Club courts on Caswell Ave. and went on to win a TSSAA state tennis championship. She taught and coached in both Florida and Mississippi before becoming the University of Tennessee's first women's athletic director. Under her leadership (1976-83), the Lady Vols won their first national championship (track & field) and all of the teams were ranked in the Top 20, three in the Top 10, and two enjoying a final Top 5 national ranking, laying the foundation for the Lady Vols' standard of excellence. The Lady Vol Leadership Award is named in her honor. When she was president and CEO of the Knoxville Sports Corporation, Knoxville served as host city for three AAU Junior Olympic Games, USA Gymnastics Championships, USA Track & Field Championships, and the USA Bowling National Tournament. Ray is associated with several other famous firsts. She was the first woman to chair the Knoxville Utilities Board's board of commissioners and the first woman to serve on the executive committee of the Blue Cross Blue Shield of Tennessee's board of directors.

George Robert (Bob) Woodruff was the athletic director at the University of Tennessee from 1963-85. Woodruff played for Gen. Robert R. Neyland as an offensive tackle from 1936-38, including the undefeated SEC and National Champion 1938 Vols. An Athens, Ga., native, he served as an assistant coach under Gen. Robert R. Neyland at Tennessee from 1939-41 and also served as an assistant coach at Army (1944-45) and Georgia Tech (1946) before becoming the head coach at Baylor (1947-49). Woodruff was head coach and athletic director at Florida (1950-59) and returned to Tennessee as an assistant football coach on the staff of his former Vol teammate, Bowden Wyatt (1961-62). Woodruff was named athletic director at Tennessee in December 1963 and held that post for the next 22 years. His byword for the program was, Any sport worth having is worth supporting. During Woodruff's tenure, Tennessee became one of the most successful athletic programs in the nation. Under his direction, Tennessee won national championships in football, cross-country, swimming and diving, and track and field, while also participating in 15 bowl games and eight NCAA men's basketball tournaments. Under his watch, there were five expansions of Neyland Stadium, the Armory-Fieldhouse became Stokely Center, and Tom Black Track became a reality. It was former UT president Andy Holt (1959-70), who once observed that Woodruff has a head full of sense. Woodruff died Nov. 1, 2001.

entry.category: Chad Pennington Professional Athlete of the Year
entry.description: Candace Parker is a WNBA star, currently playing for the Los Angeles Sparks. This past 2014 season, Candace posted a team-high 19.4 points and 4.3 assists per game. She finished third in the league in scoring, as well as marked her fifth All-WNBA selection. From January to May each year during the WNBA's off-season, Candace plays for UMMC Ekaterinburg franchise in Russia. In her first season with UMMC, she led her squad to the 2010-14 Russian Cup as well as the 2010-13 Russian League championship. She had a distinguished Tennessee career, helping lead the Lady Vols to back-to-back NCAA championships (2007 and 2008) and leading the team in scoring (20.6 ppg) and rebounds (8.8) her final season at Tennessee. She was also named the 2007 and 2008 Collegiate Female John R. Wooden Player of the Year, State Farm Player of the Year, Basketball Writers Association National Player of the Year and Kodak All-America. She earned the NCAA Final Four MVP award in both 2007 and 2008. Candace graduated from Tennessee with a major in sports management and a minor in psychology. She was an Olympic Gold Medalist in 2008 and 2012. She is married to NBA player and former Duke University All-America selection, Shelden Williams. They have one daughter, Lailaa Nicole Williams.

A 2002 All-SEC selection at Tennessee, Witten was a third round selection of the Dallas Cowboys in the 2003 NFL Draft. His memorable moments at Tennessee included a 64-yard catch and run against Michigan, in which Witten, playing at 6-5, 265, outran the Michigan secondary for a touchdown. In 2002, he caught the game-winning touchdown pass from Casey Clausen to give the Vols a 41-38 triumph over Arkansas in six overtimes. Witten built a Jason Witten Learning Center, complete with a state-of-the-art recording studio, at the East Dallas Boys & Girls Club center in March 2008. A month later, he dedicated another at the Boys & Girls Club in his hometown. He has also dedicated a third such center at the Halls/Powell Boys & Girls Club in Knoxville. In 2012, Witten became the first player ever to win the Bart Starr Award and the Walter Payton NFL Man of the Year Award in the same season. Previously, he was honored as the Pro Football Weekly Humanitarian of the Year in 2010. Jason and his wife, Michelle, have two sons, C.J. and Cooper, and two daughters, Landry and Hadley, and reside in Westlake, Texas.

Dr. Bill Youmans first moved to Tennessee from his native Tifton, Ga., to attend Vanderbilt University, where he graduated from medical school and completed his orthopaedic training. In 1968, after two years as a Navy Surgeon at Camp LeJeune, N.C., joined the Knoxville Orthopaedic Clinic and began work with Dr. Bob Brashear caring for University of Tennessee athletes. Since then, Dr. Youmans has provided the clinic care for all the University of Tennessee athletic programs and has been the orthopaedic consultant to numerous local colleges, universities, and high schools. Dr. Youmans has contributed enormously to the growth of the field of sports medicine and was among the first orthopaedists to employ the techniques of arthroscopic surgery. He was the SEC Team Physician of the Year in 2005. He was instrumental in placing medical personnel in each high school in Knox County during football season, assuring that these student athletes would receive the best medical care possible. The University of Tennessee honored Dr. Youmans and the Knoxville Orthopaedic Clinic with the naming of the Neyland Stadium Dr. Bill Youmans and Knoxville Orthopaedic Game Day Training Room in the Vol dressing room under the north end of Neyland Stadium on Nov. 18, 2005.

Hammaker, who signed with Kansas State University, averaged 18 points, 5.2 steals, 5 assists and 4.2 rebounds as a senior, was a Class AA Miss Basketball finalist. For her career, she averaged 18.1 points, 5.3 steals, 5 assists, and 4.2 rebounds. She was the 22nd rated guard in 2015 class nationally and the third-rated senior in Tennessee. She was a five-time All-State selection, four times in Tennessee and once in West Virginia. She was ated as a top 125 player according to ESPN's All Star Girls Report, Prospect Nation, Blue Star, and ESPN Hoopgurlz. She was an EBA (Elite Basketball Academy) All America selection. She was a 4-time All-Region 2AA Tournament selection (2011, 2013, 2014, and 2015). She was also a McDonalds All-America and Gatorade Player of the Year nominee. Under the leadership of coach Mike Capps at the Knoxville Girls and Boys Club, she was part of the 2006 and 2007 training league girls Jr. Pro state and national champions. In addition, she was a part of four AAU state championship teams in 2007, 2009, 2010, and 2011 with the Lady Pride and a 2009 GBA national championship under Coach Capps. She was a member of the National Honor Society and volunteers regularly at various organizations in the Geater Knoxville area, including Mission of Hope, Hope Resource Center, and the Boys and Girls Club. She traveled to the Bahamas on a mission trip to perform a basketball camp with local youth in the summer of 2014. She also coaches a third grade Tennessee Fury Boys basketball team.

Katie Collier, who has signed with Middle Tennessee State University, was a four-year basketball starter and five-year letter winner for Webb, playing a significant role in three Division II-A state championships. With an overall career record of 120 wins and 20 losses, Collier was a three-time All-State player and is fifth on the all-time scoring list at the Webb School of Knoxville with 1,418 points, behind Glory Johnson, Faith Dupree, Kitty Houston and Micah Scheetz. She was a state tournament all-tournament team selection in 2014 and 2015. Collier was the Region Tournament Most Valuable Player in 2015 and a member of the Region All-Tournament Team in 2014 and 2015. Coaches voted her District Co-MVP in 2015. Under the leadership of Coach Mike Capps at the Knoxville Girls and Boys Club, she was a part of the 2005 state and national championship teams in the Instructional Co-Ed League team and the 2006 and 2007 training league girls Jr. Pro state and national champions. In addition, she was a part of four AAU state championship teams in 2007, 2009, 2010, and 2011 with the Lady Pride and a 2009 GBA national championship under Coach Capps. On the AAU circuit, she was a 5-time State Champion. Collier has been an active member and an officer in the Fellowship of Christian Athletes (FCA) all four years of high school.

Gabriella Prevost has played soccer since she was four years old. She played for both the Knoxville Football Club and FC Alliance. She participated in varsity soccer for four years at Knoxville's Catholic High School. She has been a starting outside defender on the soccer team since her freshman year and was a team captain her senior year. She was named Rookie of the Year as a freshman and Defensive Player of the Year as a senior. She was picked to the PrepXtra girls soccer second team and was named All-KIL and to the Class A/AA TSWA All-State team her senior year. Gabriella ran for Catholic's track team for four years as well, racing in the 800m and 4x800m relay. In her junior year, the girls 4x800m relay won state in class A/AA in which she ran a personal best of 2:24. Her senior year, the relay placed third in the state. In her junior and senior year, she placed in sectionals for the 800m race. Prevost, who played a role in three state championships, one in track and two in soccer, will play soccer at Transylvania University, in Lexington, Ky.

In one of the most dominating performances by a Knoxville area running back in recent years, Nathan Cottrell, who has signed with Georgia Tech, set West's career rushing mark with 3,974 yards, helping the Rebels win their first Class 5A championship in 2014. That came on the heels of a runner-up finish in the 2013 TSSAA state finals. He was the state championship game MVP and a two-time All-State running back. For the season, he had 180 carries for 1949 yards (10.8 avg.) and 21 touchdowns. For his career, he had 334 carries for 3974 yards (11.8 avg.) and 48 TDs. He is West's all-time total yardage leader (5594 yards), all-time rushing leader (3972 yards), single-season rushing leader (1949 yards), and has the single-game rushing record (225 yards against Heritage). He also holds the single season average per carry record, 14.3 yards. He was a two-time All-PrepXtra selection, covering all of East Tennessee and two-time All-Region. He was a two-time High School Hero's Team selection and two-time High School Hero's Player of the Year. He was a two-time All-Region Running Back of the Year and two-time All-Region Returner of the Year.

After playing for the Anderson County Mavericks from 2011-2014, Fox signed with East Tennessee State University after leading the state of Tennessee in rushing yards as a junior and senior, finishing with 2,116 yards on the ground in 2014. He was a two-time All-State selection in 2013 and 2014. He was 3AAA District MVP in 2013 and 2014. Fox came back from an injury in his sophomore season to help carry his team in 2013 and 2014 and did exactly that. Over the course of those two seasons, he had 469 carries for 4,731 yards rushing, scoring 51 touchdowns and catching eight passes for 121 yards. Media reports described him as a punishing runner, playing at 5-10, 195. He marked his name into Anderson County Maverick history, wearing his father's No. 43. His career started in Dickinson, Texas, then to Foley, Ala., then to Anderson County. In 2013, he had his best offensive performance in the game against Knoxville Catholic with 433 yards rushing and four scores. That came on the heels of a 394-yard performance, with three scores, against Knoxville Central the previous week. He played in the 2014 Battle of the Border in Williamsburg, Ky. He is expected to major in engineering at ETSU.

During his freshman football season at Fulton High School, Williams's work ethic and athleticism immediately caught the eye of his head coach and position coaches, as he lettered as a defensive back and on special teams. During his sophomore season, his exceptional skill set, passion to improve, and leadership helped him cement several starting positions for the Falcons during his high school career. He excelled on defense as a lock-down cornerback, on offense as a dual threat wide receiver and Wildcat quarterback, and on special teams as, statistically, one of the nation's best returners. He helped lead the Falcons to three straight 4A state championships, as well as earning TSWA All-State Team honors in 2013 and 2014. After a spectacular senior season, he was named All-PrepXtra defensive back,All-KFL, and District 3-AA MVP, as well as being selected to play in Toyota East vs. West Tennessee All Star Classic and the National Guard Border Bowl. He also excelled as a track athlete, qualifying for the state track meet in 2013, 2014, and 2015, and winning the state championship as a member of Fulton's 4x200 relay team in 2013. Williams's parents are Debbie Edwards and Larry Williams, brother Devin Williams.

Hannah Tate made her basketball debut on the Alcoa Elementary fourth-grade team, but with no basketball experience at all, she was good enough that she made the team. She didn't look back and continued playing in middle school. While in middle school, she had the chance to play AAU basketball with her coach, the late Mike Sellars, who always believed in her and played a big part in her basketball career. As a freshman at Alcoa, she received a great deal of playing time and looked to be on her way to having a successful basketball career. At the beginning of her senior season, she awaited her doctor's release after suffering an ACL injury that July. That release never came. X-rays confirmed she had cancer, and on Nov. 9, she was flown to St. Jude Children's Research Hospital, where she was diagnosed with Wilms' Tumor, a type of cancer that starts in the kidneys. She has since had three major surgeries and was preparing to come home so she could start college at the University of Tennessee. After she had her final scans on July 6 and 7, more cancer was found. On hearing the news she still had cancer, she replied, I just have to fight a little longer. She's currently doing well, she's still in good spirits, and is taking things one day at a time.

William C. Bill Battle, or Doc Battle as many of his friends call him, was the consummately professional football official with more than 40 years of service in the Knoxville area. He officiated well more than 400 high school varsity football games in the area, plus additional state playoff games, a state championship game, and small college games. In his later years, he served as an area supervisor for the TSSAA.

Multi-sport star at South High in Knoxville was Tennessee fullback from 1971-73. Earned game ball after wins over against South Carolina (1971) and Penn State (1972). Had a 66-yard quick-kick in 1971 South Carolina game. Earned bachelors and masters degrees at Tennessee. Also played basketball as a freshman at Tennessee. Named Best Blocking Back in SEC by the Birmingham News.

Founder of the Knoxville Track Club in 1962 and long-time track official. Started the first track program for high school girls in Tennessee in 1967 and co-directed Knoxville's first youth athletics program, which now involves more than 3,000 children of all ages. Has served as statistician for Anderson County High School Football for the last 24 years. Was a competitive weight lifter until age 62.

A decorated graduate of Knoxville's Austin-East High School and Carson-Newman College. Led Roadrunners and Eagles to state and national titles, respectively. A member of Carson-Newman's Athletic Hall of Fame (2013). Played in Super Bowl XXVIII with the Dallas Cowboys. Was 1989 South Atlantic Conference Defensive Player of the Year. Had 11 career interceptions at Carson-Newman, returning three for scores.

A native of Nashville, Kenny Jones learned early on in his life the role youth sports play in the community. Jones had many positive role models during his youth, his parents, coaches, and teachers. Kenny attended Stratford High School and, after a successful athletic career, earned a scholarship to play football at the University of Tennessee for head coach Johnny Majors in 1978.

Had distinguished career in mixed Martial Arts dating to 1960s. Has taught more than 10,000 students and signing more than 250 Black Belt Rank Certificates. A member of the United States Martial Arts Hall of Fame, winning its Lifetime Achievement Award in 2008. Worked with the University of Tennessee's football team in 1998 and 1999, teaching defensive hand drills, split blocking techniques, and hand leverage techniques.

Swam on 1978 University of Tennessee NCAA Championship team. Was All-America selection all four years at Tennessee. Was NCAA individual champion in the 400 freestyle relay in 1978 and 1979. Inducted into the Tennessee Swimming Hall of Fame in 1995. Vols were second, third, first and fourth in the NCAA meet during his career. Member of the United States swim team in 1979 and swam in the PanAm Games.

Coached and taught at Knoxville's Central High School from 1960-77. Was named Fountain City's first Man of the Year and was part of the first class selected for Central's Wall of Fame and Central High's Sports Hall of Fame. Was elected Knox County Trustee in 1990 and Knox County Executive in 1994 and 1998. Is a former co-chair of the Public Trust PAC.

Ben Byrd, a legendary figure in Knoxville sports journalism, returned home from service in World War II in 1947 to begin work as a sportswriter for the Knoxville Journal. During his career, Byrd covered Tennessee and SEC football and basketball, the Kentucky Derby, the Masters, the U. S. Open golf tournament, the 1976 Montreal Olympics, and the 1984 Los Angeles Olympics.

Legendary Tennessee tennis coach Mike DePalmer once called Hallie Cioffi Carroll the best female junior to come out of Knoxville. She moved to Knoxville at age 10 and went to Bollettieri Tennis Academy at Bradenton, Fla., at the same time as Andre Agassi, Jim Courier and Monica Seles.

An exceptional athlete and coach who began playing sports at the age of five. Was Carson-Newman's Softball Player of the Year and softball's Best Offensive Player of the Year in 1993. Was inducted into the South Atlantic Conference Hall of Fame and was part of the first all-female class to be inducted into Carson-Newman University Hall of Fame.

Coached and taught at Farragut High School from 1962 until 1991. Had overall coaching record of 544-353 (.607). Gym at Farragut was named in his honor in 2002. A four-time Knoxville News Sentinel Coach of the Year. A 2003 inductee into the Blount County Sports Hall of Fame and in 2013 the Farragut High School Sports Hall of Fame.

Kentel Williams is a dual-sport athlete who graduated from Fulton High School and played varsity football and basketball all four years. He earned a football scholarship from Austin Peay University located in Clarksville and will major in broadcasting.

Micah Scheetz, a UAB signee, capped off a decorated prep girls basketball career this past March by winning Division II-A Miss Basketball for the second time. The four-time all-state selection and two-time PrepXtra Player of the Year helped the Lady Spartans to four consecutive state championship game appearances, including state titles in 2013 and 2015.

Megan Murray started running cross-country her freshman year in high school. Over the course of her four years, she went from running 21:13 to running 18:04 for a 5k race. After qualifying for the state cross-country meet her sophomore and junior year, she was the Region 2 AAA champion and AAA state champion her senior year. These performances led to her being placed on the PrepXtra cross-country first team in her sophomore, junior, and senior year.

Gatorade and Perfect Game/Rawlings Player of the Year in Tennessee. Drafted in the 16th round of the Major League Baseball 2016 draft, but chose to play for at Tennessee. Led his team to its first appearance in the TSSAA baseball tournament. Named first team All-State by TSWA and Tennessee Baseball Report. Pitched in the UnderArmour All-American game.

Eric Berry, who lettered as a defensive back for the University of Tennessee in 2007-2009 and was a consensus All-America selection in 2008 and 2009, was named the NFL's Comeback Player of the Year by the Pro Football Writers of America for 2015

Born in Ethiopia, but came to the United States in 2012. Began his athletic career playing soccer. Attended TSD and discovered he had talent for distance running. Set national records for deaf athletes, 9:37.65 for the 3200m (9:37.65) and 4:25.98 for the 1600m. Won the AAA Region 2 Championship with a time of 9 minutes, 38.97 seconds.

There's a saying that the true character of a person shines in a time of crisis, according to a story on CNN. There's no doubt of Zaevion William Dobson's character, according to the 15-year-old's friends and family. Dobson was shot to death Dec. 17, 2015, while shielding two girls from random bullets fired in an apparent gang-related shooting. For his heroic actions, Dobson posthumously received the Arthur Ashe Courage Award July 13, 2016, with his mother, Zenobia Dobson, accepting the award on his behalf. He was the youngest person to be so honored.

Cayla Arnold, a Tennessee softball signee, has garnered nearly every possible award for her tenure at Maryville High School over the past two years. She has had an impressive career, with a 51-9 record, 790 Strikeouts in 401 innings pitched, and an overall career ERA of 0.98. Her career batting average is .365, with 125 hits, 22 home runs, 100 RBIs, and 104 Runs Scored.

entry.category: Chad Pennington Professional Athlete of the Year
entry.description: Harrison Smith has had a distinguished football career, first at Knoxville's Catholic High School, then at Notre Dame, and currently with the NFL's Minnesota Vikings. In his senior season at Catholic, he was named Gatorade Football Player of the Year in Tennessee in 2006. He was listed by Rivals.com as the No. 25 prep athlete in the nation, choosing Notre Dame over offers from Tennessee, Auburn, and Alabama.
